PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TITLE.XREF: NATURAL HERITAGE TRUST OF AUSTRALIA BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 13 May.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering the Natural Heritage Trust of Australia Bill 1996, amendments 1, 17 and 22 on revised amendment sheet 181, moved by the Australian Democrats.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night I think we summarised everything that needed to be said about the advisory committee. While it is short of where we had hoped we would end up, it is certainly an arrangement that I believe will give people greater confidence in the decisions that the Natural Heritage Trust Fund is going to be making as far as where the money goes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move my two amendments together on behalf of the Greens to the Democrat amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Amendment 17, at the end of section 29B, add:

(2) Particulars of any requests from the Natural Heritage Ministerial Board to the Committee under this section in a financial year must be included in the annual report about the Reserve for that year.
(2) Amendment 17, at the end of section 29D, add:

(2) Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, the Minister must cause the minutes of the Natural Heritage Trust Advisory Committee to be made available on request to any member of the public and to be laid before each House of the Parliament at the time when the Minister tables the annual report about the Reserve.

These amendments will help the public. The first amendment requires that the annual report include for public information any requests that the ministers—Senator Hill and Mr Anderson—have made to this advisory board so that the public can see what is going on between the ministers who totally control this fund and the advisory board which is able to give advice when and if asked for by the ministers.

As I said last night, we are very concerned that this advisory board will not be able to free range. It will not be able to look into those matters that it thinks are necessary for the good running of this billion‐dollar fund from the sale of Telstra. It is going to be trammelled by the conditions which specifically outline the functions of the committee. That includes the first function, which is to advise the two ministers about the integration of the objectives of environmental protection, natural resources management and sustainable agriculture; and the second function, which is to achieve integrated outcomes for the operations of the reserve—that is, the spending of the money.

In both those cases I am concerned about the limitations of the word `integration'. It seems that the committee will be able to advise how to integrate the various components aimed at in the spending of this money—for example, natural resources management, environmental protection and sustainable agriculture but not on those features themselves. When we get to section 3, we find that this committee, when requested by the natural heritage ministerial board—that is the two ministers—can advise those ministers about other matters.

On the face of it, that means the environmental experts on this board will not be able to advise the ministers about anything the ministers do not ask for. They have a very closed circle which is very restrictive indeed. The first amendment would enable the public to see what the ministers have asked the advisory council to do. The second amendment states:

Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, the Minister must cause the minutes of the Natural Heritage Trust Advisory Committee to be made available on request to any member of the public and to be laid before each House of the Parliament at the time when the Minister tables the annual report about the Reserve.

That means the minutes of this advisory committee will be publicly available. That is pure public accountability. I do not think the minister would have any objection to that. I doubt that Senator Lees will have any worry with it either. I hope that the committee will be able to decide in favour of these two minor improvements in terms of public accountability of a very constricted advisory committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me very briefly indicate to the committee that the opposition will support these amendments. I said yesterday that the advisory committee, in our view, is not the answer. I do not think the advisory committee removes the real potential for the Natural Heritage Trust Fund to be used as a political slush fund, which does certainly appear to be becoming the modus operandi of this government. The opposition will support the two amendments because they open up the operations of the trust fund a little. They make the operations of the trust fund slightly more transparent.

SPEECH.PARA: The opposition supports all the requests between the ministerial board and the advisory committee to be included in the annual report, and I think the suggestion that the advisory board's minutes be made available to the public is a reasonable one. We say the operation of the trust should be public, because without public scrutiny the trust is open to abuse. I think there will be a real need for this parliament to scrutinise very closely the operations of all the government's slush funds, and we will be doing just that.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened carefully to the argument of Senator Brown, and I am not convinced that any benefit would flow from it. The annual report provisions within the bill are quite comprehensive. The requests that flow from the board to the committee are really internal matters. It just seems to me to be odd to include the communications between the board and the committee, as they occur during the year, within the annual report. The annual report will set out the workings of the trust for the year. In relation to the second amend ment, the fact that the minutes could be required at any time by any member of the public just seems to me to be an unnecessary intrusion upon the workings of the committee.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am rather surprised the minister has problems with minutes of a committee designed to open up the process and to make sure that the various programs under the trust fit together. We talked yesterday about the aims of the advisory committee, so I find it most concerning that the minister feels the minutes of the meetings are something that do not need to be available. I thought it would have been something that would cause no-one any great problem. The minutes will be kept as a matter of process. It is not as though there is any extra work to do. They would be available to those people who are interested and concerned about the programs being run, what the priorities of the ministerial board are and tracking where the money is going. So I do not have any difficulty with these two amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it quite extraordinary that the minister wants to cover up already. His control of this money—along with fellow Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Anderson—is going to be total. He is already treating this effort to get an advisory council as a bit of a show. It is nothing more than that.

SPEECH.PARA: He does not even want the minutes of that meeting available to the public—even though this is public money; even though it is being spent on so-called environmental projects, which are publicly competitive; even though the ministers are going to, on behalf of and in the public interest, refer matters to this council for its deliberation; and even though, I suspect, all members of that council are going to be very happy to be transparent—not this minister. He wants to cover up from the outset. He wants to put a blanket of secrecy over what this committee is doing.

The key to it is, he says, `When we—' that is, I as the Minister for the Environment, and Mr Anderson as the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, `send a directive to this committee to look at any matters that we may want them to look at, and I suspect there will be precious few of them, it is an internal matter.' I submit to you, Mr Temporary Chairman, that it is not an internal matter; it is a matter for the Australian public to be involved in. It is the Australian public's money and it is, of course, the Australian public's environment. When these ministers send requests and messages to this advisory council, it ought to be open and transparent and available.

Just last night this minister and the government in general were talking about transparency in the budget. They are holding up transparency as a virtue. By the way, I could not see it. The transparency that the minister is talking about came across to me as obfuscation and an ability to hide, but here we have him on test. Is he good and true to this word of transparency when it comes to the public interest? What he is saying is, `These are internal matters. They are secret. The directives that we as ministers are going to give to this advisory committee, and the correspondence in the reverse direction, we want to keep hidden. As the minister, I want to keep total control.'

It simply adds fuel to the fire of alarm that this is going to be a slush fund, that this is going to be a fund directed by the ministers with political bias, that it is going to end up favouring those who have the best connections with the government and with coalition members. If that is not the case, let us have it fully open.

The minister last night, along with coalition members and Senator Harradine, voted against the amendment that the Greens put forward for the whole of this fund to be disbursed by an independent panel. So be it. The minister is keeping total control. The Democrats have come along with a worthwhile effort to at least have some proper environmental advice going into the workings of this fund. It is a pretty modest advisory council set-up. It is totally limited, if you ask me—it is even hogtied—by the need to only be instigatory in terms of what it looks at when the ministers so direct.

BREAK.PARA: Here we have Senator Hill, the Minister for the Environment, for opaqueness, not transparency, saying, `I don't want my letters to this council open to the gaze of the public. I don't trust the public of Australia to see what I'm doing. I have designs on this money. I am going to use it with fear and favour and I don't want the public to know about that.' This cannot be read any other way. It is part of the pattern of this minister of putting the environment second to his own political interests.

If it was ever very clear that that is what is going on, it is clear in him saying, `I don't want these modest amendments to have the minutes of this advisory council made available to the public, and I particularly don't want—because it's an internal matter—to have my letters and correspondence to and from this committee open to public view.' It is an extraordinary snubbing of the public, thumbing of the nose at the public, thumbing of the nose at the public interest and thumbing of the nose at proper due public commitment to good and open government.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —For the record, I do not think it is necessary for this to be part of a statutory regime—it would be unusual and I think it is unnecessary. But I say to Senator Brown, if he ever wants copies of any formal requests—I presume he is talking about formal requests rather than just normal communications—in terms of the legislation, then I would be happy to let him have them. Similarly, I am sure that, if anyone approached us and asked if they could have copies of the minutes of the committee, we would ensure that they have copies of the minutes. But, again, you do not normally include these things within a legislative regime, and it just seems to me to be overdone.

—I agree with Senator Hill. To have this in a legislative regime is setting a precedent which is not a good precedent as ministers could then say, in respect of requests in other particular areas, `It's not in the legislation so you cannot have the minutes.'

BREAK.PARA: I do not know what the argument is all about. Senator Hill has spoken. Personally, I was thinking of voting for the amendment, but now we have had the assurance from Senator Hill that, presumably, if any honourable senator makes a formal request for the minutes or the other matters referred to in the particular amendment, they would get it. If you think about this for a minute, it is a bit of an unfortunate precedent if you have to have this sort of provision in legislation before ministers cough up with minutes of a whole range of statutory advisory bodies and so on.

I think that is our right, whether it is in the legislation or not. I think all honourable senators should consider what the minister has said and hold him to it not only in this particular area, but also in respect of other matters of information that we desire and are entitled to have, whether or not provisions such as the one that has been moved by Senator Brown are in the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Well I do think it needs to be written in.
—Oh!

—Senator Harradine exclaims about that, but he has not been listening. What the minister said at the outset was that he believed the communications between him and this committee were internal matters—that is, secret; that is, ought not to be readily available to be seen by the public. Senator Harradine has spoken with Senator Hill, because there was the possibility here that he would vote for this amendment and put the government in the position where it was required to do these things. Senator Hill has given an assurance. I do not accept it. The fact is that he may be minister now but he may not be minister next week or next year. Senator Harradine has been in this place long enough to know that the word given by one minister is not necessarily going to be that of another.

SPEECH.PARA: If it is good enough for there to be an open agreement about these matters being available to the public, let's write it in; no harm done. The very fact that the government, and apparently Senator Harradine, are now going to vote against this amendment means that they do not have total commitment to the words in the amendment—that is, to allowing these minutes and these messages passed between the advisory council and these two ministers to be, with assurance, available to the public as we go along. It is simply a good housekeeping measure. It is simply a good measure to ensure that future ministers and future communications between the ministers and the council are available to the public.

By the way, we are talking about two ministers. We do not have the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) here. We do not have a commitment from him. Even if we did, the giving of that commitment simply endorses the idea of the amendments. The government ought to be voting for this. I would have thought Senator Harradine, who is something of a stickler for transparency, for open government and for the flow of information to the public, would have been supporting this instead of blocking it.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Brown's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: (Senator Jacinta Collins did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Panizza.)

SPEECH.PARA: (Senator Bolkus did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Short.)
Question so resolved in the negative.
Amendments (Senator Lees's) agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—(9.59 a.m.)—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 12, page 8 (line 1), after "indirect", insert "causes and".
Clause 12, page 8 (line 21), omit "on Australia's economy and".
Cluase 12, page 8 (line 3), at the end of paragraph (a), add "and to estimate the effects of land and water degradation on Australia's economy".

These are small amendments inserting either a word or a clause to generally make the intent much clearer. In particular, regarding amendment 4, we believe that we should not just be looking at the effects of land water degradation but also addressing and examining the causes of that degradation—hence that amendment. Amendments 5 and 6 are basically putting the environment first in what is an environment bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will be supporting these.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very supportive of this. Senator Lees has pointed out—
—Why don't you sit down and we'll have a vote?
—Because your responsibility, Senator Hill, is to answer questions in the committee stages and not simply try to get this through without any debate.
—You are wasting hours and hours and hours.

—What I was going to say before Senator Hill quite rudely interjected was that the Democrats are saying, `Let's look at the causes of land and water degradation.' That should be a primary function here, not just seeking to mend it when it has gone wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the things that concerns me greatly about this fund is the provision in the farm forestry program for $22 million, plus an unspecified additional amount from the national vegetation initiative, to encourage the incorporation of commercial tree growing and management into farming systems for the purpose of wood and non‐wood production. The problem here is that the loss of woodlands and forests leads directly to soil and water degradation.

It would appear that the minister is satisfied to have money spent from this fund actually assisting native vegetation clearance and the loss of woodlands and forests on farmlands. Then he will provide the money out of the Natural Heritage Trust Fund to plant trees to make up for that. It can be seen as an incentive to degrade water and soil through native vegetation clearance. It brings to point this amendment to ensure that the processes leading to land and water degradation are not actually assisted out of this fund. This fund is meant to be for the protection of the environment, not for the degradation of the environment.

BREAK.PARA: I would like the minister to give the committee an assurance here and now that money from this fund will not be spent on tree plantation schemes which are following on the heels of natural vegetation clearance, and that money from this fund will not be allowed to actually encourage the loss of woodlands or forests into the logging industry or through the sheer impulse to clear native vegetation, through the incentive of then giving money to the people who are involved in those processes to get on with the tree planting scheme. We have to be very careful about this. One of the things that is worrying environmentalists right around this country is that this trust fund is, in its worst applications, going to be able to lead to despoliation of the environment, not to the fixing of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to follow up that question from Senator Brown with a further query in relation to Western Australia. Currently in Western Australia, the Department of Conservation and Land Management who, as far as we know, do not actually have in their legislative charter anything to do with organising or coordinating salinity programs, seem to be positioning themselves to try to get a fairly substantial chunk of the natural heritage fund. Would the government consider it proper to actually hand over money from the fund to an agency whose legislative role does not actually legally have an element of salinity protection? Would that be what the Commonwealth government would be prepared to do?

SPEECH.PARA: At the moment it seems that the Department of Conservation and Land Management are renaming programs so that it looks like they are putting in their bit but they are perhaps taking money out of programs to do with species and other areas where they are meant to be involved in order to position themselves to attract federal funding. Is this going to be the kind of process the federal government is going to be involved with?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly it is good news, in a way, if the state administrations are restructuring themselves to be enthusiastic partners in the Natural Heritage Trust and are investing in the whole range of worthwhile environmental programs thereunder. Exactly what CALM is doing in that regard, I do not know. We make no secret of the fact that at least a part of the fund will be applied through state instrumentalities, basically because we do not do the on‐ground works; a lot of it is supervised and run by state governments. That is why we are entering into partnerships with the states.

SPEECH.PARA: But we are not planning to substitute our money for theirs. We are planning that this be additional money. They have got to agree to the objectives of this trust and, of course, within the trust there are not only the salinity issues that you raised but also programs for endangered species and other environment programs. CALM has a feral animals program and a weeds program and we are happy to work in partnership with them with those programs because they are consistent with the objectives of the trust.

TALK.START.PARA: —So, if I might get this straight, you would be happy if the Department of Conservation and Land Management renamed some of their forestry programs and called them salinity programs, and if they perhaps pulled money out of biodiversity, and then you would reward them with a fairly large chunk to administer from this program?

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —Biodiversity is a very important objective of the overall fund. I am not so concerned about what they call their various programs. I am concerned with how the money is to be spent. That is why we are involved in these quite complex negotiations with the state governments at the moment—to ensure that as they administer their programs they do so consistent with the objectives of our trust, and biodiversity is a very important part of it. As you know, Senator Margetts, there are very major salinity problems in Western Australia. I hope that under the national vegetation initiative we can help contribute a significant capital base to start reversing the trend of an ever‐expanding destruction of the natural resource through the rising salinity level.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister did not answer my earlier concern that money from the fund would be spent in farm tree planting projects consequent upon native vegetation clearance. I put it to him again, through you, Mr Temporary Chairman, that $22 million plus an unspecified additional amount from the national vegetation initiative will go into the farm forestry program and the aim of that is to encourage `the incorporation of commercial tree growing and management into farming systems for the purpose of wood and non‐wood production'.

SPEECH.PARA: There is nothing there about the environment at all. It is a commercial operation. I ask the minister: is money from the Natural Heritage Trust Fund going to go into commercial operations or is it going to go to the environment? The two are mutually exclusive in this situation. Is the minister able to explain how he will be spending $22 million or more on commercial tree growing projects which have no environmental commitment and which indeed might be based on native vegetation clearance and be environmentally inimical? If that is so, I think the committee would like to hear it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not relevant to this part of the committee consideration but Senator Brown is again just reflecting that he is stuck in this time warp. His views on these matters are really reflective of what were the popularly accepted views 20 years ago when what we were doing to protect biodiversity and the like was to try and lock up more of our natural resources basically through national parks and the like. The real challenge today is not what occurs on reserve but what occurs off reserve. Certainly we will be supporting the reafforestation of non‐government lands and how we distinguish between private and public benefit is that principally the part that we look to be financially contributing to is the public benefit that flows from that.

SPEECH.PARA: I return to Senator Margetts's question about preserving biodiversity. The big challenge of the future is how we as a nation can help preserve biodiversity off reserve and that is going to require public contribution.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for that answer. I just wonder what contribution to biodiversity a handout to overseas commercial blue gum plantations may make.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will be supporting the Australian Democrats' amendments Nos. 4 to 6. We believe that the Democrats' proposal to ensure that causes as well as symptoms of problems are investigated as part of the land and water audit is a sensible suggestion. Senator Lees's other suggestion to rearrange the wording of clause 12 to place a greater emphasis on the environment by placing the reference to the Australian economy after the environment is one that the opposition is comfortable and relaxed about.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I put it again to the minister that the farm forestry program, which may receive $22 million‐plus out of the Natural Heritage Trust Fund has the aim not of environmental considerations pure and simple, as he would have it, but to encourage `the incorporation of commercial tree growing and management into farming systems for the purpose of wood and non‐wood production'.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a crop, and it may well be displacing native vegetation. We in this country are in the deplorable situation that in Queensland, in the latest year for which there are figures, nearly half a million hectares of natural vegetation was bulldozed into oblivion. It is a rate that approaches that of the forest clearances in the Amazon as far as area concerned.

In much of this vegetation clearance area the work has not been done to see that biodiversity is maintained. In fact, when I last visited Ayr in the sugar growing area of coastal Queensland, large areas of woodland—bushland containing rare and endangered orchids, amongst other things—were being bulldozed into oblivion without any proper environmental impact assessment and without any of the checks that probity would say that we ought to have as a nation if we are going to look after the diversity of species knowing that Australia has an appalling record over the last 20 years with the loss of some 20 major mammals and a whole range of other species due to the encroachments of agriculture, logging and so on.

Here we have got the situation where, on the face of it, money from the Natural Heritage Trust Fund may well go in as an incentive to clearing of native vegetation. It is not good enough for the minister to try and fob this off. I want to know if he will give an iron‐clad guarantee that money will not be used from this fund as an incentive to the clearance of native vegetation, that it will not be used simply as a subsidy to commercial agricultural operations and that it will not be given to those large corporations involved in the woodchip industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether Senator Brown is just being silly, or what. The whole purpose of this amount of over $300 million that we are putting in is to encourage the maintenance of remaining native vegetation and for revegetating.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that Australia has been overcleared, Senator. That is why we are doing something about it. That is why we would like to get this bill through and start the program. All that you seem to be intent upon is delaying progress as long as possible.

Through this program we can do something about it, something positive. That is why we have the capital fund. We have the potential to start influencing better practices. We have money to put in, off reserve as well as on reserve, to start achieving a better outcome which will be good for the environment and for all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, the minister is ducking the questions I put to him. They are very clear and very explicit. Also, he is talking about me being silly, and so on—and I will take that on the chin. But I know when someone is ducking and weaving, and refusing to be clear in answering questions to this committee for those who are listening to us or to those who might read Hansard .

BREAK.PARA: I put it to you again, Minister, quite explicitly: will you give this committee and the Australian public a clear assurance that money from this Natural Heritage Trust Fund will not be put into any project which would be an incentive to clear native vegetation; will you give the committee an assurance that money from this Natural Heritage Trust Fund will not go to the export woodchipping companies; and will you make sure that it is not used for commercial cropping purposes in the Australian agricultural areas?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have answered the question.
—The minister says no.
—I said that I have answered the question
—The minister says no because he has not answered the question—and let that be on the record. The second component I want to get to here is that he says—
—All you want to do is waste time.
—Let me take that on, Mr Chair. The minister is talking about wasting time. How dare he!
—Can we address the issues before the Senate?

—How dare he try to cut my time in addressing the issues before the committee! I will not fall for that. I am here in the public interest, and I intend to stand here in the public interest to try to get information out of this minister who is refusing to give it. That is not going to sit me down.

BREAK.PARA: I have another question for the minister. He said in answer to Senator Margetts that he is very pleased that state governments and instrumentalities, like the notorious CALM in Western Australia, are readjusting what they are doing to get their hands on money from the Natural Heritage Trust Fund. When we get to this natural vegetation clearance, why is it that the minister has not insisted that state governments have natural vegetation clearance controls in place before getting their hands on this money?

For example, why is it that the minister is so ready to be handing money across to Queensland government instrumentalities when there is this awesome rate of native vegetation clearance going on in that state? Why is it that the minister is so happy to be handing large components of the money to the Tasmanian government where, as I said last night, the advisory committee on the disbursement of these funds is not in the Department of the Environment but in the Department of the Premier and headed up by a logger from Forestry Tasmania? If that does not set the alarm bells ringing, what does?

There are no native vegetation clearance ordinances in Tasmania. There is not even a proper biodiversity protection system in place. What we do know is that the regional forest agreement process is coming to a head. Already it is very clear, as was said last week by a major independent assessor in the form of Professor Jamie Kirkpatrick, a professor of geography at the University of Tasmania, that this process is going off the rails; that it is not sticking to environmental excellence. Professor Kirkpatrick has also said that he is very concerned that we are not going to see biodiversity, particularly on private lands in Tasmania, protected.

That is the crux of this problem. The minister is not putting in place the environmental checks and balances. He is not using the leverage that this money gives to ensure state governments do protect the spectrum of wildlife—flora and fauna—in this country which is threatened by agricultural, logging and mining processes.

We are seeing the public becoming increasingly concerned that this money is simply going to foster the greenwash, which has become standard as far as this minister is concerned and as far as many of the applicants for this money are concerned. The minister has turned down an independent environmental committee to determine where this money should go. He is not going to put pressure on state governments to ensure that they do it right thing before they get the money. He will not give an assurance to the committee that this money will not simply be used for commercial purposes, for economic ends. He will not give an assurance to this committee that it will not be used as an incentive for the destruction of woodlands and, therefore, the degradation of soils and waters—and that is the point of Senator Lees's amendment here, to help tighten up on that just a little.

The whole thing is becoming a total disappointment, to put the least spin on it. It is shaping up as a slush fund which has lost the environmental imperative that the Australian people were promised when Prime Minister Howard announced this scheme before the election last year in the Dandenongs. The minister is being derelict in his obligation to this committee to—

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope you pointed that out to a few of your mates in Tassie who were conned by it, though.

—Senator Faulkner, if you are going to say that people in the environmental committee were conned by this, you will have to say that about the whole of the Australian public—and that is putting the onus on the wrong side of the fence. The fact is that involved here is a breach of promise by Prime Minister Howard and Senator Hill. They led the public to believe that this money would be—
—That is taken for granted.
—Yes, if you take a cynical view of politics, Senator Faulkner—
—I take a cynical view of Mr Howard and his promises on the environment.
—Senator Brown, could you concentrate on your third question to Senator Hill, please?
—Mr Chair, I am being diverted by the interjections.
—You are just determined to waste the time of the Senate.

—Senator Hill sees this as a waste of time because he does not like being put under scrutiny. But I am helping to explain why it is that more and more people in the environment movement and, more generally, in the public see this Natural Heritage Trust Fund as being a sham.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Faulkner described it last night as a slush fund. Senator Hill is giving no assurance that that is not a correct conclusion. We have in this committee the opportunity to tighten it up, to see that it does go to proper environmental objectives and to see that it is properly accountable. With the assistance of Senator Harradine of all people who stands, time and again, for proper process and for proper accountability of government, the amendments that the Greens, the Democrats and the opposition are putting forward are being serially knocked back.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, we all agreed to this amendment.

—Mr Temporary Chairman, you might tell the minister that interjections are out of order and that he should listen to me with the attention that I give him on the rare occasions that he does get to his feet, even though it seems he is unable to give the assurances that I seek.

BREAK.PARA: Once again I put those three requests to Senator Hill. I am not going to mention them again because it is becoming quite clear that he is not going to respond to them. Will you, Senator Hill, assure this committee that money will not go to the big export woodchipping corporations like North Broken Hill, which is currently engaged in logging pure rainforest as well as tall eucalypt forests and the destruction of the ecosystems in those forests in Tasmania? Will you give an assurance that this money will not be put into commercial agricultural ventures which have a commercial impulse and do not have environmental excellence as their outcomes? Will you give an assurance that it will not be used in any way that could be seen as a direct or indirect incentive to the clearance of native vegetation in this country?
Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (7) Clause 13, page 8 (lines 9 to 11), omit "to assist with the establishment and maintenance of a comprehensive, adequate and representative system of reserves", substitute ", by the year 2000, to establish and maintain a comprehensive, adequate and representative system of reserves".

After lengthy discussions with the government to try to improve this legislation, we have withdrawn quite a number of our amendments and are no longer pursuing them. I believe this is one that does need to be pursued. What it does is tighten up this clause by adding a time line—that is, we must focus on a time by which we establish a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system.

At the moment, `to assist with' basically leaves us with the year 2000, 2020 or the year 3000. While it is obviously an important part of this legislation that we look at establishing that reserve system, we are well behind at the moment when it comes to our rangelands and woodlands, and particularly in East Gippsland when it comes to forests. For the government to leave it open ended is a major concern and therefore we are seeking to actually focus the mind on a particular date or a particular time and hopefully speed up the process.

If we do not move now we will continue to allow clearing of land for agricultural purposes or wholesale felling, as is going on in East Gippsland, and the establishment of pseudo plantations on what was native forest land. They are finding in Errinundra Plateau that the rainforest is not regenerating. They are now moving in and planting and trying to develop plantations up there to provide yet another generation of trees for the woodchip mill. We cannot sit back and leave this to some time towards infinity so far as the current wording of this bill is concerned. That is why we are persisting with this particular amendment. We think that time is against us.

Urban expansion is important to consider when it comes to some of our coastal areas and reserving areas along the coast. I note that the New South Wales government has moved at last to designate a large part of Nadgee as a wilderness area. That is it as far as the New South Wales coast is concerned. There are no other areas they can move to put into an adequate reserve system. Unless we move fairly quickly and impress upon state governments that time is of the essence, I really see some major problems for some of the repre sentative samples of native vegetation that we want to preserve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with the sentiment of what Senator Lees says even though I cannot agree with the amendment. The reason I do not agree with the amendment is that we have recognised all along that the contribution of this fund, even though it would be the largest re‐investment of capital in the natural environment in Australia's history, will nevertheless only partly fix the problem. What is going to be needed is further capital, further cooperation from the states, as you mentioned, and further contributions from the non-government sector. Ultimately, I hope we will be able to achieve something for this country that we can all stand by and say is a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the marine environment, we are really only just starting on the challenge. What we are doing through this trust is directly investing a further $80 million towards these objectives. In terms of clause 13, which sets out that the prime objective of the reserve system is to assist with the establishment and maintenance of a comprehensive, adequate and representative system of reserves, we will put $80 million in to assist with that. By the year 2000 we will not be able to achieve everything that you would like to see and I would like to see.

But our objective is to more than make a start—it is to contribute more than has been contributed in the past. Hopefully, as we continue to build public enthusiasm for the project and public involvement, we will do even better. But to accept your amendment would be, I regret to say, a touch of unreality and it would not be appropriate to legislate that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The only touch of unreality about this is the minister's inactivity and his failure to rise to the challenge that is put into the amended clauses put forward by Senator Lees. In 1974, consequent on the flooding of Lake Pedder by the Tasmanian Labor government of the time, supported by the Liberal opposition with the hydroelectricty commission at the height of its power, the Whitlam government decided that there ought to be an Australian heritage commission set up with the aim of effectively establishing a comprehensive, adequate and representative system of reserves for this nation. A quarter of a century ago that aim was brought to the fore. It was found necessary to have a national viewpoint on this and not leave it to state governments because places of national importance like Lake Pedder would, if left to regional governments, from time to time be lost—to the loss of the national and the international community as a whole. Lake Pedder was of world heritage significance.

SPEECH.PARA: Here we have, 23 years down the line, a minister for the environment sitting at the desk here in the Senate saying that he hopes that this will come to be some time in the future but that he cannot and will not make a commitment to a full reserve system being established in the nation under the auspices of the national government by the end of this century. We know in the budget that a billion dollars are being set aside for great national projects for the centenary of Federation. But we cannot put in place, because of the lack of political will and a failure of vision by this Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), a system of proper national parks and protected areas to ensure that this nation's natural heritage is handed on to future generations.

We will have the minister getting up and saying that that is an old‐fashioned point of view. I would like to add to that by reading from a letter the Humane Society International has written to a number of us, including the minister, expressing concern about this Natural Heritage Trust in that it is a timely weapon to be used as leverage on state governments doing the wrong thing about the environment. In summary, it says quite sensibly that before the states get this money they ought to be obliged, amongst other things, to put in vegetation clearance controls to ensure that we do keep an adequate system of reserves and that we do protect the nation's extraordinarily rich and wonderful diversity of plants and animal life.

BREAK.PARA: The Director of the Humane Society International, Michael Kennedy, wrote to the minister just a week ago saying this:

This brief note is to express our extreme concern at the implications for the conservation of biological diversity that may arise from the Commonwealth, State and Territory actions in response to the Wik decision.

This concern stems from Government's proposals that may see some 42% of the country converted from leasehold to freehold status—exchanging government controls in pastoral leases (minimal as the are) for ownership that would permit a new range of primary production developments that may not be ecologically sustainable.
It was particularly alarming to read in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald,—
the letter is dated 7 May—

that the Queensland Government is already moving ahead to convert an area covering some 22 million hectares to freehold, relinquishing as the Government will, any powers it has to effectively protect biodiversity. The ill consequences for the natural environment in Queensland may be catastrophic in breadth.
Mr Kennedy goes on further to say to this minister:

It was also alarming to note that between January and November, 1996, the Queensland Minister for Natural Resources, Mr Howard Hobbs, has issued licences to clear 497,000 hectares of native vegetation. The Minister was also quoted in the SMH article as saying (in relation to the conversion of leasehold properties), "What this is about is providing security, so a future Labour Government can't come in with stupid things like land‐clearing controls or whatever. "'
The letter goes on:
As the recently published 1996 State of the Australia Environment Report noted, vegetation clearance is the greatest threat to the loss of biological diversity in the country today. We urge you—
that is, environment minister Senator Hill—
therefore to do all that you can to ensure that such wholesale leasehold conversions do not become a national feature of the Commonwealth's response to the Wik decision.
I will be asking the Biological Diversity Advisory Council (BDAC) to write to you along similar lines in regard to this matter, when it meets in Canberra next week.
That is this week. His final paragraph says:

May we also suggest, in the wake of the Queensland Government's attitudes towards land clearance, that any monies being sought by the Queensland Government under the guise of the Natural Heritage Trust, or indeed any other State or Territory Government that cannot demonstrate adequate land clearance controls (NSW for example is about to exempt rural land clearing controls from the provisions of the Threatened Species Conservation Act, 1995 ) be denied pending the adoption of policies that have been publicly debated, and widely agreed to be effective.

They are not my words; they are the words of an independent organisation concerned specifically with biological diversity. It has an international reputation and it is working to protect the species of this country in a world in which the loss of species is calculated to be some 50 to 100 a day, primarily due to the loss of natural vegetation cover, including forest.

The minister says, `Oh, it is unreal to expect us to be involved in a process leading to a comprehensive, adequate and representative system of reserves by the year 2000.' Minister, you are unreal in this. You are getting in the way of the expectations of this country that you, as chief environment advocate, because that is your responsibility as minister, will represent the aspirations of people who do want a comprehensive national park and reserve system to protect our magnificent range of species of creatures in this country, including flora, by the year 2000.

Every government comes along and says that it cannot be done in our time and now we have the minister saying the same thing. He is sitting there with his chin in his hand saying, `I don't want to commit myself to this. I am the Minister for the Environment. Why should I have vision as far as the environment is concerned? Why should I have a commitment as far as the environment is concerned. I have other parameters in this age of economic rationalism which I want to put first.'

I can only reiterate that the responsible position would be for the minister to accept the challenge coming from Senator Lees in this very worthwhile amendment. Instead, there is no leverage being used out of this billion dollar fund of public money to ensure that state governments do the right thing by protecting the nation's biological treasures. There is no leverage at all. In fact, as we have discovered in the last half hour or so, the minister is quite content to totally fail in his responsibility to ensure that the worst excesses of this fund are mitigated against while we have the opportunity to do so in this committee.

It is a pretty shameful process. I feel disgusted as an environmentalist to be confronted by what I see as a dereliction of obligation and duty to the environment by a minister and by a government which has enormous leverage through this fund to do the right thing. Senator Harradine, of course, is pivotal in this matter. If he were to use the position he has, we would be seeing these amendments getting up instead of being lost and we would not see the minister being able to get away with his obfuscation, his failure, and his wimpish attitude to the environment.

It is worse than that; he is actively against the interests of the environment because he is toadying to the economic rationalist impulses of the wider cabinet, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer of the day. They are, in turn, being very easily pressured into the dictates of the rich and the powerful, the stock exchange and the corporate sector which does not want to see clearance controls. Is Mr Packer, with his extensive leasehold interests in this country, going to want to see clearance controls, the protection of the nation's biodiversity or regulations that are going to trammel his economic interests? Of course he is not. The same can be said for a large number of other millionaires and billionaires in this country and, indeed, land controlling interests which are outside the country.

That is where the pressure comes from which is leading to this minister sitting there failing to answer challenges coming from the committee and certainly failing to rise to the occasion to use this opportunity to get something very positive and progressive done for the environment. As Senator Faulkner said, all that we are seeing established is a slush fund, an opportunity for green wash and window dressing, as the nation's natural vegetation cover and its grand forests in all those forested states of this country get clobbered at the greatest rate in history under licence from the very same minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me remind the chamber of what Senator Brown just said. He described the Natural Heritage Trust Fund as a slush fund. We are dealing with the Natural Heritage Trust Fund and the quite rigorous application of certain principles, including the principles of ecological sustainable development, in this particular piece of legislation. Senator Brown characterises it as a slush fund.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me also remind the chamber that if Senator Brown had his way, not one red cent would have been paid into the Natural Heritage Trust Fund, whereas there is over $1 billion being paid into that Natural Heritage Trust Fund. I think that is something about which we should rejoice and I think it is something that all Tasmanians would rejoice in their share of that particular fund being 10 per cent.

We are dealing with Senator Lees's amendment. The contribution made by Senator Brown has certainly done that amendment no good. All the minister did was suggest that we are only at the start of the aim to get a comprehensive reserve system. I think the minister has made perfectly clear—he can speak for himself, although I doubt whether he will—his personal commitment to ensuring that the moneys flow from the trust fund as quickly as possible and that the jobs start flowing from that. I support the legislation as it stands in respect of this particular clause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —What double talk! Senator Harradine says that he is about the rigorous application of ecologically sustainable development at the same time as he is voting down a Democrat amendment which says we should put in place a definitive system of reserves by the end of this century.

SPEECH.PARA: He says that he is after the rigorous application of ecologically sustainable development, but last night he specifically voted against the word `ecological' being put before `sustainable' when it came to the aims and objectives of this money being spent in the Murray‐Darling Basin. In a quiet voice, he lamented the fact that I did not vote for the loss of Telstra from public hands and the partial handing over of it to the private sector. There are very good reasons for that.

But what he did not say is that he has been totally inefficacious in terms of protecting the Tasmanian environment when he had an opportunity to do so. In fact, when other people were protesting and being sent to gaol during the Franklin campaign, he was questioning, in this chamber, their belief system. When he had the opportunity, before his entry to this chamber, to do something about Lake Pedder, he failed to do so. He went quiet on it. So Lake Pedder was destroyed.

In the decade and a half since the Franklin campaign, when it came to the protection of Tasmania's forests and the bulldozers moving in on Farmhouse Creek, the Lemonthyme Valley, Jackys Marsh and a range of other spectacular, beautiful and wonderful natural precincts, he failed to say anything. He was there as a quiet shepherder of the bulldozers and chainsaws. And he gets up with a hypocritical point of view—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I think you should address the matter before the committee and not divert to a Tasmanian debate.

—Thank you, Mr Temporary Chairman. It is very tempting because when Senator Harradine gets up he does tend to divert things to Tasmania. Of course, that is where my heart is a lot of the time as well—certainly in some of those areas that have been destroyed in the 21 years during which he has been in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, the reaction of the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) is notable. He has not said a thing, except that he is not in favour of this government aiming, by the year 2000, to set up a definitive, adequate reserve system in this country. It speaks for itself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Brown, as his piece de resistance, said that I voted against the word `ecological' last night. The reason, as he knows and as the debate last night will show, was that those words are specifically contained—and apparently he did not know it—in the legislation which we are dealing with. All of the measures must be consistent with the provisions of clause 21 of the bill, which is a whole clause about the principles of ecologically sustainable development. It defines what those principles are in great detail. So there was no need—and that was accepted by the committee—for that word to be contained as a descriptive adjective as was proposed last night.

SPEECH.PARA: I think those people listening to the debate will understand that there is little credibility in what Senator Brown has said on that particular matter and, might I say, on the matters that he has raised about me. He just would not know what I have done over the past 21 years. He ought to have a look at a few of the photographs of the wilderness that I have in my office. I am a great camper, Senator Brown, and I certainly am very much in favour of this Natural Heritage Trust Fund and its quick disbursement for the benefit of our natural heritage, particularly in Tasmania.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —It is refreshing to know that Senator Harradine is a great camper. So are many of the captains of industry, the loggers, the miners and the bulldozer drivers of this country. I remember Mr Ashton of the Hydro Electric Commission, at the time when they were aiming to destroy the Franklin River, saying what a great environmentalist he was. It is part of the cant that comes with those people who will not stand up for the environment—they say that in fact they are greatly concerned about it and have pictures on their wall. I have heard that so often before.

SPEECH.PARA: Here we have an opportunity for Senator Harradine to be backing a Democrat amendment to have this government bring into place, through the enormous leverage of this trust fund, a system of adequate reserves for the birds, the animals, the flowers and the trees of this country by the end of this century. Yet here we have Senator Harradine saying, `I'm not going to back that. I don't have the fibre, the strength or the commitment to make sure that this government is held to a clear and definitive plan instead of a lot of wish and wash.' The Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) has made it clear that he is not going to support it either. So Senator Harradine's pivotal vote is going to fail the environment again on this score. It is a pretty sad reflection on the role of the Senate, if you ask me, but there you go.

I think Senator Lees is to be congratulated for this amendment, as with other amendments she has brought forward. I think we are going to see a continuing process of such excellent amendments, which tighten this legislation up, defeated by the pivotal vote of Senator Harradine, who assists the government wherever he may by sticking to the loose, wishy washy, unspecified legislation that we have in the disbursement of these funds—a lost opportunity. And not least a lost opportunity to put leverage on state governments like those in Queensland, Victoria, Tasmania and Western Australia, in particular, to put an end to the open slather destruction of native vegetation cover, including our forests, which is the greatest threat to biodiversity in this country, and to ensure that that reserve system is put in place at least a quarter of a century after the national parliament took up the challenge of the national responsibility of governments to define where the Australian heritage was, to define its values and to take up the onus of protecting it.

Here we have the minister and Senator Harradine saying, in 1997, `We are not going to commit ourselves to that.' Senator Hill says that I have got thinking that is 20 years old. In fact he has reverted to pre‐1974 thinking and is divesting himself, against the wishes of this country, of the powers that he ought to have—and the responsibilities that he ought to have to several maverick state governments—over the impending rate of destruction, not protection, of this nation's environment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Just very briefly on this amendment: I have listened to the debate on this matter because it is something on which I did not come to the chamber with a strongly preconceived view of my approach on this particular amendment. Senator Hill, it is quite a genuine contribution on my part. I do not know why you laugh; maybe it is a laugh of frustration on your part.

SPEECH.PARA: But I do want to ask the minister briefly—understanding the points he makes about what might be the restrictions and constraints of placing a time frame or a limit on the establishment of the reserve system; appreciating the points he makes about the need for flexibility, and also the environmental challenges beyond the year 2000 as the reserve system may develop—what interrelationship he believes there is between that time frame and the capacity of his department to be able to meet such a time frame, given the very significant cuts to the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service that are outlined in the budget?

If the reason that you make that contribution, Minister, is because of a resource issue, if it is because of your government's own budget cuts in this area which are limiting the capacity of the government to move towards the establishment of the reserve system, then I think it does, in fact, diminish the strength of your arguments quite considerably and I would quite seriously ask you to make a contribution. When I read in the budget papers that the 1996‐97 appropriation for the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service goes from $43,378,000 to $35,858,000 this financial year, I am interested in the interrelationship between that cutback, in terms of the National Parks and Wildlife Service, and the capacity of the government to move towards the establishment of a reserve system by the year 2000.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of this fund and the $80 million is to accelerate progress towards a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system for Australia. What I have said in the committee is that it is unrealistic and therefore foolish to put within legislation an objective to achieve that outcome within the next 2½ years. What we will be able to do, as a result of this fund, is to make more progress than we would otherwise have been able to achieve.

SPEECH.PARA: Yes, there is some need for us to tighten administration of our parks structure, and that is being done through the budget, as Senator Faulkner has noticed. We inherited a very large deficit and we have all had to share the burden of that. That has meant some belt tightening, but it does not mean that in any way we are retarded in seeking our objective of expanding the reserve system of this nation towards that goal of a comprehensive, adequate and representative system as quickly as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that was a most unenthusiastic defence of the government's position from Senator Hill. It does not really go to the nub of the issue, which is what this cutback in resources means in terms of a capacity to establish that reserve system by the year 2000. It will be interesting to explore in other venues, particularly through the estimates committee process, what this means in terms of contribution of staff of the department in these important areas.

SPEECH.PARA: I also ask—and I would appreciate an answer to this question, Minister, if it were possible—what difficulty you have with linking this back to the biodiversity strategy. Of itself, it seems a not unreasonable request of Senator Lees, accepting that arguments can be mounted both ways in relation to the establishment of a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system by the year 2000, which at least is a very proper and worthy objective as a minimum. I fail to understand the government's position in relation to the biodiversity strategy as embraced in this particular amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —Establishing the CAR system is a contribution towards protection of our biodiversity, but it is not a total answer. What I said in answer to a previous question in this committee debate was that I think the greater challenge in the years ahead is not going to be so much how much we preserve biodiversity through the reserve system, but how we protect biodiversity in off reserve areas. That is why there is greater emphasis on the off reserve in this bill than has been the case in the past.

SPEECH.PARA: The development of the CAR system is important in terms of biodiversity. I agree with comments that have been made that, although we are a megadiverse country in terms of biodiversity, we have already lost a great deal—an extraordinary amount, actually—in the last 200 years. It is very important that we learn from those mistakes and do better in the future. That is really what the Natural Heritage Trust Fund is all about: to provide the capital base to those people who are real environmentalists; those people who want to get out and do works on the ground in order, in part, to protect what remains of our biodiversity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, I think that the government's miserable excuse that it cannot achieve the establishment of a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system in this country—
—In 2½ years.

—You have the advantage of the extraordinary contribution that I made to this proposal when I was the environment minister. You did not see those sorts of cutbacks in the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service during my stewardship of this important portfolio.

SPEECH.PARA: What this says to us is that that is the real priority of this government. The real priority is to say, `We will cut back the National Parks and Wildlife Service from over $43 million to over $35 million.' That is the truth of the matter. That is the real indication of the government's priorities. I came in to the chamber to the debate on this particular amendment. I had an open mind, but I am surprised at how unconvincing the minister's contribution and arguments have been. For that reason, I will be supporting Australian Democrat amendment No. 7 standing in Senator Lees's name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) said that we have to learn from the mistakes of the past. That is the very point here. Unless we have a goal and a target to protect what is left of the areas of greatest biodiversity and richness in this country, we will simply compound the mistakes of the past. Under this minister we have a record rate of destruction of forests where you have concentrations of biodiversity. We have absolutely appalling rates of natural vegetation clearance.

SPEECH.PARA: The point is that the minister, instead of using his undoubted powers and abilities in the leverage of this legislation to put a halt to that so that we do not compound the mistakes of the past, is an arbiter of an increased rate of destruction of habitats in this country. It is extraordinary double‐talk coming from Senator Hill. He has an extraordinary blindness to his responsibility, if I am as kind to him as possible.

It is an extraordinary dereliction of his duty, on the one hand, to say that we must learn from the mistakes of the past and, on the other hand, for him to be an agent of the slaughter of biodiversity in this country here and now. He is a prime agent through his direct removal of restrictions on the destruction of our forest and through his direct licensing of export woodchipping of grand forests.

Senator Margetts would support me in drawing his attention to the fact that the Giblett block of grand karri and jarrah trees in Western Australia is only being defended by a band of citizens against his injunction to the logging companies to go ahead, against the advice of his own Heritage Commission, because he has failed to come to the defence of those forests, though it is his responsibility.

We are seeing the clearance of pure rainforests in Tasmania, with all the birds, animals, insects and bats that depend on those forests. I was there on Sunday and I saw the roads going in. They are preparatory to clear‐felling, fire bombing and poisoning of these grand intact ecosystems because this minister has licensed it. He calls himself the Minister for the Environment. I would get into trouble if I used some other appellation. The fact is that he is the agent of destruction. He is the cause of destruction. He says glibly, `We must learn from the mistakes of the past.'

Anybody who has knowledge of ecosystems must be aghast at the minister's failure. It is even worse because he knows what he is doing. It is not as if he is inept. There is a deliberation in his destruction of natural ecosystems in this country. That is compounded by his failure to act now when he has the opportunity to use leverage to protect ecosystems against other state governments which are willy-nilly allowing the destruction of this nation's panoply of species, its natural heritage. He just mouths the public relations key words that seem to say that he is sincere and he is concerned. When it comes to action, he is on the side of the chainsaws and bulldozers. His own actions show that. That is why I have no concerns about saying that he is the worst Minister for the Environment in the history of this country.

Just at a time when we should have somebody who stands up for the environment, who is a campaigner for the environment in the box seat as Minister for the Environment in this country, we have somebody who, in my books, is selling it out. What a shameful performance! What a failure! What an insult to the people in this country who want to see our natural ecosystems protected for the sake of future generations as well as for the wellbeing of our fellow species!
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (8) Clause 14, page 8 (lines 17 and 18), omit paragraph 14(c), substitute:

TAB.TAB: (c) to ameliorate threats to Australia's marine biodiversity;

SPEECH.PARA: This is an amendment the government has accepted. I really think perhaps what we saw in the original bill was a mistake, an inadvertent shuffling of some of the words, maybe just a drafting error. All we are adding here, although it is not important, is a clause to the section on page 8. It just adds in that we wish, as one of our objectives, `to ameliorate threats to Australia's marine biodiversity'.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I confirm that we support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment and what it says.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Faulkner, your amendments Nos 5 and 6 seem to be similar to the one that has just been carried.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —The running sheet suggests to me that that is so, Mr Temporary Chairman. It is suggested to me, Senator Faulkner, that your amendments are now unnecessary.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Given that that is the case, and I understand that is the general view of the committee, I will not move amendments Nos 5 and 6 standing in my name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens amendment No. 4 goes to the meaning of sustainable agriculture for the purposes of spending money out of the Natural Heritage Trust Fund. What Senator Hill has, as it stands, is that the first meaning of sustainable agriculture is the economic viability of agricultural production. Later on it gets to this:

SPEECH.PARA: (b) the social viability and well‐being of rural communities;
(c) the ecologically sustainable use of Australia's biodiversity;
(d) the natural resource base;
(e) ecosystems that are influenced by agricultural activities.
It is a total economic orientation; it is not an ecological orientation. It is economic.

A little earlier, the minister simply failed to say anything when I challenged him to ensure that money from this fund does not go to tree farms replacing natural woodlands, because this fund is about protecting the natural environment, not about stimulating economic activities which are inimical to the natural environment. What we all want to see, of course, is a pursuit of environmental excellence which has, as a consistent rule, good economic and employment outcomes. Therefore, I move:
(4) Clause 16, page 9 (lines 6 to 17), omit the clause, substitute:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 16 Meaning of sustainable management of agricultural land

SPEECH.PARA: (1) For the purposes of this Act, the sustainable management of agricultural land means the use of land management practices and systems that maintain or improve the following:

PARA.TAB: (a) the ecological viability of agricultural production;
(b) the ecologically sustainable management of Australia's biodiversity;
(c) the natural resource base;
(d) ecosystems that are influenced by agricultural activities;
(e) the social viability and well-being of rural communities.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) to avoid doubt, for the purposes of this Act, property management planning in relation to the farm unit is taken to be the sustainable management of agricultural land provided that the plan has as one of its primary objectives the protection of Australia's biodiversity.

That is a very simple and clear amendment. It brings biodiversity and environmental good practice back to the major point in the spending of these funds. The minister may think economic considerations come first. I think the committee should put him back on course and make it ecological considerations. We are here considering a bill about the ecology of this country, the protection of this nation's environment. The minister and Senator Harradine ought to be refocused on that prime objective.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —Therein lies part of the misunderstanding, I think, in that we are focusing not only on an environmentally satisfactory outcome but also on sustainable agriculture. That is why we have this definition within the bill which encompasses the three arms of sustainability; that is, the ecological consideration, the social consequences and the economic viability.

SPEECH.PARA: Our objective is to ensure that agriculture in the future in this country is sustainable. Unless the three arms are, in fact, incorporated within the decision making process, it will not be sustainable. It is when it is sustainable, in the terms of this definition, that under this act we are prepared to support it. Too much of Australia's agriculture in the past has been unsustainable. That is the experience, for example, of the Murray-Darling Basin.

Again, we have sought to learn from those experiences and now provide a capital base which can contribute to putting in place in this country more sustainable agriculture than we have had in the past. We are now better informed. Farmers are better informed. We have a better science base. We better understand the fragile nature of the Australian environment. Recognising those facts, we are now better able to put in place practices that will ensure sustainability for the future. That is a key objective of this legislation and a key purpose of the funding. That is why we have the definition as set out in the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will be supporting this amendment. It is very similar to one that the Democrats persisted with earlier on when we initially started debating this bill. Our concern then and now with the government's wording is that economics is there again up at the top. While I listened to what the minister had to say about farming communities certainly improving their understanding of what is ecologically viable, the fact that the government again has economics ahead of all the rest does ring some alarm bells.

SPEECH.PARA: Economic viability for many of our farming communities has really meant economic survival in the short term. Their definition of economic viability unfortunately has been, `Can we hold off the banks and manage to put food on the table for another season?' Hopefully this bill is going to be working with and supporting those farmers, particularly many of those in landcare organisations, who at last understand that that is a very short‐term view of the world and of their property and who understand that they have to undo the practices of the past.

Indeed, it may cost them money in the short term to put back the trees and to remove some of the works that were put in years ago—perhaps, once we look at some of the salinity problems, dams will have to go. To again have this economic viability, they may need considerable economic support in the short term to get to the point where the farm is actually ecologically sustainable and the community socially viable. So while I understand that the minister has been saying the right words and certainly understands where the farming community should be heading, I think the government's wording of this particular section 16, which is the definition of sustainable agriculture, is still sending the wrong message to many people out there.

I want to congratulate those farmers who have made the sacrifice, because they knew they had to destock and they knew they had to give some breathing space between crops. But that has put enormous pressure on them economically. Indeed, if they go and ask their bank, the bank says to them, `Sorry. You shouldn't be doing that. You've got this interest payment due, and that payment due next June.' To put the economic viability issue in the definition again really confuses what this bill should be all about.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will support this amendment which effectively omits the existing clause 16 as it is currently drafted and replaces it with a new clause which, as Senator Lees says, effectively reorders the components of sustainable management so that economic viability is the last item, not the second. The proposed new clause also includes a phrase that management plans—
—No, it doesn't. It removes the reference to economics altogether.
—Is that right, Senator Hill?
—As I read it.

—As I read it, it also includes a phrase that management plans must have as a primary objective the protection of Australia's biodiversity. It is for those reasons that the opposition supports the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I presume the minister has absolutely no response to this. What he did say last night to Senator Lees in response to a very sensible amendment regarding the Murray-Darling Basin—where she had a number of conditions that should be fulfilled before money was spent out of this environmental fund on projects—was that she had the word `and' between each of them. Legally, his advice was that this meant all conditions should be met at the same time. In this clause as it stands, the minister has no `and' between any of them, and it would indicate that his legal advice is correct—that any one of the stipulations is enough to satisfy the conditions for the spending of money.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us take the first one, and let us read it out and see what the imperatives are for directing the use of funds out of this environmental trust fund, a la Senator Hill. It says:
For the purposes of this Act, sustainable agriculture means the use of agricultural practices and systems that maintain or improve the . . . economic viability of agricultural production;
