That is, maximum profitability. That's that. That is enough to enable him to spend money as far as agricultural sustainability is concerned—nothing to do with the environment; simply to do with the pursuit of profit.

The minister has been talking about the excesses and the damage of the past, but here he is aiding and abetting that philosophy going into the future. It is absurd and it is irresponsible. Senator Lees was quite right when she said that there ought to be support given to those farmers who are doing the right thing. There is 30 per cent or 40 per cent of farmers who are linked up with and involved with landcare; there are a majority who still are not.

It is time that support was given to those people on the land who, in very difficult circumstances, are doing the right thing. If there is going to be project money available, let us give it to those people who already understand the need for ecological sustainability as well as the need to provide themselves with a good income. This proviso as the government has it does not do that. The amendment from the Greens is aimed at giving those farmers involved in environmentally sound farming practices the assistance that they deserve.

Senator Hill is free, under the condition as he has it, to give it to any farmer who can show that they are in the pursuit of economic viability and profitability. It is as loose as that. He will get up and say, `Oh, I don't intend that' or `That's what I wouldn't do' or `I wouldn't do that in the future.' The fact is that we ought to be writing the prescription here in this committee in this Senate.

We ought to be ensuring that through the words of this legislation the money is going to the environment and not just to be pocketed by people who know how to use the system, know which levers to pull, know how best to get to the government, are already doing very well thank you, and will be able to get their hands on this money at the expense of those farmers who are really putting an effort into maintaining biological diversity and ecosystems on their farmlands.

The Green amendment is simply saying, `Let's support the farmers doing the right thing.' The government amendment, if you take that first stipulation, really means, `Let's support those farmers who are simply, at the expense of their land, into quick returns, and let the environment take a second path.' If the minister were sincere in environmental pursuit, he would be supporting this amendment.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Brown's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: (Senator Jacinta Collins did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Panizza.)

SPEECH.PARA: (Senator Sherry did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Short.)
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 17, page 9 (lines 21 and 22), omit "management of the use, development or".
(2) Clause 17, page 9 (lines 27 and 28), omit "management of the use, development or".

I had intended to move a motion to delete clause 17, which is the definition of natural resources management. Instead of that, I move the amendment now circulated which amends the wording of this clause by deleting the words, `management of the use, development or' where those words twice appear. Again, it is pretty simple, basic environmental logic that, if you are going to spend money on the environment and on natural resources management, you do it on activities relating to the conservation of soil, water and vegetation—and that is your focus.

What the minister is providing for in this clause is that, before conservation, you can spend money on the management of the use and development of soil, water and vegeta tion. That is totally around the wrong way. This is an environmental trust fund. It is not a development or use of resources trust fund. It is not meant to foster mining corporations which might be able to show that they are in the business of the use and development of the soil; dam building operations that are in the business of the use and development of water, or agricultural operations that are in the business of, for instance, the clearance of vegetation. It is about conservation, so let us make it about conservation. It is as simple as that.

The Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) and Senator Harradine—whose vote is pivotal to these amendments, which we are losing serially here today—ought to lift their focus and get back to the environment, which is what this fund is supposed to be about. It is pretty awful that, instead of that, the primary meaning of natural resources management in the clause as it stands—as far as Senator Hill, no doubt influenced by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Anderson, and Prime Minister Howard, are concerned—is the use and development of our lands, our waters and our vegetation. The woodchippers will love that. So will the Packer corporation and other big land‐holding investments which are in the business of potential land clearance further down the line. The dam builders, who see parts of our wild and natural remnant domain in this country as targets, will love it too.

This is a very rare piece of legislation devoted to the environment. Day after day, week after week, month after month we see going through here pieces of legislation aimed at fostering development and use. Here we have a piece of legislation about the environment, yet the minister has managed to put the environment last after development and use. The Greens' amendment simply puts it back to first where it ought to have been at the outset.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the clause is to be consistent with the definition under the Natural Resources Management (Financial Assistance) Act 1992 under which land care is funded. We are providing additional funds for land care through the Natural Heritage Trust; therefore we need a consistent definition so that we are not inhibited in making that application. It is as simple as that, and that is why the definition is as has been put within the bill as circulated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —That is exactly the point. It comes out of previous legislation which is to do with the financial assistance act of 1992. This is the environment assistance act of 1997. Get your focus right. We are talking about the environment here. Let us put the environment back on the frontburner. What you are doing is putting it on the backburner. The Minister for the Environment knows what he is doing. The government knows what it is doing. On the one hand, the government, along with Senator Harradine, is beating its chest and telling the public, `We've got all this Telstra money we are spending on the environment; it is unprecedented in history'. But, on the other hand, its policies are actually leading to a degradation of the environment—unprecedented in history—at a time when there is public alarm, particularly amongst the young people of this country. It is unprecedented in history as far as the environment is concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: There have been some excellent projects that have come out of land care, but there has been a lot of money frittered away as well, as many of the rural people who contact me tell me. The people who do the right thing ought to be encouraged. We should tighten up these definitions so that we see that it does go in the right direction. We should put conservation of soil, water and vegetation back in the place of priority from which Senator Hill has taken it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Brown has made a very good point. Despite the clear concerns that the community had, the government kept asking again and again why the Greens were not pleased to support the sale of Telstra because there was going to be all this extra money going to the environment. It is becoming patently clear as this debate is proceeding that the money is not going to the environment. The money is going to many different places. The environment is the least of the government's concerns and, as Senator Lees suggested, an afterthought. The fact that the word `ecological' is not in there suggests it is not about maintaining biodiversity but about using it, whatever that means, from the government's point of view.

SPEECH.PARA: Specifically, what I wanted to ask the minister followed on from my previous questions about the proposal to hand a big chunk of money to a lead agency in Western Australia, the Department of Conservation and Land Management. Was the minister aware of the fact that there is no legal charter for the Department of Conservation and Land Management to manage or develop specific salinity programs?

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I am not familiar with the Western Australian legislative structure in relation to those matters.

—I thank the minister for his candour. Considering all of the debates we have had in this chamber about accountability, would it not be reasonable to expect that, if money were to be handed over to a lead agency, it had the legal ability to use it for the purpose for which it was purported to be given?

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, but I think this expression, `handing over', is misleading in itself. What I have said is that we will be working in partnership with state governments and through their instrumentalities to effect the objectives of the bill. Obviously if the state authority does not have the legal capability, it cannot administer that program for us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The point is that the objectives of the bill in this particular clause are the use and development, before conservation, of soil, water and vegetation. Anybody who is at school today would tell this minister that an environmental trust fund ought to be aimed at the conservation of land, soil and vegetation. What the minister is doing is putting the priority on development and the use of biodiversity, but that includes in Western Australia a land management agency that is notorious for its destruction of forests and ecosystems and for the mismanagement of its environmental responsibilities.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Margetts is saying that a large amount of money will come out of this fund for the ostensible purpose of offsetting increasing salinity—it is an awesome problem in Western Australia due largely to agricultural and logging clearances—and it will go to CALM, the conservation and land management authority, which has not got in its charter the management of salinity. The minister says, `I will do it in consultation with state governments.' Let us not be diverted into the record of the Court state government. But, as we sit here today, let me repeat that that government along with this minister, who purports to be for the environment and has the label of Minister for the Environment, gave the licence to the chainsaws and the bulldozers to move in on the Giblett block in Western Australia and destroy a particularly valuable patch of it which the Australian Heritage Commission had told the minister in 1994 was of particular value and had put on the interim listing for the National Estate.

Who could have faith after that dereliction of duty? Who could have faith in this warped set of priorities that puts conservation last in a piece of legislation that is about conservation excellence? It is an appalling set‐up. It is an affront to people in this country who are alarmed about the loss of our natural heritage and about the loss of our flora and fauna—wildlife, habitats, ecosystems and environmental amenity. It is simply an invitation for those who are in positions of influence with this government to get their hands on some money for the use and development of our natural resources with a glib throw‐in of some conservation motive which all the worst of the environmental despoilers these days know how to do.

The amendment that the Greens have put forward specifically focuses on this minister's responsibilities because otherwise he is going to have total control—he has rejected having environmental experts make these decisions, and he is going to make them himself, with the minister for agriculture. The amendment would specifically direct his attention to the definition of natural resources management as being an activity relating to conservation of soil, water and vegetation. If the minister were up to it and up to his responsibilities, he would not only be supporting this amendment but would have written the legislation in that way himself.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Brown's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

BREAK.PARA: (1) Clause 19, page 10 (lines 25 to 28), omit subclause (3), substitute:
(3) An agreement under subsection (2) may be entered into:

PARA.TAB: (a) by either of the following Ministers on behalf of the Commonwealth:

TAB.TAB: (i) the Minister;
(ii) the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy; or

PARA.TAB: (b) jointly by both of the following Ministers on behalf of the Commonwealth:

TAB.TAB: (i) the Minister;
(ii) the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy.

BREAK.PARA: (2) Clause 20, page 11 (lines 12 to 15), omit subclause (3), substitute:
(3) An agreement under subsection (2) may be entered into:

PARA.TAB: (a) by either of the following Ministers on behalf of the Commonwealth:

TAB.TAB: (i) the Minister;
(ii) the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy; or

PARA.TAB: (b) jointly by both of the following Ministers on behalf of the Commonwealth:

TAB.TAB: (i) the Minister;
(ii) the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy.

BREAK.PARA: These amendments allow for agreements under the act to be signed by the Minister for the Environment or the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, or by both those ministers, as is most appropriate in the circumstances. That flexibility I think is important. The two departments have entered into a memorandum of understanding in relation to administering programs under this act.

Madam Chairman, as you know, this is an attempt by the federal government to join together the skills and experiences of both departments—the Department of the Environment and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy—in order to achieve the dual objectives of good environmental practice together with sustainable agriculture. So I put these amendments as a sensible process for sound administration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —As our amendments 12 to 15 are in conflict with the government amendments, I wish to ask senators if they would consider them first. I will explain very briefly why.

SPEECH.PARA: Our preferred option is that the environment minister be the minister with the final say on all matters relating to what is supposedly an environment fund. The government's amendment is basically giving the okay for the minister for primary industries to make decisions independent of the environment minister and we would have great difficulty in voting on this first. While we have been assured that there will be cabinet level consultation, there is no guarantee of that in this legislation.

Moving the government's amendments ahead of ours causes a considerable amount of difficulty for us. We are mindful of the fact that the government amendment is an improvement on the legislation. We welcome joint initiatives. That is our third option. Ahead of that is that the environment minister has the final say in all matters. Second to that is amendment No. 19, which I will move later, which gives him a veto if there is any conflict and gives him the final decision. This is a third option. It is certainly a lot better than simply leaving it to one or other of the ministers.

As noted on the running sheet, government amendments Nos 1 and 2 on BA340 are being moved first. As it says on the running sheet, they are in conflict with Democrat amendments 12 to 15. I would like to seek the indulgence of the chamber to look at our amendments relating to clause 19 first. If they go down, then we would look favourably on supporting the government amendments. I have great difficulty in doing it the other way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be as cooperative as always and am prepared to agree to that proposal. I seek leave to withdraw my amendments temporarily.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
Amendments withdrawn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (12) Clause 19, page 10 (lines 25 and 26), omit "either of".
(13) Clause 19, page 10 (line 28), after "Minister", insert "and the Minister".
(14) Clause 20, page 11 (lines 12 and 13), omit "either of".
(15) Clause 20, page 11 (line 15), after "Minister", insert "and the Minister".

I thank the chamber for its indulgence. I will speak very briefly to my amendments. This is one of the few groups of amendments that we have persisted with. We feel very strongly about them as this fund is spending what is largely environment money, although considerably less than the previous government had forecast it would spend. The fund has been set up—certainly the rhetoric during the election relating to the sale of Telstra gave the public the impression that it was to be set up for the purpose of dealing with the very great environment problems facing this country.

We feel very strongly that it should be the environment minister who should have the final say, in consultation with the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy as, because of the way this is structured, that is the other department which will be spending a lot of the environment money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —In principle this is a very worthy amendment. In practice it is hard for me to make a judgment as to whether Mr Anderson or Senator Hill would be the preferred custodian of the environment.
—Ha, ha!

—Senator Hill laughs. The situation is that we have a bill before us that effectively means that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, without an involvement of the Minister for the Environment, can make important decisions in relation to the future of the natural environment in this country. That is of concern to me. I am making the point Senator Hill that I am putting aside the personalities involved. It is possible in the instance we face at the moment that Mr Anderson may have more interest in protecting the environment than you have. You seem to cave in and roll over on every opportunity that comes before you to the interests of Mr Anderson and his colleagues from the National Party.

SPEECH.PARA: Regardless of that, regardless of the individuals that currently and temporarily occupy the positions of Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and Minister for the Environment, the principle is that the Minister for the Environment ought to have a clear role in making decisions in relation to these matters. Anything that ensures that the Minister for the Environment exercises his or her responsibilities in relation to this I think is an improvement. I stress that this is supposed to be an environment trust fund and, therefore, I believe it is proper that the environment minister be involved. In the view of the opposition, Senator Lees's amendments improve the drafting of the bill and ensure that both ministers have to enter into an agreement on behalf of the Commonwealth.

I urge Senator Hill to be far more serious about the exercise of his responsibilities in this regard; to take his responsibilities much more seriously than he has. It is disappointing to me that an environment minister could come before the parliament and propose that he not have a role in the administration of the Natural Heritage Trust in this way. That, in itself, says it all.

Even though you do not appear to be willing to protect yourself, Senator Hill, I hope that the Senate will agree to ensure that you have a role. Then the ball will be in your court for you to take up the cudgels on behalf of the protection of the environment in this country, and to exercise some responsibilities in the administration of your portfolio. It is a heavy responsibility that you have and we are all disappointed to see that you have abdicated it to Mr Anderson and the National Party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lees, you do not understand. The problem here is that the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) wants to divest himself of responsibility and power, and your amendment, Senator Lees, is giving him the appropriate responsibility to ensure that this money is spent on the environment. He does not want to take that. He wants to make himself even weaker than he is; he wants to wimp out on his responsibilities; and he wants to sell out the Australian people's expectations that they have someone in cabinet who will stand up for the environment. He wants to cave in, as Senator Faulkner was quite appropriately saying, to the National Party interests, the land clearers, the woodchippers and the environmental marauders of this country, and he will do it. But it is much better if he does not have to be seen to be doing it.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments that you are bringing forward, Senator Lees, would make him responsible as Minister for the Environment for the environment. That is not what Senator Hill wants. He wants to cop out; he wants to sell out on the environment; he wants to enhance his reputation, at least amongst the big boys of industry—those people who support his party—

TALK.START.PARA: —His reputation can only go up.

—It is going up with those tiny sectional interests that wield the power—and let the Australian people go jump. That is what Senator Hill says, in effect. Goodness me, here is Senator Lees from the Democrats saying that Senator Hill should have his signature and authority on the disbursement of all these funds. Senator Hill has a different plan. He wants the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson)—the minister for land degradation, if you like to see it that way—to be given the authority. That is the fox in charge of the chook house while the lame duck Minister for the Environment quacks on the outside hoping that nobody will notice that he is totally incapable and that he is effectively the agent of the fox and not the protector of the fowls.

SPEECH.PARA: What an extraordinary situation. You could skirt close to laughing about it if it were not so serious. Taking a more serious line on it, Senator Lees, of course you are absolutely right: commonsense would dictate that this minister would be making sure that he had the authority to look after the interests of the environment instead of divesting himself of it, and he would be endorsing your amendment—in fact, he would have written it that way in the first place.

BREAK.PARA: The real power here is going to be with the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The economically rationalist government of this country, whose performance on the environment is irresponsible, not only is disappointing the people who are concerned about the environment within this country but is increasingly leading to Australia getting an awful reputation internationally as a developed country which is turning its back on its environmental responsibilities. It is more about kowtowing to the coal and woodchip industries and the big agricultural corporations than it is about having the responsibility for the Australian people carried into cabinet through this minister.

He sits there and makes little comments on the side; he fails to get up when challenged on key points; he fails to get up and defend his role in selling the environment out. He is going to sell out as well on the opportunity which Senator Lees presents here for him to put a bit of muscle and fibre into his responsibilities—no doubt aided by Senator Harradine, who, if there is a division on the matter, will support the government, because that is consistently what he has done throughout this pretty tawdry sell‐out of the environment against the expectations of the people who voted for this government on the basis that this much vaunted Natural Heritage Trust Fund was really going to be about protecting and enhancing Australia's environmental fortunes.
Amendments negatived.
Amendments (by Senator Hill)—by leave—proposed:
(1) Clause 19, page 10 (lines 25 to 28), omit subclause (3), substitute:
(3) An agreement under subsection (2) may be entered into:

PARA.TAB: (a) by either of the following Ministers on behalf of the Commonwealth: (i) the Minister; (ii) the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy; or
(b) jointly by both of the following Ministers on behalf of the Commonwealth:

TAB.TAB: (i) the Minister;
(ii) the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy.

BREAK.PARA: (2) Clause 20, page 11 (lines 12 to 15), omit subclause (3), substitute:
(3) An agreement under subsection (2) may be entered into:

PARA.TAB: (a) by either of the following Ministers on behalf of the Commonwealth: (i) the Minister; (ii) the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy; or
(b) jointly by both of the following Ministers on behalf of the Commonwealth: (i) the Minister; (ii) the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said previously, these amendments are a long way from what we would have liked to have seen, but there is a marginal improvement in that at least the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) seems prepared to work jointly—and publicly jointly—with the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson). Perhaps it would be a good thing if the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy was involved in some of the decisions relating to the reserve system and biodiversity. Perhaps we will see an education process for many people in another department. They hopefully will come to understand some of the damage that activities in other departments have caused as far as protection of Australia's environment is concerned. So it is with some reluctance that we support this amendment, but it is marginally better than the way the bill now reads.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I agree with the comments that Senator Lees has made on this occasion. It is marginally better but only marginally. We still have a situation where the government's proposed amendments allow the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy to enter an agreement without reference to the Minister for the Environment. I really think that is the fundamental point.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have indicated earlier in the debate, as this is supposed to be an environment trust fund, the opposition believes that the environment minister must be responsible at least in part for agreements that are entered into to distribute the trust funds. I think that is perfectly reasonable. I am disappointed that Senator Hill did not seek the Senate's protection in this matter but while this is a marginal improvement it is only that. Nevertheless, as it is an improvement of sorts, it will be supported by the opposition.
Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (19) Clause 30, page 16 (after line 21), after subclause (3), insert:

PARA.TAB: (4) Where the Minister and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy disagree in relation to any decision taken under this section, the final decision lies with the Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment is a last ditch effort to claw back some ground on the issue we have just been discussing regarding ministerial responsibility. Basically what this does is argue that where there is conflict the final decision and the final responsibility rests with the Minister for the Environment. Perhaps if I can use as an example to illustrate my concern here what happened under the previous government when Aboriginal health really did not belong anywhere.

I have come into this chamber wanting to ask a question on Aboriginal health—in those days the Labor Party was over there—only to find the minister representing the minister for Aboriginal affairs pointing that way and the minister representing the minister for health pointing the other way and neither taking responsibility. Aboriginal health was with two departments and neither department wanted to own the problems at the end of the day.

Perhaps I need to use another example—in this case a hypothetical one. Let us go back to the forests of East Gippsland and let us presume you have given money from this fund into the Victorian government's program to move in and continue doing what they are doing on the Errinundra Plateau, which is turning what was rainforest and old-growth forest into plantation. The regeneration rates are so appalling that they are actually now hand planting part of the Errinundra. I was up there about a week ago.

That may be, according to the environment minister, leading to further problems relating to biodiversity—quolls and Powerful Owls are all being threatened up in that area now. But the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy would say, `That is fine. That is plantation. That is to be encouraged. Victoria should be getting that money.' If we came into this chamber with questions on this issue, who would answer the questions?

If I asked the Minister for the Environment questions relating to where this money from the trust was going and why it was going there, would you turn around and indicate that the question should be answered by the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy because it was his or her final decision to let that money go through to the Victorian government? Who is going to answer questions on the floor of the Senate if there are two ministers involved?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will because I am responsible for the legislation, but the scheme that is being set up is a cooperative scheme. It has been done deliberately. It is a new concept but we think it is time that Australia developed this concept in relation to its natural resources—that is, a cooperative approach towards these issues between those who have a particular focus on the environmental outcomes and those who have a particular focus on the primary industry outcomes.

SPEECH.PARA: It does give those of us who have the environment focus a greater input to primary production decision making in this country than has ever been the case in the past. To include a provision such as in this amendment would be inconsistent with that spirit of cooperation. It would send a wrong signal in fact. But, to use your hypothetical example, if you want to ask a question about that in this place then, as I am responsible for the legislation, I would be the appropriate minister to receive the question.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Therefore, Minister, can we have—I guess we can have it only for this government and for the life of this parliament—your guarantee that, if in either chamber questions are asked relating to the disbursement of money under the Natural Heritage Trust relating to why particular projects have taken precedence over others, it will be either you, as environment minister, or whoever the environment minister is, or your representative in the other place who will take final responsibility for ensuring that those questions are answered?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am interpreting the question technically because in terms of wanting to get the best answer you may prefer to ask the other minister depending on the question. In terms of technical responsibility, I think it is the environment minister because the environment minister is responsible for the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: If the questions are specifically related to a program that was primarily administered by the primary industries minister, such as landcare, you might prefer to ask that minister the question. But if you got up and said, `I want to ask it of Hill because Hill is responsible for the legislation,' then I will do my best to answer. Because I will now have a greater degree of input into the landcare program, particularly towards the biological diversity objectives, than has ever been the case in the past, I think I would probably be in a better position to answer the question than any previous environment minister.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the point made by the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill). I thank him for his answer because it basically confirms that what we are trying to do is not in conflict with the legislation; that we are only putting up this amendment to say that the final decision—should there be a problem—lies with the Minister for the Environment. If the environment minister is happy for the other minister to deal with the issue, to make decisions on the issue, to sign off on a state agreement, to sign off on a landcare agreement, that is fine, but we are talking about times when we need a final decision and somebody finally responsible. That is why this amendment, I believe, covers one of the very important issues that we really do need to come to terms with. It is not as threatening as you suggest; it is simply that there is a final resting point for ultimate responsibility.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will support this amendment on the basis that the Minister for the Environment would have the final decision on a matter where two ministers are in disagreement. Again, we offer the hand of friendship here to Senator Hill to assist him in the battles that we would like him to have within government to protect the environment, the battles that it appears he will just shy away from or turn his back on. It is disappointing, Senator Hill, that you will not take up the cudgels on behalf of protecting the environment. We are doing our best to help you. Please have the generosity of spirit to accept our assistance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I support that sentiment, Madam Chair. Can you imagine what the outcry would be if there were a piece of legislation or a suite of pieces of legislation dealing with economic development where the Minister for the Environment had a veto or a full equal say on the outcome? Of course, it would be a sensible thing to do, but it is so far from the unreal way in which the economic rationalists think and the pressures they have to respond to that there would be outrage. But here we have a piece of environmental legislation over which Senator Lees is proposing that the minister have ultimate authority and that it not be left to ministers whose direction can be totally against the environmental good, and the minister says, `I won't have it.'

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Faulkner says, the minister is not going to rise to the occasion. He can sit and swivel in his chair and occasionally smile, as he looks down, about his failure to defend the environment and his failure to uphold his ministerial responsibilities. Once again, Senator Lees has found that the minister cannot rise to the occasion.

Let us be clear about this: it is not a matter of the government wanting him to act in this way. This is a matter of a minister who does not have any fight for the environment in him, who is not an advocate for the environment and who is a handservant of people whose interests are inimical to the environment. We are seeing that pattern unfold in a pretty gruesome and totally unsatisfactory way here today in this debate.

But it is part of the face of this government that is being exposed here. It is part of the harsh, cold face it is turning against the warmth which Australians feel towards their environmental amenity. What we are doing a little of is presenting to that public the new age of environmental irresponsibility as the economic rationalists and materialists have full sway.

So we can have a minister for development and primary resource extraction and interests—and National Party interests. In Queensland, among other things, they advocate broadscale clearance of native vegetation, and laugh and scoff about rare and endangered species. In New South Wales they have wanted on occasions in the recent past to invade national parks and log them. In Tasmania, besides eulogising Pauline Hanson last weekend, they are terribly in favour of the woodchip industry as it marauds the rainforests and tall eucalypt forests which should have world heritage or national park protective status. Those interests are overriding this weak and irresponsible minister who is selling out, who cannot even stand the potential of being ultimately responsible for employing a veto over another minister who wants to spend money out of this fund in a direction that is not in the interests of the environment.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Lees's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: (Senator Jacinta Collins did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Panizza.)

SPEECH.PARA: (Senator Robert Ray did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Short.)
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (9) Clause 19, page 10 (after line 28), after subclause (3) insert:

PARA.TAB: (3A) An agreement under subsection (2) may establish a framework under which the Commonwealth and the State are to work cooperatively to achieve both common and complementary outcomes in relation to: (a) environmental protection; and (b) natural resources management; and (c) sustainable agriculture.
(3B) Subsection (3A) does not limit subsection (2).

SPEECH.PARA: (10) Clause 19, page 10 (after line 28), after subclause (3), insert:

PARA.TAB: (3C) An agreement under subsection (2) must include a requirement that a grant under this section must not be used to replace any existing programs in a State but must be used to fund additional programs.

SPEECH.PARA: (11) Clause 19, page 10 (after line 28), after subclause (3), insert:

PARA.TAB: (3D) An agreement under subsection (2) must include an undertaking that the State receiving the grant must not do anything contrary to the principles of this Act.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment No. 9 inserts a subclause relating to the potential for cost shifting. It has been a worry in other portfolios. The states find all sorts of inventive and unique ways of moving responsibility back into the federal government's coffers, and this involves money. We will deal with the other two amendments, which the government is not supporting, immediately after this.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think you are dealing with No. 10.
—Amendment No. 9 deals with the total issue, as well as Nos 10 and 11. I will be straying into the two that you are not supporting. For clarification, I will read the one you are supporting:

SPEECH.PARA: (9) Clause 19, page 10 (after line 28), after subclause (3) insert:

PARA.TAB: (3A) An agreement under subsection (2) may establish a framework under which the Commonwealth and the State are to work co-operatively to achieve both common and complementary outcomes in relation to: (a) environmental protection; and (b) natural resources management; and (c) sustainable agriculture.
(3B) Subsection (3A) does not limit subsection (2).

SPEECH.PARA: That is the very small step at the beginning of the process we would like to have seen. We would like to have seen the Commonwealth government really have some power to say to states, `Hang on a minute, you have pulled money out of that area; we are putting money in on the understanding that you leave your money where it was.'

BREAK.PARA: Amendments 10 and 11 are stronger amendments which would have given this minister far greater power. You would not have simply been relying on cooperatively working towards common goals. I believe it is really important to tie the states in both to stop cost shifting and to stop them doing things which are directly in opposition to the thrust of the aims and objectives of this fund. Two states—and Senator Brown has mentioned that Tasmania is one of those states—are still wholesale land clearing. Why are we going to give Tasmania money to plant trees, which they are legitimately entitled to apply for—and no doubt a number of landcare groups already have applications in—when we are going to allow the state government to keep signing licences for people to do whatever they like?

There is no protection for the vast amount of native forests on private land. Tasmania is in a unique position—and I stand to be corrected by either Senator Harradine or Senator Brown—because I think at least 50 per cent of its remaining significant forests are on private land. There is nothing in this bill to prevent wholesale clearing. Indeed, previous actions by this government, including opening up private forests for woodchipping, are encouraging this very thing to happen.

We were trying to give this government some power to say to the states, `If you want to get money under this fund, if you want to get money out of the trust, then you do not allow your farmers or your landholders to do anything that is in direct contradiction with the aims and objectives of what we are supposedly setting up as an environment fund.' Again, I acknowledge that in No. 9 the government is happy to talk about working cooperatively. Obviously that is the prime objective and that is the preferred outcome. But we are talking about two states—Queensland, in particular—which show absolutely no interest in stopping the clearing of between 500,000 and 800,000 and maybe even a million hectares a year.

Whether we talk about its impact on greenhouse, salinity or erosion, the impact is huge. We are setting up a fund to help farmers manage their land properly to undo some of the damage inflicted by previous generations, who came from a country that has much higher rainfall and totally different soils to us and presumed they could farm it using the same practices. The current generation of farmers is left with a mess to clean up at huge expense.

Of all the amendments we retain that the government is not supporting—and I think there is only another half a dozen—Nos 10 and 11 are really critical ones. It was not going to stop the states wholesale land clearing; they can keep doing that under state legislation. But it would have had a financial disincentive put in place to discourage them from doing that if they wanted money under this fund. It went beyond just land clearing.

Clause 11 provides that an agreement under subsection 2 must include an undertaking that the state receiving the grant must not do anything contrary to the principles of this act. If we go back to the principles in the act, we see that it goes well beyond just looking at native vegetation; it goes to endangered species, coasts and marine acquisitions. As the minister has said time and again in this debate, it goes right across a whole range of environment initiatives.

I turn to the amount of money allocated for the Murray-Darling Basin initiative. Queensland is one of the biggest remaining problems as it is clearing land that is within the basin. I believe its intention to put yet more dams on rivers that flow down into the basin is a problem that this federal government should be concerned about. While we cannot stop it doing that under this legislation or indeed under any Commonwealth legislation, we can at least discourage it by not saying, `Come on in, be part of all this and get money for this.' Under the Murray-Darling Basin initiative, they are entitled to money. It is an ongoing concern that this government and future governments will have, particularly with the Queensland government and to some extent with the Tasmanian government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been said, I agree with Democrats amendment No. 9, but I am unable to support amendments 10 and 11, although we agree with the spirit of the amendments. It is similar to the debate we have been having in regard to a number of other clauses. That is, whether you progress an objective through a cooperative arrangement—in this instance, a cooperative arrangement with the states—or whether you seek to pursue that objective through legislative prescription. We believe the former is more consistent with the spirit of the partnership agreements that we are establishing and is a better way of doing business.

SPEECH.PARA: The negotiations we have been having with the states have been cooperative. They have not always been easy. Some of the difficulties that we are seeking to overcome through those negotiations have been mentioned in this debate. Senator Lees mentioned one, and that is the practices in Queensland which might affect the flow into the Murray-Darling system. As you know, Queensland is now cooperating within the Murray-Darling mechanisms. Within that, there are certain obligations that Queensland will have to face up to. I think that will be the subject of some discussion at the next ministerial council meeting to be held in a week or two.

We will progress that matter, and it is a matter of making the case. What we recognise—although some in here have not been prepared to accept it today—is that this fund does give us a certain amount of leverage that we can use towards these better environmental outcomes. We do not start from the premise that the states are evil; we start from the premise that all Australians want to see a better environmental outcome. Now, through a cooperative arrangement, we have a funding base to help achieve it, but that is only part of the answer as well. The other part of the answer is the adoption of better practices, and we think we can influence better outcomes in that regard through a cooperative response.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge—indeed, I agree with the minister—that we should not start from the premise that the states are evil, but surely we should acknowledge history and fact. The fact is that there is no interest from Queensland in stopping the wholesale land clearing on leasehold land.

SPEECH.PARA: I will bring up another issue, and that is the agreements with the states. We have had some brief discussions previously regarding those agreements. Is it your understanding, Minister, that we will be seeing those tabled in this place so that we can watch the progress—hopefully it will be substantial progress—as you negotiate these agreements with the states?

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my understanding that they should be made public. It would be wrong for there to be an element of secrecy within them. I do not know about whether tabling is the right process, but there is certainly nothing to hide.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will support the Australian Democrats' amendment No. 9, which comes about as a result of a compromise between the government and the Australian Democrats. It is an attempt to ensure that some cross-compliance mechanism is included in the bill to ensure that the trust's funds are not granted to states which are pursuing policies that are contradictory to the stated purposes of the trust. We say that—and I do not want to be unkind to Senator Lees—this amendment is tokenism. We say that it should be stronger, but I appreciate this is the best you have been able to negotiate in difficult circumstances with a recalcitrant government.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the fact that, when you consider Queensland's clearing laws being in contradiction to the trust vegetation initiative, it really does provide a good example of why these mechanisms should be stronger in the bill. So we say that the amendment is weak but we also say that we will support it because it is an improvement on the first draft of the bill, which included no reference to cross-compliance at all. The issue of cross-compliance was considered to be a very important issue by the Senate committee, which recommended, in fact, that the bill be amended to include measures to ensure that no project receive funding where existing regulations worked against the achievements of the goals of the trust.

I also acknowledge the fact that Senator Lees has proposed other amendments which go further. The Australian Democrats' amendment No. 11 inserts subclause (3D), which requires states to give an undertaking not to do anything contrary to the purpose of the act, which effectively rules out state programs that undermine the intent of the trust. So that would mean, in the example that I used before in relation to Queensland, that they would not receive funds under the vegetation initiative while they continued to allow land clearing. Again, I think this is a good amendment. I am disappointed the government will not support it, but it will have the support of the opposition.

The Australian Democrats' amendment No. 10 that stands in Senator Lees's name, which is before the chair at the moment, also will be supported by the opposition. We think this amendment is important to ensure that the trust is accountable. It inserts a new subclause to ensure new funds are not only applied to new projects. It aims to avoid cost shifting between the states and the Commonwealth, as I understand it. It is unclear to me if such an amendment would actually prevent cost shifting. Nevertheless, on the information I have before me, I think it is worthy of support, and I inform the committee that it will receive the opposition's support.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the few minutes left, I will speak for the last time on these three amendments, and that is to amendment No. 10 regarding cost shifting. I wonder if this minister is aware of how inventive the states can be. Perhaps I can give you an example in health. It is pretty blatant when they start charging people against the Medicare agreement for emergency treatment in public hospitals. It is perhaps not so obvious when they start letting people out of hospital with only one night's medication and saying to them, `Look, just pop down to your doctor in the morning and get the rest of your antibiotics.'

BREAK.PARA: I wonder if this minister is going to watch the total amount of funding going from state governments to local governments in rural areas, particularly funding from local governments for things like roads. If you have a catchment group that has managed to get, say, $130,000 under this trust, you may well have a council, a local government authority, that decides they can take $130,000 out of road grants.

So, when we resume after lunch, I will need some confirmation from the minister that he is aware of some of the inventive practices of the states and that he is prepared to look at some of the total amounts of money flowing from the state government to local government and from local government out into regional and rural areas for things like bridge maintenance and roads.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to endorse what Senator Lees has said. What we have here is the government saying, in effect, that it does not want to have the states abide by the ecological tenets of this bill when they get the money. It is not going to do anything really to channel itself to make sure that the states do not just simply transfer money, which should be earmarked for the environment, out of their own coffers and replace it with money coming out of this fund.

SPEECH.PARA: Progress reported.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., I now call on matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling, Sen Grant

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take this opportunity to comment on a unique sporting opportunity currently being staged in the Northern Territory. The fourth Arafura Games commenced last Saturday, 10 May, and will run for a week through to this coming Saturday, 17 May. The Arafura Games began in 1991 and have proven an outstanding success, growing more successful with each biennial games. The games provide top level competition for developing athletes from all around the Asia-Pacific region and, perhaps more importantly, a forum in which Australia can develop relations with our close South-East Asian neighbours.

SPEECH.PARA: The first games saw 1,500 athletes compete from seven countries. By 1995, this had grown to 4,072 participants from 18 countries. This year, the impressive participation from 1995 will be further increased with a record of 5,253 participants involved from 26 countries.

There will be 26 sports contested at the games consisting of—and let me take a few minutes to list them—athletics, Australian Rules football, badminton, baseball, basketball, boxing, clay target, cricket, golf, gymnastics, hockey, lawn bowls, netball, pistol shooting, rugby union, sepak takraw, softball, squash, swimming, table tennis, tenpin bowling, touch, tennis, triathlon, volleyball and water polo.

The crowd favourite is sepak takraw. This volleyball-like game is a study in skill and coordination as it is played only with the feet. Athletes make spectacular overhead kicks to `spike', and this event alone is worth the price of admission, notwithstanding the many other high standard sports being played.

I would also like to acknowledge that the Defence Force personnel make an important contribution to the games, with a participating team of 265 this year. I am pleased that the Commonwealth government so actively supports this important event.

Perhaps the feature that makes the Arafura Games so unique is the atmosphere. Competition is of a very high standard but is played in the true sporting tradition. People from all over the Asia‐Pacific region come not only to compete but also to develop new regional links, renew old friendships and make new ones. The emphasis is on friendly competition and happily, unlike many other international sporting events, the Arafura Games has maintained and propagated this atmosphere between participants, spectators and the general population of Darwin.

This aspect of the Arafura Games is particularly important at the present time with an unfortunate and misguided atmosphere of xenophobia and racism being fostered by some people in Australia. The Arafura Games and the people of Darwin act as important ambassadors to the people of the Asia-Pacific region. The open, friendly and multicultural atmosphere of Darwin demonstrates to the participants of the Arafura Games that these views are held by a misguided few and are not the views of the vast majority of Australians.

The very make-up of Darwin with its cosmopolitan population of over 80,000 people comprising people from over 70 different ethnic groups shows the value of a multicultural society. They help contribute to a modern, vibrant, tropical city that could be used as a model of racial and social harmony for the rest of Australia, indeed the rest of the world.

In addition to its wonderful and unique population, Darwin is lucky to have sports facilities of the highest quality. The facilities which are used for the Arafura Games include the Marrara sports complex, which is located in Darwin's northern suburbs close to the international airport. This complex consists of the Marrara indoor stadium, a world class hockey field, a state‐of‐the‐art synthetic athletics track, soccer pitch, rugby field, baseball diamond, gun club, turf cricket wicket and a 25,000 capacity football stadium lit to television standard.

The majority of the sports played at the Arafura Games are played at the Marrara sports complex and this contributes immensely to the success of the games. Spectators and athletes are able to wander from event to event with ease that this close proximity allows. Transport to and from events is made as simple as possible with extensive use of public transport facilities and the general ease of commuting around Darwin.

The quality of these facilities and the general growth and potential of Darwin is demonstrated by Darwin's recent bid to host the 2006 Commonwealth Games. Whilst that bid was unsuccessful, the Australian Commonwealth Games Association representatives were very impressed with the bid, the existing facilities and the 10‐year master plan for Marrara. I am sure it now also exceeds the dream and the vision of the architect of that proposal, the now federal member for the Northern Territory, Nick Dondas, when he was an important minister for sport in the Northern Territory government. The master plan showed the potential of Marrara and is being implemented to enhance the facilities for Darwin residents.

Members of the Darwin community are enthusiastic supporters of the Arafura Games. Perhaps the best example of this support is the attendance at the opening ceremony. The opening ceremony spectacular is held at Darwin's international stadium at Football Park, Marrara. This year, the opening ceremony of the Arafura Games was witnessed by a crowd of 12,000 people. This is almost 15 per cent of Darwin's population, which is quite an amazing level of attendance for any event and shows the willingness and desire of the people of Darwin to view and support top level competition.

The attendance at the games for all events is a tribute to the organisers of the games and the people of Darwin. It also indicates the preferred way of life for most people in Darwin, which is outdoor living and making the best of the wonderful dry season climate. The climate during the Arafura Games is perfect for sport, with temperatures ranging from 18 degrees Centigrade overnight to 30 degrees Centigrade at midday. Most sporting events are held late in the afternoon and at night enabling participants to avoid the heat of the day and the maximum number of spectators to enjoy the games.

The Arafura Games enjoy significant support from the people of Darwin and also receive substantial assistance from the Northern Territory government. This includes providing a major events unit and funding for the 1997 event totalling $1.4 million. I would like to congratulate the Northern Territory minister responsible for the coordination of the Arafura Games, the Hon. Steve Hatton MLA, on the success of this year's games.

The staff at the Arafura Games office must also be thanked and congratulated for their hard work and for making the games such a well organised and friendly event. Particular mention must be made of the Arafura Games office's General Manager, Wally Mauger, and his staff for their untiring efforts to make the games a focus for sport in the Asia-Pacific region. They are an example of what can be achieved with vision, cooperation and hard work between government and the community.

The people of the Northern Territory must also be recognised for the large part they play in the continuing success of the Arafura Games. Many visitors comment on the friendly, relaxed and accepting attitude of Territorians and the support they provide for all competitors and officials. It is this aspect of the Territory character which makes the Arafura Games unique and creates the atmosphere that visitors and locals alike so enjoy.

In closing, I acknowledge the outstanding achievement of the Northern Territory team participating in the games. To date, the Territory's medal tally stands at 42 gold, 26 silver and 38 bronze—a total of 106 medals, which is 76 clear of the nearest rival, the Indonesian team, with a total of 30 medals. I wish all competitors in the fourth Arafura Games the greatest of luck and fortune and thank them for their participation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to talk about a matter which is of grave interest to the people not only of the ACT but of many people and businesses involved in the area of information technology. I make these comments in light of the budget statement that confirmed what we already believed to be so in the outsourcing of Commonwealth information technology services.

SPEECH.PARA: The first thing I would like to say with respect to this decision is to put information technology in the context in which it belongs. When we talk about the communications structures and the way in which a government department or indeed any private business communicates with others and delivers services to others, it is central to their purpose and to their business.

BREAK.PARA: In fact, the smooth running and smooth operation of communication and information technology services in any organisation, whether it be public or private sector, is a central feature of their competitiveness, of their state‐of‐the‐art position in industry, and of whether or not they are actually leaders in their field.

It is also becoming a major economic consideration for private businesses, as it obviously has become in the context of the public sector and hence the budget considerations. Private sector firms now make decisions on where they base themselves—based on telecommunications costs, the infrastructure, connection costs, call costs, et cetera. So we see departments now being forced by this government to lose control of their ability to make decisions about their efficient management, their efficient running and indeed the very services that are there between themselves and the clients that they serve—the public.

So you must question the motivation of a government that is prepared to outsource all of these services in a blanket approach when information technology and the way that these organisations and departments actually communicate are an essential tenet of their strength, their capability to compete and to provide a good, reasonable and accessible service.

I believe that the government's decision to outsource information technology is thereby flawed. They have removed the ability of the government departments in the Commonwealth Public Service to control the efficiency with which they deliver services and the efficiency with which they communicate with each other within different sections of the department.

This government has made the decision to outsource them completely. In doing so, they have compromised not only the departments' ability to manage this crucial resource but they are also cancelling out a number of developments within those departments that could look at innovative ways to communicate more efficiently—not just based on the hardware but based on the application of the various software products and innovative thinking from the policy makers on how services can be delivered. This has introduced another layer—potentially a very convoluted and complex contractual layer—between the department and an IT services contractor in the delivery of the bread and butter services of these departments.

Where is the efficiency in that? Let us have a look at the evidence. Evidence shows that the savings in this regard are not guaranteed; they are erratic. The government points only to the Department of Veterans' Affairs's IT outsourcing and claims that as a success. But when asked what else they are basing their assumptions of these savings on they say, `Well, we looked at the US model and the departments of veterans affairs are saving 20 to 30 per cent.'

I am paraphrasing, of course, but in questions asked in additional estimates only last week we know that the Office Of Government Information Technology, the office charged with handling this process, is not looking towards the South Australian model of outsourcing, which is a multi‐departmental—in fact a whole of government—model; they are not looking towards what is happening in other countries, according to them. They say there is a general trend but they are not prepared to even assess and gather evidence from the Australian situation in their decision making and modelling for how this process should proceed.

To go back to the Department of Veterans Affairs' model, it depends who you talk to as to how successful that is. The government holds up the bottom line savings, but if you talk to the people within that particular department, you start to get a picture of a lower level of service actually being delivered to the clients, of longer waiting periods to get issues addressed and of more inefficiencies being introduced in the department. This is by virtue of the fact that there is another layer of red tape within the bureaucracy in the delivery of these services. Where are the efficiencies in that? Indeed, where are the savings in that?

The Office of Government Information Technology, who are managing this whole process, were not able to point to a definitive model on which they are basing their process. They were able to point to the US arrangement, which is central to creating a group of departments based on a specific size called clusters. They are intending to initiate some sort of competitive tendering process relating to clusters of Commonwealth departments.

Unfortunately in this process, the Office of Government Information Technology has not embarked upon a wide scope of information gathering either with the private sector industry or even looking to other Australian examples of where outsourcing has occurred. They are taking advice from a very predictable source; that is, the private sector that has the most experience in this area. That is, of course, the larger end of the IT sector, the vast amount of which are what I term multinational companies.

Whilst the Office of Government Information Technology were not prepared to table the list of 21 companies that they say they have had extensive consultations with, it has become very clear to all of us on the opposition benches that the Office of Government Information Technology has set up a process which serves the purpose of these larger companies and effectively excludes the involvement of Australian information technology companies of a smaller scale, unless their involvement is introduced by a benevolent multinational.

What does this do for the innovative and vital sector that has so far certainly been one of the major growth sectors here in Canberra? It is certainly an industry which really does hold the key for our involvement on a global scale of the telecommunications and communications revolution. Why would you give away such an innovative industry and a role for the public sector in that process? Why would you give it away unless you had no regard for our industry development here? Why else would you give it away than if the dollar bottom line for one budget was more important than the future income stream from a growing industry?

There are other issues in relation to the outsourcing of information technology which add to the complexity of the issue and which explain why, now that the government has made this decision, they must proceed with extreme caution. Privacy is one of them—privacy of the data that is stored inside the blocks of computer banks, inside those central computing units within the government departments. That will go somewhere other than completely held within the confines of a department and therefore managed with the public interest at the forefront. How that is managed will be very interesting and worthy of close scrutiny.

The government is now talking about amending the Privacy Act to pick up the private sector. Whilst that is one step that can attempt to address some of these issues, it certainly leaves far too much ambiguity for the security of that very personal information to be in the hands of the private sector. I am not talking about just who has access to this information; I am talking also about what happens when something goes wrong. And things do go wrong with information technology. Mistakes happen. Who is liable when mistakes happen and that information is held by the private sector?

The question of Commonwealth liability for services contracted out by the Commonwealth is yet unresolved. It has been raised by the ombudsman and there is currently an inquiry being conducted into these matters, but as yet that inquiry has not reported to government. But their timetable for resolving these issues precedes that of the outcome of that inquiry. These questions must be answered.

The other issue is where this will take us. Let us imagine for a minute that the contracts have been signed, that there are a number of clusters—perhaps four or five major contracts. We are already seeing a situation where an existing contract that has been let is being used as a base to expand to another particular department. The words we hear about a competitive tender process do not ring so true when you start to see piggyback contracting occurring. Of course it was initially based on a competitive tender but, by virtue of the fact that those contracts can be expanded to the point where they pick up whole departments, this really exposes the piggyback tender process as being one that is quite insidious to departments becoming captive to the provid ers of these services. Where is the competition in that?

There is a two-year transition phase for most of the larger information technology contracts. It takes two years for them to be fully implemented. How competitive is the transition to the next contractor if the services provided by that one are unacceptable and there are too many mistakes? Is this going to happen in the blink of an eye? What sorts of pressures will the Commonwealth be under to inflict upon itself greater cost by virtue of the fact that they need to change the contractor because the service is just not up to scratch?

This points to two areas. It points to the true competitive nature of IT outsourcing and just how competitive it will be. It also points, once again, to the actual nature of the contract that the Commonwealth has or the department has with the particular service providers. Those issues are yet to be answered.

The Office of Government Information Technology has been charged with the role of standardising and managing this whole process. Where is the scope for individual departments to work on their own strengths and build on their own efficiencies? Where is the scope for that flexibility to be introduced to the point where perhaps what suits one department will not suit another? This goes to the point I made earlier about the outcomes in IT outsourcing elsewhere being very erratic. They are not always consistent. There is no flexibility, therefore, in what is currently proposed by the Office of Government Information Technology on this outsourcing process. That needs to be considered up front, before any contractual arrangements are entered into.

This process will deny Australian industry some of the vitality and innovation that it has shown in the past. It will hand over to multinational corporations control one of our most valuable assets, which is our ability to communicate as a government, as departments, as the providers of public service to members of the general public. I do not think that is a wise move and I think the Australian public will be the losers out of this exercise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Following on from the recent decision of the Federal Court on the status of East Timorese refugees in Australia, I believe it is crucial to place certain concerns not addressed in this decision on the public record. Since the Indonesian invasion of East Timor in 1975, it is estimated that at least 200,000 East Timorese peoples, almost one-third of the pre-invasion population, have died in what is one of the worst attempted genocides in postwar history.

SPEECH.PARA: Not surprisingly, many East Timorese people continue to flee the Indonesian military regime and seek international protection as refugees, particularly those politically active in the struggle for the people's internationally recognised right of self-determination. Although Australia has historically granted refugee status to some East Timorese, this act of support has been persistently fractured by a contradiction. Since 1975, successive Australian governments have granted political and economic support to Indonesia's so-called absorption of East Timor, the very reason that refugee status is sought.

In the past few years, this contradiction has been stretched to breaking point. Australia's desire to increasingly secure the good graces of the Indonesian government has spawned the government's push to demand that East Timorese be denied asylum on the grounds that many East Timorese in fact have Portuguese nationality and therefore should be denied refugee status.

The political opportunism of such a position has been widely condemned, particularly given the Australian government's strenuous arguments in the International Court of Justice that Portugal's current lack of connection with East Timor meant that it had no legal authority to represent the East Timorese in international fora.

The full bench of the Federal Court recently ruled on the question of the refugee status of one East Timorese man in Jong Kim Koe v. Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, a landmark decision which has implications for the 1,300 East Timorese currently seeking refugee asylum in Australia.

BREAK.PARA: The court affirmed the submission of the government that, as a matter of Portuguese law, the East Timorese applicant had acquired and retained Portuguese nationality. However, it noted that for a nationality to be operative within the context of the refugee convention it must provide effective protection from the persecuting authorities in Indonesia. Subsequently, the court has remitted the case to the Refugee Review Tribunal for this factual question of effectiveness to be determined.

From evidence presented to the court, it appears that it will be difficult for the tribunal to substantiate that Portugal can offer effective protection to the East Timorese currently in Australia. Most pertinently, the Portuguese embassy has stated that it will not process applications for Portuguese nationality within Australia. The Victorian Refugee Advice and Case Work Service has stated that this position means that the East Timorese will need to travel to Portugal and apply for at least two official documents, reliant on specific identification documents—a process which can take up to a year, during which time the East Timorese are forbidden to obtain employment in Portugal. The lack of certainty as to whether this onerous evidentiary regime will result in Portuguese status and the precarious financial situation of those even able to travel to Portugal suggests that such protection is less than effective.

Although the Federal Court decision has been greeted as a potential victory for the East Timorese, the court's resistance to embracing international human rights principles in the judgment has resulted in a much more limited victory than the East Timorese had hoped for and what they clearly deserve from this country. In particular, the court rejected key arguments from international refugee law experts as to the status of nationality within the fraught context of East Timor.

The question of nationality is not a flimsy or shallow concept within international law. It connotes a unique bond between the individual and her state of citizenship, so that the state stands in the position of trustee of the basic human rights of its citizens. Nationality is therefore a judicial and political link that unites an individual with a state.

In the first instance, nationality is a matter determined by the domestic law of the state in question. However, as noted by Professor James Hathaway, a leading international expert on refugee law, in order for nationality to be recognised at international law, there must be both an effective and genuine link between the state and its putative citizens so as to avoid sham nationality. There must be no international legal impediment to recognition of a grant of nationality per article 2 of the United Nations Convention on Certain Questions Relating to the Conflict of Nationality Laws.

Both of these issues were generally rejected by the Federal Court. However, I would like to elaborate on them for the information of the Senate. A central aspect of the necessity of a genuine and effective link between a sovereign and its national is that the sovereign is able to grant protection to its people, both domestically and abroad. Leaving aside the question of the lack of evidence of any social or political allegiances of the peoples of East Timor to Portugal, the fact that Portugal is clearly disabled from exercising protection of the East Timorese in East Timor due to the Indonesian invasion makes it rather ridiculous to suggest that the East Timorese are Portuguese nationals to whom Portugal, through its bond of citizenship, is entitled to extend diplomatic protection when the East Timorese are abroad in East Timor.

Simple comparisons of this situation with other instances of dual nationality are therefore inappropriate. More critical, however, is the interaction with the recognition of nationality in light of the United Nations human rights regime, particularly the legal duty of all states to take action to advance `peaceful and friendly relations amongst nations based on respect for the principle of equal rights and the self‐determination of people'. That is from the United Nations charter.

The right of self‐determination is therefore a pre‐emptive norm of international law which the International Court of Justice has stated `permits no acts derogating from it and no rules endeavouring to exist alongside it'. The right of self‐determination of East Timorese peoples has been consistently reaffirmed by central United Nations bodies, by the International Court of Justice in the recent case concerning East Timor, and by Australia.
