The two key human rights covenants suggest the impropriety of either a colonial power or the United Nations administering power automatically imposing its citizenship on populations which have the right to self‐determination. Therefore, unless the East Timorese choose to seek national protection from Portugal by pursuing nationality, states cannot ascribe that nationality when determining refugee status. Similarly, customary international law makes it clear that the principle of self‐determination posits a relationship between the people and a territory. Thus, an incident of the right is that the people's connection with the territory is not permanently severed. As Pene Matthew, an expert in refugee law from Melbourne University, has noted:
Nationality must therefore be considered in relation to the links of East Timorese with the territory of East Timor, not with Portugal.
The Australian government, in its submission to the International Court of Justice, has affirmed this by commenting that:
The purpose of the right to self‐determination is not to protect, far less legally entrench, the powers and rights of a former colonial power over a former colony.

Any attempt at the coerced transfer to and absorption of the East Timorese as nationals in the territory of Portugal effectively severs the link between a people having the right of self‐determination and their territory in a way that recognition of refugee status does not. Refugee status is necessarily temporary; it is able to be rescinded when the threat of persecution to the refugee has ceased.

From a different angle, a suggestion that the East Timorese people can be simply transferred to Portugal reflects the demographic manipulation which has occurred in East Timor, wherein the Indonesian government has instituted a policy of population transfer of Indonesians to East Timor as a way of establishing further foundations to deny the East Timorese their rights to self‐determination.
Commenting on this phenomenon in the context of refugee policy, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees has noted that:

Return of displaced persons and refugees to places other than their places of origin should not be a process of ethnic relocation so as to consolidate and complement ethnic depopulation and population transfers.

These arguments, based on the right of self‐determination, challenge nationality. They are separate from questions of sovereignty and, therefore, Australia's position on East Timorese as Portuguese nationals. They are consistent with Australia's recognition of Indonesian sovereignty over East Timor. The very reason for the existence of East Timorese refugees is directly entangled with their ongoing and bloody struggle for sovereign right of self‐determination in the light of an invasion which has been politically and economically supported by Australia. Their right to refugee status is enmeshed with international jurisprudence concerning self‐determination.

Since the Dili massacre in East Timor, these questions are attracting increasing international attention, culminating in the granting of the Nobel Peace Prize to two leaders of the East Timorese resistance movement. With the recent resolution in the United Nations Commission on Human Rights condemning human rights violations in East Timor, Australia's benevolent stance towards Indonesia is increasingly isolating Australia from the international community.

Domestically, the distance between the government's stance on East Timor and community views of the rights of the East Timorese are reaching crisis point, with nuns organising to hide possible deportees. The local political ramifications of such action would be significant for this government's credibility in the eyes of its constituency.

More generally, if we as a nation are to truly engage with human rights concerns, it is necessary to clearly name the structures which generate increasing flows of refugees within the world. Primarily, that would mean coming to grips with the fact that the vast majority of refugees flow from the countries in the eco nomic and political south. Unless we are to continue to engage in neo‐colonialist mentality that says such people are a little more violent, a little more backward and a little less able to politically control their territories than we are in the north, then it has to be acknowledged that the structures which create refugees are intimately linked to international economic power and political might. East Timorese refugees, coming from a territory which provided access to potentially huge oil reserves, are symptomatic of such situations.

As a country which has profited from the exploitation of such natural resources, it is about time that Australia repaid its debt to East Timor. Granting refugee status to those East Timorese fleeing a brutal regime is one very small step in this process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN MACDONALD
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —In last year's budget, the government allocated some $42 million to a great program in recognition of a commitment it had made prior to the election. That commitment was to young Australians for the environment, otherwise known as the green corps.

SPEECH.PARA: I thought it might be appropriate, after almost a year, to give an update of the green corps projects and the great work that the young Australians have done for the environment. You might recall that the campaign commitment by the coalition was for young people to volunteer for work in the environment and, while doing that, to receive training in environmental management and sciences. The projects operate in groups of 10 young people between the ages of 17 and 20—all volunteers. The government engaged the Australian Trust for Conservation Volunteers to be the project manager, so that the selection of the people and projects was sort of removed from the government.

There was to be a strong emphasis on linking the green corps to quality career opportunities. The participants who volunteer are paid a training wage, ranging from about $150 to $250, reflecting the number of years schooling the young person has completed and the time spent since leaving school. At the end of the program, people involved in the green corps will be eligible to receive a grant of $500 to assist with further educational expenses if they wish to pursue a career in the environment.

This exciting initiative of the coalition has become a reality and earlier this year the first 24 projects were launched right around Australia. I had the honour of being present at a couple of those launches—one in Malanda on the Atherton Tableland and one in Townsville—and it was tremendous to be able to talk to the young people involved, to get caught up in their enthusiasm, to talk with their project leaders and the partner agencies, and to generally see the sort of work that was being done.

There is a lot of community support for these projects and these groups. That was part of the rules—that was essential. All of the people involved—landcares, councils, different other partner agencies—have indicated to us what a tremendous program this is, so much superior to the LEAP program, which most of them will concede never really worked. This one, as a volunteer program, is one which really does involve committed young people and they do tremendous work in the community.

In mid‐March, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) officially launched the program at the Tinchi Tamba wetlands on the northern outskirts of Brisbane. We have recently announced the next 40 projects for the Green Corps. Perhaps it is instructive to mention a couple of them, mainly to indicate who the partner agencies are and some of the objectives, to give senators an idea of the very broad nature of this program.

For one program in New South Wales, on the Dorrigo plateau, the partner agency was Greening Australia, an environmental volunteer group that would be well known to those interested in the environment. That involved a farm forestry pilot project. In Queensland, some of the partner agencies for various of the projects include the Queensland Department of the Environment, the Noosa District Landcare Group, the Worldwide Fund for Nature, the Barong Landcare Association and the Mountains to the Mangroves Advisory Committees.

All of these partner agencies assist ATCV in getting these Green Corps projects operating. They involve a great number of projects, including restoration of reserves and littoral rainforest, surveying and construction of walking tracks, riparian rehabilitation, surveying of threatened vine forest remnants, and protection and enhancement of remnant bushland. So there are a lot of good projects being done by committed young people with support and finance from the federal government.

Those projects will continue. Each six months a new round of projects will be announced. We have invited input from all parliamentarians, amongst others. I invite honourable senators, if they have an idea or a suggestion on what could be looked at by ATCV, to contact ATCV with their proposals. In addition, community groups, landcare groups, conservation groups, councils—any sort of community groups—have been encouraged to think of projects and to put them forward to ATCV for consideration. It is a program we are very proud of. We think it will do great things for the participants and, of course, at the same time it is doing real work for the environment.

I thought the Senate might be interested in some of the statistics on the participants in the first 24 Green Corps projects. It was interesting to see that, of those involved, 23 per cent were 20‐year‐olds, 27 per cent were 19‐year‐olds, 30 per cent were 18‐years‐olds and 20 per cent were 17‐year‐olds. So we have got a fairly even spread of people right across the four age groups involved. In terms of their education level, 61 per cent had done year 12 or better, 20 per cent had done year 11, 17 per cent had completed year 10 and two per cent had not completed year 10.

In terms of gender, 43 per cent of the participants in the first round were female. That, of course, means that 57 per cent were male. Those of ethnic background were only one per cent and those of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander descent, four per cent. Twelve per cent of the participants were long‐term unemployed immediately prior to commencing a Green Corps placement; seven per cent of the participants were unemployed for less than 12 months but more than six months; 30 per cent were unemployed for less than six months immediately prior to commencing the Green Corps placement; but 51 per cent of the participants identified themselves as non‐unemployed immediately prior to the commencement of the Green Corps placement.

This perhaps emphasises that this is a program of young Australians committed and volunteering for the environment. It is not a make‐work scheme, as some of our opponents have, regrettably, not understood. It is a genuine commitment to the environment and it involves some training in those fields. As I say, 51 per cent of the participants identified themselves as non‐unemployed immediately prior to commencing work.

The fact that people volunteer does show that they have a commitment. They are not forced into this job or program. For that reason, it means that they have their hearts in it. They are doing it because they want to and because they have a real commitment to the environment. This is one of this government's most exciting initiatives. It represents the fulfilment of yet another election promise. It shows that, whilst the previous government talked a lot about the environment and made a lot out of votes from the environment sector, they really did nothing. This government has converted their rhetoric into actual action on the ground. It again shows this government's green and environmental credentials. We do not go out talking about it, as the previous government did. We do not rail endlessly about it, as the Greens in this chamber do, and vote against any sensible project the government has.

I remain disappointed that the Greens, the Democrats and the Labor Party opposed to the bitter end the means whereby this government could implement the Natural Heritage Trust, in respect of which we are pouring over a billion dollars into the environment. I sometimes wonder how the Greens can keep talking and talking about the environment and what needs to be done but, when the crunch comes, they vote against it. You only have to see what is happening in the chamber at the present time to know that the Greens are all about grandstanding and have little real interest in the environment and what happens to it.

I thought all honourable senators might be interested in that brief update on the Green Corps project. I again invite all honourable senators to contact the Australian Trust for Conservation Volunteers if they have some suggestions to make as to the projects that the Green Corps might look at. It is a tremendous program that is great for young people and very beneficial to our environment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise a very serious issue that goes to the interference in the legitimate freedoms of universities to select staff and to conduct their affairs without being dragooned by governments to support the prevailing political dogma of the day. I speak specifically of the case where the Victorian minister for education and training, Dr Phil Honeywood, made comments regarding Melbourne University's decision to employ Professor Arief Budiman as the university's foundation chair of Indonesian studies.

SPEECH.PARA: Given the host of political atrocities and the political jackbooting of Liberal leaders throughout this country, perhaps we should not be surprised to hear that some people regard this as a relatively minor issue. I am sure some would argue that if we were to look at it in the context of the string of abuses that are being undertaken by conservative governments across this country—the string of abuses to basic political freedoms long held to be important by Australians—the actions that the minister in Victoria has undertaken might be perceived to be unimportant. It is not a view I share. In my view, these actions go to the very basis of the ethos of accountability, the very important principles of academic freedom, and the important role that universities play in our nation's history and in the development of our political culture.

BREAK.PARA: I do acknowledge that Dr Honeywood's blunt attempts at intimidation may be minor when compared with other actions undertaken by the Kennett Government. Look at, for instance, the blatant political paybacks that have been directed at the Auditor‐General in that state, paybacks which effectively strip important responsibilities and tasks away from the Auditor‐General and his capacity to hold that government accountable in terms of its financial probity and capacity to undertake its affairs in an honest manner. It might then seem, in that context, that Dr Honeywood's statements are minor.

And, of course, when you do you look at the Auditor‐General's exposure of the criminal handling of the Intergraph ambulance service contract by this government in Victoria, perhaps, there is a point. But it was, nonetheless, important to understand that what Dr Honeywood has been arguing is a very dangerous escalation of attempts to intimidate universities, and to attempt to undermine basic human rights and freedoms in this country.

It comes at a time when this federal government is imposing, through the budget that was announced last night and through last year's budget, a range of measures which are seeking to undermine the quality and the breadth of services provided through our educational institutions. This is a strategy which is essentially aimed at reinforcing disproportionate power and privilege to particular sectors in our society.

It may well be that some would say, `Hang on a minute. You've got a government in Queensland, such as that of the Borbidge government, which is attempting to use fairly unsophisticated and very crude mechanisms to undermine Aboriginal rights in terms of their legitimate claims, as the High Court has found in terms of their native title entitlements.' And you see cases with other state governments, where similar patterns are emerging. But I still say that, given all of these matters, it is important to draw public attention to attempts being made by Dr Honeywood to undermine academic freedom in this country, which is, in itself, an important principle.

What is it that Dr Honeywood has done? I am sure that not all members of the Senate would be aware that Dr Honeywood has made the claim that Melbourne University was being used as a safe haven for the critics of the Suharto regime, and he has called upon the federal government to investigate Dr Honeywood's appointment. This is a ludicrous claim. As a former student of Melbourne University, I can assure senators that it is not a centre of real radical study. In fact, it is a bastion of conservatism. It is an institution that in many respects actually reinforces the power structures of our society. It does not really undermine the foundations of society as we know it but allows, nonetheless, for a quality education in many respects and a range of views to be expressed. But to suggest that it was a safe haven for critics of the Suharto regime seems to me to be a ludicrous proposition.

It is not coincidental that Dr Honeywood made his public criticisms of the appointment while he was leading a Victorian education delegation to Jakarta. Clearly, his motives were designed to try to placate what he perceived to be criticisms within the Indonesian regime. I wonder just how sensitive the Indonesian education administrators are and whether his criticisms reflect the opinions of the Indonesian government, or whether Dr Honeywood is undertaking actions that he believes will ingratiate him with our neighbour, Indonesia. I do not know the answer to that, but I do not think that it can be presumed that he is acting in a manner that was suggested by the Indonesian government. I have no doubt that Dr Honeywood may well have taken it upon himself to act in this most extraordinary, intolerant and offensive manner.

Professor Budiman is not only a leading Indonesian dissident—which of course is the basis for the claims against him by Dr Honeywood—but he is also a very important scholar in that country. He is highly regarded internationally as an outstanding scholar. He is a sociologist who resigned some two years ago from the Satya Wacana Christian University, after criticising the Indonesian govern ment, after advocating greater democracy for the Indonesian regime and after advocating greater democracy for Indonesians.

He was appointed to the position of Foundation Chair of Indonesian Studies, not for his outspoken criticism of the Indonesian government but because he was the best candidate for the job. This was a view publicly confirmed both by Professor Tony Stephens, the head of the Melbourne University School of Languages, which oversees the Indonesian section, and by the Vice‐Chancellor of Melbourne University, Professor Alan Gilbert.

Professor Gilbert has stated that `Professor Budiman is an outstanding scholar with an international reputation who was, on purely academic or scholarly grounds, the best candidate for the job.' Professor Gilbert has described Dr Honeywood's claims of a `safe haven'—that is, that Melbourne University is a safe haven for dissidents—as `preposterous.' Of course, Professor Gilbert is only too correct in that regard. Professor Gilbert also stated that Dr Honeywood's reported remarks were `contrary to the deepest most universally respected principles of institutional autonomy and of academic freedom.'
In defending Professor Budiman, Professor Gilbert said: The only politicians who have voiced such views in modern times are African dictators or members of totalitarian regimes.

Professor Gilbert's outrage is, of course, well understood. He is to be congratulated for standing up to the thuggish tactics of the Victorian government. It is a real pity that the Commonwealth minister for education, Senator Vanstone, did not have the same courage. Perhaps it is because she fears upsetting the Prime Minister in this regard or perhaps it is because she fears upsetting those in the Victorian government. It is nonetheless wrong that she has not undertaken the defence of academic freedom in this matter.

I would very much appreciate hearing what the Prime Minister has to say on this matter. I believe that Dr Honeywood's statements are quite clearly inappropriate and totally out of keeping with the political traditions of this country. Dr Honeywood has said that if this course was receiving federal government subsidisation it would be a cause for concern and it would have to be investigated. What an extraordinary proposition—that a state minister for education, in any capacity, should be saying that there should be a political censorship on the use of Commonwealth money for academic programs in this country. It is extraordinary for a minister in any government to be making that sort of an assertion.

I can only presume, since there has been no response from the Commonwealth government on these matters, that there is in fact a level of support for the attitude that is being expressed by Dr Honeywood. It is an extraordinary proposition that requires a response. I trust that the minister for education in this country, Senator Vanstone, will attend to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to draw the attention of the Senate to some very interesting political connections in Queensland. Just recently, there was a press report which said that a Mr Tony Pitt had been appointed secretary of the Hervey Bay branch of the Pauline Hanson One Nation Party. I would like to detail some of Mr Tony Pitt's activities in previous years and ask: is this the same Tony Pitt who was prominent in the ultra‐right Confederate Action Party, which soared to prominence during the 1993 election and then disappeared in chaos and internal disintegration not long after the election?

SPEECH.PARA: Is this the same Tony Pitt who was a key factional leader in the CAP and at the centre of the split which resulted in the demise of the Confederate Action Party? Is this the same Tony Pitt who was editor of the CAP newsletter Fight. I see Senator O'Chee nodding because he and I suspect that it is the same Tony Pitt. If it is, then Pauline Hanson should understand the kind of people she is welcoming into her party. To help her understand I thought I would read a few extracts from the Fight newsletter into the record. I think the Senate will find them interesting.

Let me firstly read a full‐page advertisement for an associated group that was part of the CAP network, a group called Australians United for Survival Individual Freedom, the AUSI Freedom Scouts. The AUSI Freedom Scouts were quite convinced that Australia was about to be destroyed and taken over by all kinds of invasions. The advertisement says:
Australia is broke, defenceless and its citizens are being disarmed. AUSTRALIA NEEDS YOU To Prepare and Equip to Defend OUR Nation Alongside OUR Armed Forces.

OUR PLEDGE:‐ We wish it to be known that the capacity to defend our nation does not exist and, if necessary, and in response to a call by the PEOPLE of Australia, we would willingly fill the huge gap between our defence capability and our defence needs.
OUR ACTION:‐
A.U.S.I Freedom Scouts should NOW go to stage II of preparedness . . . .. AMBER ALERT
1. Begin formation of small units of 5‐15 people in your own area. Coordinate with other groups. Encourage formation of groups . . .

2. Have your transport fuelled, serviced and in all respects "ready". Have your food, shelter, clothing and self defence equipment packed in your survival trailer or assembled ready for fast movement.
When sufficient people have completed Stage II then A.U.S.I. Freedom Scouts will advance to Stage III.
This is an interesting group. This next article is not quite so nice but let me put it on the record. There is a picture of a woman who has been tortured. The caption states:

This girl was seized by invaders, raped, tortured, mutilated, murdered. This could be your wife or your daughter, and it will be, if you allow the ALP, the Liberals, the Nationals and the Democrats to disarm us.
The article further states:
The Confederate Action Party will ensure that all Australians are defended, even if it is by guerillas armed with sporting rifles. That is about all we have now.
Senators can see that these are very interesting people and that they have some very interesting views. Another article in the Fight newsletter is headed `Immigration: YES or NO'. The article reads:

The government has admitted that if they give the 80,000 Chinese students who want to settle here, permission to stay, there will be an automatic influx of another 300,000 migrants into Australia under the next of kin provisions of the Act . . .
. . .. Too many migrants will soon turn this land into the sort of country migrants want to leave. We and our children will be left with the mess.
And so it goes on. Some of the policies of the Confederate Action Party are also printed in the newsletter. It says:
The Confederate Action Party of Australia will, when elected:

*Cancel the refugee programme, and in future draw immigrants from traditional and Christian countries, overall immigration to be reduced at present and to be in accord with national sensitivities and requirements.
*Eliminate government benefits from non Australians other than long term `tax contributing' permanent residents and introduce a five year wait for citizenship.
*Cancel foreign aid until our national debt is eliminated.

The newsletter also contains a long list of groups with whom the Confederate Action Party would work and with whom they would want to be associated. This list includes many branches of the League of Rights, the Anglo‐Saxon‐Keltic‐Society, the Citizens Electoral Council, which is the front for the LaRouche group in Australia, and so on.

The editor of Fight, as I said before, is Tony Pitt of Maryborough in Queensland. If this is the same Tony Pitt who has joined Pauline Hanson, then I wish them well; they deserve one another. However—and I am sorry, Senator O'Chee, I am going to have a shot at the coalition now—the Tony Pitt‐Pauline Hanson coalition is not the only interesting political connection to which I wish to draw attention. There were two disturbing reports received through AAP in the last couple of days, the first one dated 14 May 1997.

But let me first pay tribute to the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) before I do some other things. Despite Tim Fischer's courageous and early stand against Pauline Hanson, despite Peter Costello and other government ministers' rejection of her party over the last couple of weeks, despite John Howard's very belated criticisms of her policies, I find it sad to now discover that the local Liberal Party branch has said it will direct preferences to Pauline Hanson at the next election. If so, that would ensure her re‐election.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not their decision.
—I am glad to hear you say that, Senator Ellison, because it does encourage me. However, let me just read the AAP report because you may need to deal with this issue.
—It is not their decision to make.
—The report reads:

SPEECH.PARA: SYDNEY, May 14 AAP—The Liberal Party is planning to direct preferences to Pauline Hanson at the next federal election—a move likely to ensure that she is re‐elected to her Ipswich based seat, it was reported today.

Ms Hanson's One Nation Party will offer the Liberals an arrangement in which both parties put each other ahead of the ALP on how‐to‐vote tickets in the controversial Queensland MP's Oxley electorate, the Sydney Morning Herald said.
"We will not be involved in directing preferences to the Labor Party because we would have no chance of winning Oxley if we did," Oxley Liberal branch president Steve Wilson said.

Of course, that is rather a stupid reason for not directing preferences, because the Liberal Party has no chance of winning Oxley; it is really a competition between Pauline Hanson and the ALP, so their direction of preferences would ensure her election. But this is the disturbing part, Senator Ellison:
Local Liberals and Prime Minister John Howard had both indicated that they had found the offer acceptable, the paper said.
The Prime Minister yesterday again refused to back an opposition plan to defeat Ms Hanson at the next election by putting her last on how‐to‐vote cards.
Well I can assure you that the Democrats certainly will put her last.

I find that report disturbing. The other report from AAP, dated 13 May, which is also disturbing, is that at least some people believe that last night's budget does give some subtle support for Pauline Hanson's agenda. That AAP report says:
The Ethnic Communities Council of New South Wales (EEC) said the government had delivered a budget Pauline Hanson would be proud of.
That is disturbing, isn't it?

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't believe anything Angela Chan says.
—She is a good woman, Senator O'Chee. Anyway, I will tell you what she said. The report goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: Chairwoman Angela Chan said the budget would hit the people who were the most vulnerable in the country, including refugees, and would make the controversial Queensland independent MP and leader of the One Nation party happy.
"This budget panders to the extreme conservative elements of Australian society who have little regard for social justice and human rights," Ms Chan told AAP.
In coming weeks I hope to be able to report on other interesting Queensland political connections.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to attack Senator Woodley, because I found much of his speech particularly entertaining. But I must say that any suggestion that the coalition is giving succour to Ms Hanson is quite clearly misguided.
—Just preferences!
—No decision has been made on that.

—No decision has been made on that, Senator Conroy. I just want to make a couple of comments on Angela Chan's press release. Angela Chan is a delightful and charming woman. I enjoy meeting her every time we go to functions and appear together. I get on with her very well. I perfectly understand that Angela has her own political agenda, and that it is one which is not necessarily sympathetic to the coalition. It might be sympathetic to your side of politics, Senator Woodley, or to Senator Conroy's side of politics, but it is not sympathetic to ours. I think you would accept that, Stephen.

SPEECH.PARA: What we had in the press release that was cited by Senator Woodley was in fact a long traverse of things on which Ms Chan alleged the coalition was doing to give succour to Ms Hanson. In fact, many of these decisions were not included in this budget. Many of these decisions had been announced and already implemented in the previous budget and were not influenced in any way by anything in which the member for Oxley has been involved.

It is fair to say that the coalition is as concerned as anybody else is about some of the absurd statements that we have been receiving of late. Our concern is not because of my particular ethnic background or that of anyone else in this parliament. Good political decision making is predicated on access to the facts. Access to the facts is something with which we are hoping to assist the member for Oxley. At the moment, it does not seem that the offer of assistance has been taken up with the same fulsome good intent with which it was made. That is the concern that we have.

In relation to that, Senator Woodley is off the mark, just as he is off the mark in relation to the comments that he has made about the electoral process at the next election. Senator Woodley, we are two years away from the next election. Given the track record of the Democrats since the election, I would not be wanting—if I were you—to hasten the next election. You people on the other side have a long way to go before you would want to hasten the next federal election. I say that as somebody who has a very high personal regard for you, Senator; I enjoy having you around. But, on your current track record, there is not much reason that you should want to hasten the next election. Quite frankly, the electoral performance of the Democrats has been patchy, to say the least. The last time the electoral performance of the Democrats was as patchy as this, you changed your leader.

People have to seriously ask, `What do the Democrats stand for'? I know that Senator Woodley has been busy trying to portray himself as a friend of the bush. The facts are that all of the Democrat policies are anti‐bush, anti‐farmer and anti anybody who lives outside the capital cities. You do not have to go to the detail of the Democrat policies. Senator Kemp, I have taken your lead and have gone into them of late and I have found some of the Democrat policies to be particularly interesting.

BREAK.PARA: We know what the Democrats have done. In fact, I found a speech by Senator Woodley in which he said in the Senate that the Democrats strongly supported increasing fuel taxation. Of course, strongly supporting increased fuel taxation—as honourable senators on this side of the chamber would know—means only one thing: higher prices for everything that people buy in the bush. So people in the bush who read Senator Woodley's letters—and writing letters to the newspapers is now the only way in which Senator Woodley gets a run, because nobody takes his press releases seriously to heart—would have to take them all with a very large bag of salt.

I do not say that to reprimand you, Senator Woodley. I am saying it as someone who actually likes you very much. I am trying to be helpful, as Senator Parer says. I am suggesting that you might want to revise some of your policies, Senator Woodley, so that you may have a chance of being returned at the next election. At the moment, I would not want to encourage an early election, if I were you. That is all I will say on the matter, Madam President. I know that the time is hastening on to 2 o'clock, when there are other diversions in this chamber. I want to place on record again the interjection that was made by Senator Ellison that there has been no agreement from our Liberal colleagues in Queensland to give preferences to the member for Oxley. I would not expect that that matter would even be considered at this point in time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received, through the Governor‐General, from the Governor of Victoria, a facsimile copy of the certificate of the choice of the Houses of the Victorian Parliament of Senator Karen Margaret Synon to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Jim Short. I table the documents.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Senator Karen Margaret Synon made and subscribed the oath of allegiance.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —My question without notice is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Minister, did the Prime Minister pass on to you a letter from church leaders expressing grave concerns about the possible effects of further cuts to public housing? Is it not a fact that your budget cuts are a breach of coalition election policy? Did the church leaders describe any further cuts as indefensible and likely to force people into entrenched poverty and disadvantage?

QUESTION.PARA: Will you now acknowledge that your decision to cut $50 million a year in funding from the Commonwealth‐state housing agreement will cause public housing waiting lists to soar, will reduce the amount of public housing being built and will lead to a decline in the quality of existing public housing stock? Is it not a fact that you have betrayed low income Australians, condemning many Australians to private sector rental housing outside their means and low quality public housing for those lucky enough to be able to access it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I really should get out the hearts and violins after listening to that sad little exercise. The answer to the first part of your question, Senator Faulkner, is yes, the Prime Minister has drawn my attention to the letters from the church leaders. In fact, I have had ongoing and continuing contact with those selfsame church leaders who believe that the government's direction on reform is to be encouraged, supported and to be moved along as soon as we possibly can.

ANSWER.PARA: As you would be aware from your contact with the minister for housing in New South Wales, he comes out and attacks this government on the public record when it suits him while at the same time he is saying privately that he is in favour of reform to public housing and that a cut of the order of $50 million, together with certainty for the remaining years of this interim housing agreement, will be pretty okay by him. That is the view obviously expressed by the Victorian government: the minister for housing there has today put out a press release endorsing just that.

So I think that you are a bit misguided, Senator. We are all in favour of housing reform. The $50 million that you are talking about is coming out of a budget of about a billion dollars, and it is well within the ability of the states to find those efficiencies.

I draw to your attention, Madam President, that the overheads, you might say, for public housing in New South Wales are something of the order of 31 per cent. That includes some debt reduction; it includes, very seriously, the administration costs, and it is something which I think Mr Knowles for one might be concentrating on doing something about. In other words, an awful lot of the money that goes to New South Wales is not providing housing and could be providing housing if Mr Knowles was as committed in practice to producing public housing and to reforming low income housing for Australians.

I am committed to improving housing outcomes for Australians. The church leaders that you mentioned are also wanting to move in the same direction. I believe in fact that so are the housing ministers. But I would make it clear to you that the $50 million was the amount of the special purpose payments that were negotiated at the Premiers Conference. They are not a new sum. They are old news. The states found that a better alternative than other savings that could be made by them, and in a $1 billion budget it is pretty small beer. It is not going to, in fact, reduce the number of houses built for low income Australians. There are opportunities for Mr Knowles and the other housing ministers to do better than they are currently doing with the money they are currently getting from the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you talk about hearts and violins in my question. Is it not true that these church leaders warned the Prime Minister and your government of dire social consequences if the public housing budget was cut? Do you agree with the Anglican Archbishop of Sydney, the Catholic Archbishop of Sydney, the President of the Uniting Church of Australia and the Secretary of the New South Wales Ecumenical Council who said that? Do you agree with the Catholic Archbishop of Melbourne, the Anglican Archbishop of Melbourne, the Baptist Union of Victoria, the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of Australia, the Victorian Union of Progressive Judaism and the Islamic Council of Victoria who have supported them? Minister, the question is: why should we believe you and not them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very glad that the shadow minister can read. The answer to his question in fact is: they agree with me. If you had read the whole letter, and if you could read more than just their names, you would see they are endorsing the government's direction. I point out that over the 13 years of the Labor government the number of public houses built for low income Australians went down from something like 14,000 in a year to 5,000 in a year. Your record is crook. That is why they want reform in the public housing area. That is why they want us to move on. That is why we have a common direction. They do not believe that savings of that order are going to crucify public housing. They wrote that letter weeks ago, and this is not a cut in terms that they were concerned about.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Minister, the coalition government was elected on a platform to be economically responsible, to reduce debt, to increase savings, and to assist families and small businesses. Will you inform the Senate how last night's budget builds upon outstanding progress already made by the Howard government and how the budget will continue to restore confidence to the Australian economy which was so badly undermined after 13 years of Labor government?
—Certainly. I guess `economic responsibility' really describes this budget as well as any other expression. That is what this government is all about—being responsible.
—What about the unemployed? You did nothing for them.

—No more, Senator Cook, of the gimmicks of the past. You recall the rabbits out of the hat and the bringing home of the bacon and all that nonsense. Now you get sound, sensible economic management, and that is what this country is so badly in need of. I thought it was put well by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry when they said of this budget:

BREAK.PARA: This is a very good budget. Its most important characteristic is stability. No boats are rocked. No plans are unhinged. No problems are created. Meanwhile the budget will be returned to surplus in 1998‐99 as growth accelerates and unemployment begins to fall. This budget builds on the foundations of last year. This is a good budget which will go a long way towards restoring growth and lowering unemployment.

They got it absolutely right. That is what this budget is all about: stability, restoring confidence and creating a better Australia. At long last there is a government in power with a plan. Compare it with Labor's record. We inherited a $10.3 billion debt. In three years we will put the budget back into surplus—a magnificent achievement!

TALK.START.PARA: —No‐one believes you. No ideas and no jobs.

—Commonwealth debt under Labor increased by 115 per cent in the last four years of Labor government—you contributed to that, Senator Bolkus—from $45,000 million dollars to $97,000 million. That is the legacy of Labor: foreign debt over $180 billion; interest rates up to 17½ per cent—that is why Labor was thrown out; the highest unemployment rate since the Great Depression; and reduced living standards. That was the legacy of Labor. And what a stark contrast there now is with this government, a government that has tackled the fundamentals—tackled expenditure and reduced public expenditure so substantially. It has taken pressure off interest rates—three reductions in official interest rates since this government came to power. It has kept inflation down to record low levels; kept its promises on taxes—no new taxes as compared with Labor; and has given business now the opportunity to grow and to employ.

BREAK.PARA: That is the plan of this coalition government and this budget builds upon the plan that was established in the last budget. But in doing so we remember those were hurt most by Labor. We remember families that suffered so much under Labor. That is why we gave the family tax initiative—$1 billion benefiting two million Australian families. That is why we have given the private health insurance incentive, which is about to come into effect.
Senator Crowley interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Six hundred million dollars, Senator Crowley, being put back to help Australian families afford private health care. That is why we are giving the $3.9 billion savings rebate initiative in this budget—the first time in Australia's history that an Australian government has actually provided an incentive for the people of this country to save. We are doing something positive, building upon a base that will give a better future. That is why this budget is biased so much in favour of small business, because small business creates—it is the engine room of growth, the engine room of the jobs of the future. What is clear is that this is all part of a plan. We took the hardest decisions last year. We laid the foundation, built a sound sensible foundation. This is a responsible budget. Its hallmark is to provide stability and to give business a chance to employ, and for that this government ought to be applauded.
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, can you further inform the Senate as to community reaction to last night's budget?

—Madam President, community reaction, not surprisingly, was overwhelmingly supportive, as it was last year. Do you remember what they said last year? They said that it was tough and fair. What they have said this year is that they recognise that it is built upon the base of last year. It provides stability; it is a very responsible budget. I mention the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry. The Master Builders gave credit to the government; they said that it will keep pressure off interest rates, which is so vitally important. The housing industry supported it; the Real Estate Institute said that it would keep interest rates down; the Minerals Council—
—What did ACOSS say?

—What about the carers bodies, Senator Cook? Carers commended the new caring initiative—because the Liberal‐National coalition government will never forget those who were hurt most under Labor. We are for the battlers. The Council for the Ageing commended the budget; the Hotels Association, a very big employer, commended the budget; the Catholic welfare association commended the budget—and so I could go on. Overwhelmingly, this budget has been supported for its sound and sensible economic management. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister for the Status of Women who also represents the Minister for Family Services. I refer to the answer you provided to Senator West, in response to her question on notice at the estimates on September 24 last year, in which you indicated that the projected increase in the number of child‐care places in private and non-profit child‐care centres for the years 1997‐98 and 1998‐99 were 21,000 and 20,000 respectively. Does this not mean that your budget decision to restrict growth in these areas for each of the years to 7,000 places translates into a massive cut of 27,000 places, or 66 per cent? Why is it that in the last budget you undermined community child‐care centres and this time you are undermining private child‐care centres?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —This is interesting, is it not, coming from those who presided over a child‐care system which was out of control, wasteful, untargeted, not providing the services to the children who were in need of them—such as those needing outside school hours care, those in rural and remote areas, those with disabilities. It is amazing that—
—They were lining the pockets of unionists, basically.

—Lining the pockets of unionists, as Senator Alston helpfully contributes. It is amazing that at this stage now, after we have had a government in place for a year that is trying to undo the harm of the past, we get these nit-picking questions about what provision we are making for child care.

ANSWER.PARA: A few days ago we had the shadow minister responsible, Mrs Macklin, going around Tasmania saying that we had targeted 12 child‐care centres for closure—and what did it turn out to be? First of all, there were none targeted for closure at all. Secondly, two had closed in the last couple of years: one during the Keating government, and one during our government when a new child-care centre opened up and took the children from them. If that was not an indication of the lack of planning and foresight we inherited about the provision of child-care places where they are needed, I would be very surprised.

What we have done in this budget is a continuation of finding savings where they properly can be found. For instance, we had the taxpayer subsidising child care for non-work related purposes for over 20 hours a week. It is very important for families that parents at home have the respite opportunity that that child care offers. But it does not necessarily mean that it has to be 20‐odd hours a week. You were hypocritical enough to try 12 hours a week when you were in government, and you thought that was good enough.

We believe that there is a purpose in respite care for parents at home. But 20 hours a week, or about five four‐hour sessions, is perfectly okay—except where the family is in crisis and emergency situations, and then that can be extended. We have put money into playgroups, which for many families at home is a very important option. There has been a substantial increase in funding there: an increase of 60 per cent on the current funding—$1 million over three years. That is badly needed for those at home.

But on the one hand we have the Labor opposition saying that we are trying to send everybody home, and on the other hand we have them now obviously thinking that we are harming those at home. The point is that we need a child‐care system that is affordable; that is well planned; that provides for the needs, as I have said, of the child with special needs, with disabilities or who is in rural areas, et cetera. I know you do not like to hear that, but this is a rational planning of child care to meet the needs of Australian families. I think it is something that Australians will endorse—and all your nit-picking, Senator, will come to nothing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I do appreciate the benefit that can be obtained from an additional $1 million for playgroups, and I am sure that those playgroups are very much appreciated. But my question was how you explain the cut of 27,000 places in private centres around Australia and, more particularly, a total cut of $840 million over two budgets? What did you do to explain to the Prime Minister and the Treasurer the pain that will be inflicted on the women and families of Australia because of those two cuts over two years?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is obvious that the senator is a little deaf. She obviously does not understand what some of these reforms that we are putting into place will mean. The change to non-work related child care is estimated, for example, to free up about another 6,000 places for long‐day care. In addition, the government is providing for another 7,000 child-care places for this current year. So there are an extra 13,000 places for child care for this coming year, on top of the 31,000 extra child-care places that we provided in this financial year.

ANSWER.PARA: If anybody is trying to suggest that we do not have a commitment to extra child-care places, then they are utterly wrong. But the trouble is that you are coming to it from a perspective where you were just allowing it to rip out of control without planning. We are doing differently. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. My question relates to the Howard government's economically responsible budget, which has received such widespread praise in the community. Will the minister outline the means by which the important task of creating sustainable employment will be achieved through this budget?

BREAK.PARA: Senator Bolkus interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bolkus, you have been persistently interjecting during question time today.
—And will the minister outline the specific measures that the government is taking to address Labor's shameful legacy of high unemployment?

BREAK.PARA: Senator VANSTONE —I thank Senator Eggleston for the question. The answer is very simple. Firstly, the budget reduces the deficit, taking the pressure off interest rates. The people on the other side never understood the value of doing that, but it does encourage small business to create jobs. I quote Masters Builders Australia, who have indicated that the budget reduction strategy, which we have followed: . . . will
remove upward pressure on the deficit, on interest rates, benefiting businesses, including housing and construction, and further stimulating economic growth.

That is the key to getting more jobs. Secondly, there is the savings initiative, reducing our reliance on foreign debt which will in turn lay the basis for steady economic growth. Thirdly, there are the federation and heritage funds totalling $2 billion. The focus is on employment creation as we celebrate 100 years of federation. These three things together are the centrepiece of a budget that will generate more real jobs.

It is true that there is not money in there to splash around for fake training programs that people participate in for six months and then find at the end of the six months that there is not a real job there for them. This is the budget of a government that is prepared to make the tough decisions and prepared to get the economic settings right so that the flow through of real jobs will come from the private sector.

We are going to be spending about $1.6 billion this year on labour market assistance. We are spending about $17 million on work for the dole in 1997-98. We have a package for small business. We are reforming the way employment services are delivered. We have reformed the industrial relations system. The Prime Minister announced yesterday a $10 million package to assist the Hunter region in the wake of the BHP decision. We also have about $41.6 million over three years for the green corps.

I noted that early on in the answer senators opposite sought to criticise these decisions. But with a record like theirs they have no place and no credibility to be offering any comment at all. They should stand back and applaud a government that has had the guts and determination to take all of the hard decisions that they simply refused to make and that they meekly walked away from.

It was the party opposite under Keating that drove us head on into the recession we allegedly had to have. That recession was a disaster. It was a hit and run with no apologies. Labor has never apologised for doing what it did in terms of unemployment in Australia.
Senator Robert Ray interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It was your government, Senator Ray, that destroyed over 400,000 full‐time jobs. You were a cabinet member, Senator Ray, and you were a part of a government that said it was the recession we had to have. In that recession you destroyed 400,000 full‐time jobs. It was a disaster for Australia. This government attacks unemployment from a whole‐of‐government perspective rather than simply throwing money at the problem through unambiguously, inefficient and poorly targeted labour market programs.

BREAK.PARA: I note, Senator Eggleston, that my time is dwindling away, but there is definitely a lot more that I would like to tell you. It is very important that senators opposite understand the responsibility they have for the mess that they left Australia in before we were elected to government to clean it up. Let me start by pointing out that Labor's 11.2 per cent unemployment rate in December 1992, when they had had plenty of time to do whatever they had to do—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. In last night's budget the Treasurer announced the Howard new drugs tax and claimed it would save $560 million by forcing up PBS co‐payments for patients with blood pressure, high cholesterol, ulcers or depression. Do you recall another PBS measure from the 1996-97 budget in which your government planned to save more than $100 million by restricting access to so‐called high cost drugs? Is it not the case that both of these measures purport to make savings by reducing the government's expenditure on the same group of drugs—namely, ACE inhibitors? Could you explain to the Senate whether this apparent double counting means that this year's budget is already in error by $100 million or whether it means that last night's $560 million cut is in fact a cut of $660 million?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I see that the opposition is having a desperate time today trying to do something about a budget which Australians recognise was fair, appropriate and needed. It is a vitally important matter for the truth to be told to Australians. Through the years of your government we had all sorts of devices which kept the truth from Australians. I remember some years ago when I was the spokesman on health that former Senator Richardson had to be dragged kicking and screaming to do something to implement Labor policy on generic drugs. I know that his party was very unwilling to do the right thing but eventually he did.

ANSWER.PARA: In this budget the government has moved to take more action in the area of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme because it has been growing at a rate of knots and it is complete unsustainable for the taxpayer to manage. I think that a lot of safeguards have been put into the proposals which the minister has announced. Pensioners, unemployed people and low income earners are particularly advantaged in respect of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme subsidies through much lower co-payments and safety net thresholds. In fact, about 80 per cent of government outlays on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme is for concessional payments. So anybody listening to the broadcast of this parliament should be aware that, despite the puny efforts of the opposition to try to bring the budget measures into fear and loathing among voters, they will not success because the facts belie their claims.

BREAK.PARA: There are three measures which the federal government has decided upon to ensure the ongoing value of money for the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and to support quality cost effective prescribing of medicines. They are the introduction of the therapeutic group premiums for a limited number of groups, the establishment of a national prescriber service and the deletion of some less important medicines from the pharmaceutical benefits scheme.

It is important to ensure that the people who use the system, both patients and doctors, take cost into account when they are reaching treatment decisions. That is a cost decision between the doctor and the patient. We are not, in fact, moving to take action which will harm patients. The doctor with the patient will decide which drug will be used.

The introduction of therapeutic group price premiums maintains the rights of patients to freedom of choice, and it properly limits the taxpayers' liability to subsidise the choice only to the level of the lowest priced drug within the group. That is what currently happens when patients chose a proprietary brand medicine rather than its generic equivalent. Most patients are going to use the cheapest drug in the therapeutic group, and therapeutic group premiums are expected to settle around the $2 mark rather than the highly exaggerated figures being bandied about in the media. For example, the average brand premium is about $1.70.

The government will be seeking expert advice on situations where some individuals must stay on a more expensive alternative, and will consider exceptions in their cases so they do not have to pay more. However, such cases are expected to be very uncommon.

Together with the new national prescriber service for doctors, the government anticipates that this policy will lead to a greater emphasis on more rational and cost conscious prescribing. The corollary is that this should in turn lead to reduced costs to taxpayers and a reduction in the pressures to introduce more radical cost control measures. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I know that you and your government have promised to make Australians feel more relaxed and comfortable, but I am not sure how you do that when you put up the price of anti‐depressants and other drugs. Minister, you failed to answer the question regarding the double counting.

QUESTION.PARA: Minister, is it not a fact that under the Howard new drugs tax people will be forced to pay more for drugs, not because of whimsy on their part but because in a large number of cases the government's own advice is that the more expensive drugs are both more effective and actually safer? Do you support toying with people's health in this way and distributing the safest and most effective drugs on the basis of ability to pay and not on the basis of medical need?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —Except for the fact that I do not endorse people taking drugs, I would suggest to the senator that he himself might do with an anti‐depressant. He has a bit of a problem, I think. I really did enjoy the fact that you are saying that the more expensive drugs will be more effective and safer. If that is the case, Senator, why did your government introduce the generic prescriptions? Why did you have it as part of your platform? Why did you all endorse it and have it put into law? Come on—you cannot have it both ways, Senator. Do not be depressed; try another trade.

—My question is to the Assistant Treasurer. Your savings budget centrepiece has come in for a lot of informed criticism today. Was it not your election promise to give workers earning less than $35,000 a 25 per cent tax cut on the first $5,000 of interest and to match Labor's dollar for dollar subsidy for those workers' super contributions? And is it not true that last night you delivered a lot less in your untargeted 15 per cent rebate on the first $3,000 of savings? How many Australians earning below $35,000 a year have $60,000 in bank savings or can afford to put $3,000—nearly 10 per cent of their income, or even half of that—into superannuation? Where is the incentive there? Will not the vast bulk of the $3.7 billion flow to the people who can afford to save or who already have savings? Therefore, how does this actually increase national savings, which was the purpose of the measure?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator Kernot, for that question. In fact, much of the substance of the question goes to a dorothy dixer that I may be getting later. I say to the person who feels they might like to ask me a question later, `Do not bother'. The underlying assumption of your question, Senator Kernot, is dead wrong. This centrepiece, as you correctly call it—the savings initiative—has been widely welcomed.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me share a couple of quotes with you Senator Kernot, and with you Senator Sherry, the man who wanted to exempt high income earners from the 15 per cent surcharge.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a tax now, isn't it?

—You will wear that cross wherever you go, Senator Sherry, because you voted against it. Let me get back to the question asked by Senator Kernot. Let me share with you a couple of quotes. This is from Mark Patterson of the ACCI:

ANSWER.PARA: The government has turned the L‐A‐W taxed trust to good use in financing a series of savings measures. All forms of savings are encouraged equally. Greater savings will help finance the growth of investment and will repay this initial seed money many times over in the long term.
John Maroney from LISA had this to say:

LISA applauded the government's action to improve the retirement income system introducing greater freedom of choice, more realistic preservation requirements and pension take up deferral incentives—a move advocated by LISA members for the past decade. The integrity of the retirement income system is considerably bolstered by these measures with an added bonus of marked improvement in the national savings position in the long term.
That was John Maroney of LISA.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, John Maroney!
—Senator Kernot says, `Oh, John Maroney!' That's nice! The Master Builders Association said:

ANSWER.PARA: The government savings initiative is a welcome boost for raising national savings and improving the capacity for first home buyers to raise the deposit for the purchase of their home.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel so confident in their judgment.
—Another group that has welcomed this is the Investment Funds Association of Australia. They said:

ANSWER.PARA: The budget initiatives for investment and savings are closely aligned to the industry position. The initiative to introduce across-the-board incentives for all savings vehicles including managed investments will receive wholesale support across the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —That makes it right, does it?
—Order! There are too many interjections!
—The quotes go on and on. Terry McCrann—
—What about Ross Gittins?
—Well, he is often quoted over there against us. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: Peter Costello has decisively buried the Keating legacy in more ways than one with a very good budget.
Senator Sherry interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I keep on going? He goes on:

ANSWER.PARA: It consolidates the nation's finances around a smaller government dynamic—importantly not a slash and burn and bash the poor smaller government but one that seeks to make government work better delivering the same services more efficiently and cheaply.

The self-funded retirees have also made favourable comments. Senator Kernot, you might have one quote there which you might like to adduce but let me say this: the savings initiative has been widely welcomed. Who benefits from the savings initiative?

TALK.START.PARA: —You do—$450!
—Senator Sherry, let me repeat: the man who—(Time expired)
—Senator Sherry, you have been interjecting too frequently.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I find three quotes from the usual suspects entirely unconvincing. It is the old economic cheer squad on display. Let me just share one little quote with you—`a savings confidence trick from Costello the conjurer'. You left that one out, didn't you? To go to the heart of the mathematics of this, if you are reducing public savings by $2 billion and you are adding very, very little to private savings, because the people who have savings are not going to be saving more, then is it not quite appropriate for Ross Gittins to be able to say that your budget national savings centrepiece actually reduces national savings and is therefore a giant con? It reduces it; it does not add to it at all.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kernot, you quoted one article; I quoted five. I guess you will quote another one and I will quote another five. All I am saying to you, Senator Kernot, is that that is not the sentiment around the nation. The sentiment around the nation is that this is a very important initiative which will help bolster national savings which collapsed under the Labor Party.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Sherry interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sherry continues to call out. I have to remind this Senate and I have to remind the nation that Senator Sherry wanted to exempt high income earners from the 15 per cent surcharge on superannuation contributions. Senator Sherry, you've lost the right to enter this debate. That is what you have lost.

—My question is to the Minister for Social Security. Can you explain what has happened to your government's proposal for a single youth allowance and why there is no mention of it or provision for it in the budget? Earlier this year didn't you identify the Youth Allowance Bill as essential for passage in the autumn sittings? Didn't the Prime Minister single it out on 4 February as one of his priorities for this year? When is the Prime Minister going to step in and put an end to the endless turf battles between you and Senator Vanstone and your departments and bring forward a firm proposal on the youth allowance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very gratified to see that Senator Cook is at last taking an interest in social security matters. It is not before time, I guess. It is a pity he is not prepared take an interest in some of the important initiatives in social security in this budget such as the carers' package—
—You don't know. You haven't got a clue, have you, as usual?
—Order! Senator Faulkner, stop shouting across the chamber.
—Senator Faulkner seems to confuse loudness with impact and he certainly doesn't make much of that.
—Answer the question.

—I am happy to answer the question. I am just drawing attention to the fact that there are some very good things in the social security budget that the opposition is not prepared to ask questions about, like the pension bonus plan and like the carers' package, for example.
—Answer the question—the youth allowance!

—Madam President, if that bully would be quiet, I would let him hear what the answer is. I am very happy to talk about the youth allowance. We announced in the last budget that we wanted to move, in principle, to a youth allowance and that we would undergo substantial community consultations. They have been undertaken by both Senator Vanstone's department and mine and a lot of work has been going on to try to develop a common payment. It is a matter which is extremely complex.
—Complex, is it?

—It is extremely complex and we have been working very closely together. Despite the allegations that Senator Cook might like to suggest, we have in fact been working amicably and cooperatively to try to achieve good outcomes for the young people of Australia.
—Why has it taken you so long?
—You never managed to do it.
—No, you didn't even try. The welfare organisations want success in this area and we are working through with them some of the complexities which go to make up the system which we inherited from you.

BREAK.PARA: There is a disincentive in the system now which discourages young people from study ing and makes it financially more advantageous to take unemployment benefits. There is a difficulty for young people who become sick to also move from one payment to another effectively. We are doing this carefully and in a consultative manner both within government and outside government. It is an important matter which should not be rushed.

I will point out to you a much simpler matter in this budget—the introduction of the parenting payment, which has aligned the partnered parents with the sole parents, partly to reduce the stigma which sole parents get from the sole parents pension and partly to make it simpler for people when they are transferring from a partnered arrangement to a sole parent situation and perhaps back to a partnered arrangement again.

I am glad to say the Council for the Single Mother and Her Child, which is intimately concerned with this issue, has endorsed the direction the government is taking, as has the Catholic Social Welfare Commission. These things are to be achieved if we possibly can, because people who need help need to know what help is there and be able to access it. When the system is complicated, complex and contradictory, as it has been in the area of youth payments, we need to try to do something meaningful about it. We are working on that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, all of this was known at the time you designated this bill as urgent for passage in the autumn sittings. So nothing that you have told us is different from what you knew then. Given that, why shouldn't it now be rushed? Were you telling us the truth before when you designated it as urgent for passage or are you telling us the truth now when you say it should not be rushed? Can you also say, should you ever get around to developing this proposal, who will administer the proposal—DEETYA or DSS? Will it be means tested? Minister, will you please try to answer the question?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —Did I really hear correctly? Was the question: will it be means tested? Of course, it will be means tested. You presided over a means tested social security system; so do we. It goes to people who need help. That is the most stupid question I have heard in here for a long time. Of course, this is an important measure and we are not going to muck it up by rushing it along when there are still issues that need to be perfectly addressed.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Last year the Treasurer made much of the crackdown on tax avoidance by the very wealthy, estimated to be costing Australia $800 million. He further predicted that, in the coming financial year—that is 1997‐98—that crackdown would recoup some $100 million in revenue. However, it seems to have evaporated. What the budget does, instead of implementing that program and making that recoupment, is to cut Aboriginal students' assistance, overseas aid, services to immigrants and refugees, the SBS and so on.

QUESTION.PARA: I ask: is the change in affairs in response to some sort of inverse Robin Hood idea of taking from the poor and giving to the rich, or is it a reflection of the invisible hand of the Pauline Hanson front discriminating against those people in Australia who have a hard enough go of it as it is?Finally and specifically, what has happened to the crackdown on tax avoidance? (Time expired)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, that was a low question, even by your standards, I would have to say. I am just tempted to answer no and sit down because of the appalling assumptions which were included in that question. The government has outlined a wide range of measures to tackle issues such as aggressive tax avoidance minimisation—a large range of measures in the last budget and this budget, and if you had bothered to read the budget papers, they are outlined there for you. We get no help from the Labor Party on this.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me tell you, we get no help from the Labor Party; the chardonnay set have the ear of the Labor Party. We have outlined in this budget a—
—Tax rorters have got your ear!

—Senator Sherry, you are the fellow who opposed the crackdown on R&D syndicates and infrastructure bonds—we remember that, Sherry! Can I say that the assumptions in the question are quite wrong and I do not plan to respond further.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. To concentrate the minister's mind, I ask specifically what has happened to the $100 million that the Treasurer last year forecast would be recouped in the coming financial year, 1997‐98? Where is it? What is happening to the other $700 million that he estimated in last year's budget was being taken from the Australian people's revenue by the tax avoiders at the big end of town? Where is the money, and how much in the coming year is going to be recouped through the crackdown on tax avoiders?
—Order! Senator Kemp, please wait. There are too many senators on my left constantly interjecting.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —At least that question was worded in a more constructive fashion. The $800 million figure announced during the 1996 election campaign refers to the revenue potentially at risk from aggressive tax planning arrangements used by some high wealth people. We, of course, have always cautioned that this estimate is subject to uncertainties about wealth data, remedial measures, the utilisation of losses and behavioural losses by affected taxpayers. The figure should be seen as an order of magnitude estimate of the revenue potentially at risk, not the sum of gains from particular measures. In the 1996‐97 budget it was announced that early improvements in compliance are expected to generate revenue in the order of $100 million in 1997‐98 and that figure stands.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Attorney‐General and part of the answer Senator Brown wants might be in this question. Minister, last night's budget contained an annual $24.7 million cut to the Australian Federal Police compared to Labor's last budget. Is it not true that, on Monday night at the estimates committee hearing, the AFP's Commissioner Palmer advised that, for every $1 million cut to the AFP budget, approximately 20 officers would lose their jobs? Your cuts amount to a loss of up to 500 jobs in the Australian Federal Police.

QUESTION.PARA: Minister, why have you also cut the Director of Public Prosecutions' budget by some $14.6 million over the last four years? Won't this reduce the DPP's capacity to prosecute the ever decreasing number of criminals that the AFP will be able to catch? Why has your government so dramatically cut the budgets of the AFP and the DPP, sacrificing the safety and security of Australians and their families?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bolkus, I have a briefing from the Attorney-General on a significant number of the budget initiatives announced last night, but not one with respect to either the AFP or the DPP. So let me briefly indicate to you that I will get an answer for you from the Attorney on those matters.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not suspect for one minute that you would come in and misquote what Mr Palmer had to say the other night. But I say to you, Senator Bolkus, before you get carried away and assume that a cut in finance of any level assumes necessarily a fall in operational activity, look at the sorts of stupid claims that your party was prepared to make with higher education.
As I recall, according to your party and according to Senator Despoiler down there, higher education was going to fall apart.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh! Senator Sandstone!
—What has happened? With a little bit of a prune to the bush there has been new growth and the higher education sector is blooming.
—Cut it out. You have got to be joking. Not even you believe that.
