—There are more students and universities have got more money than ever before. You might not like it, Senator Carr, but they are the facts of the matter. Universities have got more under graduate government-funded students than ever before. They have had an increase in postgraduate fee paying students, providing them with an awfully large amount of money—nearly $200 million more than they had last year.
—They are bodgie figures and you know it!
—Order! Senator Carr!
—Yes, do try to control yourself. The sector is absolutely blooming.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator, I just ask you not to rush to a judgment. At least give the Attorney the courtesy of waiting to see his answer and give it proper consideration lest you put yourself in the position that Senator Stott Despoiler and Senator Carr have put themselves in with respect to higher education.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, on a point of order: is it proper for the minister to refer to an honourable senator by a name other than her proper name? I ask you to ask the minister to withdraw that statement in relation to Senator Stott Despoja.
—Madam President, I would be very happy to withdraw it. I do hear so many people call her Senator Despoiler that I must have slipped. Her name is Senator Stott Despoja.
—I am happy to withdraw a reference to Senator Sandstone, too.
—Thank you.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I remind the minister that just two days ago she was at the estimates committee where Australian Federal Police Commissioner Palmer gave evidence. Minister, wasn't it true that you were also there when the AFP gave evidence that they were in crisis and that they were facing a $7 million shortfall because of the cuts of your government in last year's budget? Minister, how can you begin to explain to the Australian public and Australian families that they will be adequately protected when your government's response to this crisis is to cut the AFP's funding even further? You were there. You must be aware of it. Try to answer this question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bolkus, I was at those estimates, just as you were. I did not take notes; I rely on the Hansard . I will go back and look at what Mr Palmer said. I will come back to you with whatever advice the Attorney cares to offer you.

ANSWER.PARA: I repeat my caution: do not rush to a judgment and let yourself look like an idiot such as Senator Stott Despoja and Senator Carr now look with their stupid comments on higher education. I am sure you are smart enough to wait until you get the answer and give it a good look and a bit of consideration before you run in and rush to a judgment and make yourself look at real dill.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. Minister, last night's budget provided a welcomed additional boost to regional Australia. Will the minister inform the Senate of the specific measures the coalition government is taking to support regional and rural Australia in its significant contribution to Australia's economic wellbeing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —This budget is very good news for regional Australia, which has been suffering mightily for 13 years prior to the last election. Indeed, they recognise more than anyone else in the community the crippling effects of debt and, therefore, they are delighted at the savings initiatives we have put in place. In addition to those initiatives there is a number of very positive expenditure items that have particular relevance to rural and regional Australia.
—Increasing quarantine charges—that will be welcome!

—Yes, they are grateful for that too, Senator Collins. But $1.6 million for roads, 90 per cent of which will in be regional areas, is again a very significant initiative. There will be something like 19,000 jobs created as a result of that one initiative.

ANSWER.PARA: There will be something of the order of $200 million spent on the Newcastle-Hunter region. Again that will create something of the order of 1,000 badly needed jobs. The $1 billion federation fund will create a number of jobs all around Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —A slush fund!

—No, you know what slush funds are all about. This is a measure designed to assist and to create jobs. If you want to get out there and knock it, do it at your peril. If you want to get out there and tell people that these projects are not worth having, get it on the record now—that is fine by us.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that regional Australia is crying out for the assistance that you deliberately refused to give them over that long period of government. That is understandable, of course, because 75 per cent of this lot are urban-based union officials with no idea about regional Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —What would you know?
—I should have thrown in a few primary and secondary school teachers for good measure, but the fact is—

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Robert Ray interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I made more money in the bush than you ever did, Senator Ray. I used to help the battlers in the western districts, I can assure you. Whenever there was a good bushfire, I was down there quick as a flash.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The level of noise is too high.

—I did not see too many of your lot down there. The only bloke who ever turned up was Barney Cooney because he officially had an office down there which was a front for the local union reps. That is about how far you mob got in the western districts.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that the regional telecommunications infrastructure fund, with another $250 million—he is not denying it; a plea of guilty—to ensure that regional Australia has high quality telecommunications services is also long overdue. Networking the nation is going to deliver that. There is a $20 million assistance to depressed regions program. That, again, will be of dramatic assistance in terms of budgetary support. Austudy improvements will, of course, help families in regional areas.

There are a number of major arts initiatives. Playing Australia and Visions are designed to assist companies to tour through regional areas. I know it is not of the slightest interest to you lot, but there are people in rural Australia—if you went out there—who have a few cultural bones in their body and very much appreciate those sorts of initiatives. Of course the centenary of federation fund will be of assistance as well. The Social Security telecentre initiative will also make a major difference.

We are doing all that we can for regional Australia. We have put our money where our mouth is. They know that you lot are not interested. They know why—because you have never been there. It is about time you disowned Paul Keating's Sydneycentric approach to life and realise that is why you got wiped out 15 months ago, because you have got no empathy, no understanding and no interest in rural Australia. We are the ones who will deliver, have delivered, and will continue to deliver.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator Herron. Minister, do you agree with the post‐budget statement issued by your chief Aboriginal adviser, ATSIC chairman Gatjil Djerrkura, that the government's failure to reverse the decision taken in last year's budget to place the CDEP program in a virtual no‐growth phase, eliminating the budgeted increase of 2,500 places put in train by the previous Labor government and providing for a miserable increase of 600 additional places, will seriously increase the rate of Aboriginal unemployment? Is it not a fact that officials informed a recent Senate estimates committee that this strategy will see Aboriginal unemployment increase from its current rate of 38 per cent to a catastrophic 43 per cent by the year 2000, when Australia will be hosting the Olympic Games?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The CDEP program is one of the cornerstones of the budget and we are allowing for an increase in CDEP over the next four years. I was pleased to announce in the budget that we have guaranteed ATSIC funding for four years—something that the Labor Party never did. They never guaranteed funding for ATSIC. ATSIC's budget now has been guaranteed for the next four years, Senator Collins. You never did that, because they had to go cap in hand every year to the Treasurer. We have guaranteed their funding for four years and confirmed that that will occur. There will be 600 extra jobs in the CDEP program. Senator Collins is up to his usual bluff and bluster, Madam President. It is the old thing: he is the possessor of knowledge. He ought to declare his interest in this regard in this portfolio, which he has in the past.
—What interest?
—Does he not have an interest?

—I raise a point of order, Madam President. I understand the imputation. Are you suggesting, Senator Herron, that I have got a personal financial interest in Aboriginal affairs questions? Either clarify that implication, Senator, or withdraw it.

—On the point of order, Madam President, I said he should declare his interest. He is very interested; I have said that before. There is no imputation; he has got a very thin skin when his veracity is questioned.
—You are an absolute sleaze.
—He has called me a sleaze, Madam President. I will put my reputation up against—
—You are.
—And Senator Faulkner has too. I'll accept those interjections, Madam President. I will accept them with pleasure.

—On a point of order, Madam President: as you well know, the expression `personal interest' and a demand for a senator to declare it have got an absolutely clear meaning inside this chamber. I was prepared to cop this once, but I will not cop it twice, Senator Herron. I either want Senator Herron to withdraw the imputation that I have got in some way a personal financial interest in the area of Aboriginal affairs or apologise.
—He didn't say that.
—He did say it, Senator Alston.
—On the point of order, I did not say the word `financial'. Check the Hansard . I did not say that.
—Withdraw the imputation.
—If Senator Collins asks me to withdraw—I respect Senator Collins—I am happy to withdraw. I have no difficulty with that.
—Senator Herron, Senator Collins has asked that you withdraw and I would ask you to do so and express yourself in a way that does not use those words.
—I am happy to withdraw, Madam President.

ANSWER.PARA: To get back to the substantive matter, my poor thin‐skinned friend and colleague over there—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is something I have never been accused of before.

—He is very thin‐skinned when I bring up this matter because we have quarantined the CDEP, which we did in the last year's budget; we have increased the numbers; we have said to ATSIC that if they can come forward with any new initiatives that occur in the next four years we are happy to look at them. We have increased a business incentive program which will increase employment. Senator Collins is not even listening to the answer—he does not want to hear it. The $120 million we are giving for the indigenous business incentive program over the next four years will increase employment. It is for individuals and communities to access and provide employment for those communities, and that is a very major part—a centrepiece—of the budget that we are putting forward. I hope Senator Collins takes notice of that.

BREAK.PARA: We do not want Aboriginal people to be on the dole for the rest of their lives. That is not the objective of the government. Our policy is self‐empowerment through economic independence so that they can get off the dole. The socialist Labor Party wanted to keep everybody on the dole for as long as they could. That is not what we are doing; we are giving incentive for Aboriginal people to get control of their own destinies so that they can increase employment through small business, which we are encouraging in the budget as a whole.

So I do not resile. It is Senator Collins, with his imputation in that question, who should be asked to withdraw—the imputation that Aboriginal people should be kept on the dole for the rest of their lives.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. In respect of your reference to this so-called new scheme for encouraging employment, is it not a fact, Minister, that the budget papers clearly indicate that this $120 million of allegedly new money is a fraud? The budget papers clearly indicate—do they not?—that only $40 million of this is new money from the government over four years and that $80 million of it has to come from ATSIC's already slashed budget.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Here we go again—the implication that he is the fount of all knowledge. There is $15 million new money in the budget.
—That is existing money!

—You did not refer to that, Senator Collins. You did not refer to the $15 million new money in the budget. There is $10 million which has come in. There is $20 million which has come from the CEIS program. That goes to $30 million each year, which will be $120 million over four years. There is another $20 million on top of that, Senator Collins, that you did not refer to. You did not even know that existed because you did not refer to it. You were pretending that you knew all about this but, in fact, you did not know about the other $20 million that you did not even mention.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I undertook to get some more information for Senator Allison, and I seek leave to have that answer from the Minister for Family Services, Mrs Moylan, incorporated in Hansard .

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—
QUESTION WITHOUT NOTICE
SENATOR ALLISON—13 MAY 1997
ACCOMMODATION: DISABLED

SENATOR ALLISON—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. Minister, the Council of Intellectual Disability told a New South Wales parliamentary committee yesterday that almost 1,000 young disabled people in New South Wales are forced to live in nursing homes with elderly residents. Minister, do you consider nursing homes to be appropriate permanent accommodation for young people with disabilities and mental illness? Minister, how many young disabled people are there throughout Australia in such accommodation? Why does the Aged Care Bill not mention people with disabilities or how they will be affected by the nursing home entry fees?

Senator Newman—I do not believe personally that they are ideal places for people with severe disabilities, if they are young, to spend years in. However, that has been a point of last shelter, you might say, for many years for people for whom there was no other appropriate accommodation. That means that under the previous government that was the situation too.

I know that Mrs Moylan has been having a lot of discussion in recent times with the states to see what we can do better for people in Australia with disabilities. I know that this government has been across portfolios focusing very much on improving the lot of people with disabilities and their carers. Beyond that, obviously, at this stage of the day, I am not able to say any more.

SENATOR ALLISON—I thank the minister for her response. However, we would like to know what the government is prepared to do, particularly in the case where we end up with a two tier system in nursing homes, as many people believe we will with your so‐called reform? What sort of accommodation and services can we expect for the young people?
Senator Newman—I am happy to take that on notice to the minister responsible, Madam President.
Answer
Accommodation for younger people with a disability is the responsibility of the States under the Commonwealth State Disability Agreement.

Nursing homes principally provide care for the frail aged. Younger people with a disability are only placed in aged persons nursing homes if suitable accommodation is unavailable and as a last resort. There were 882 younger people, aged less than 50 years of age, and 21 people under 20 years of age in aged persons nursing homes, nationally as at 31 December 1996.

Of course, I (Moylan) agree that this is not a desirable situation and believe that younger people with a disability should be in a setting which is more appropriate to their age and care needs. However, there may be a variety of reasons why, as a last resort, younger people with a disability seek entry to a nursing home. For example, it can sometimes be the only viable arrangement to enable a person to remain close to their family, particularly in a rural area.
Clearly, the residential aged care system should retain the flexibility to respond to these situations.
Younger people with a disability will remain eligible for entry to aged care facilities under the new arrangements where entry is the most appropriate response to their care needs.

Younger people with a disability currently pay 87.5 per cent of their pension in fees with the Commonwealth paying an additional amount to meet any shortfall. A parallel arrangement will be maintained under the hardship provisions of the new funding arrangements to ensure that younger people are not disadvantaged.

As most younger people with a disability will have only limited assets in their own right it is expected that they will qualify as concessional residents and not be required to pay an accommodation bond. As concessional residents, they will have access to a proportion of places reserved for concessional residents with providers paid a higher subsidy on their behalf.
It is expected that a large number of those who do not meet the concessional resident requirements will be in receipt of a compensation payment.

Younger people with a disability will have the same standard of accommodation and care services as other residents. This will be ensured through the new quality assurance arrangements which will apply to all facilities irrespective of the resident profile.
The introduction of new arrangements in residential aged care will not mean any fundamental change in access for younger people with a disability or reduction in the quality of their care.

The enrolment decline also means that Universities will have to hand back money for unfilled quotas. This will be yet another funding cut to Higher Education.

The enrolment decline also means that Universities will have to hand back money—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill, to a question without notice asked by Senator Ferguson today, relating to budget matters.

The alleged centrepiece of the budget that was handed down last night was the document relating to savings. If it had been an appropriate form of savings, it should have been the centrepiece of the budget, and I will refer to that perhaps in some detail a little later. But what was obviously missing as the centrepiece of the budget last night were initiatives designed to tackle unemployment, which is the most pressing economic and social condition that faces this country today.

Since this government was elected, even though it continues to assert and claim that Labor had a poor record with respect to unemployment, unemployment has been steadily increasing and it is now close to 8.75 per cent nationally. It is much more serious in a range of regional centres around Australia. None is worse than my own home state of Tasmania where unemployment is hovering around 11 per cent and would be much higher if it was not for the significant number of people leaving the state because they cannot get a job.

In the budget speech that Senator Hill so proudly acclaimed in question time today, what is significant, as I have said, is the notable absence of any positive approach with respect to unemployment. Prior to the budget being announced, Mr Costello, the Treasurer, and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) were trumpeting what would be centrepieces to encourage growth development and employment in rural and regional Australia.

In this rural and regional Australian section on pages 6 and 7, two initiatives are announced that are supposed to help improve employment prospects. One is a comprehensive rural policy package of $200 million over four years, but there is no additional money; it is to replace the apparently ineffective rural adjustment scheme. I think it will be news to the National Party how ineffective the rural adjustment scheme is in this country. But I think perhaps this has been dropped in as the sort of `save Tim Fischer's leadership' plan. It looks like it has just been lobbed in at the last minute.

There was some noticeable reference to quarantine. Indeed, as I have noted, quarantine is mentioned five times; unemployment gets three mentions in the budget. I think quarantine is very important but it is a sign of the priorities of this government that unemployment rates less of a focus and less of a mention than quarantine.

The irony of the quarantine initiative announced in this part of the budget—$76 million over four years; the Prime Minister said $75 million and Mr Costello says $78 million but it does say $76 million in this budget paper—to encourage rural and regional employment in Australia is that half the money is going to fund the redundancy payouts to the 700 meat inspectors that are to be made redundant over the next four years. And this is the real centrepiece for creating employment in the budget. I particularly wanted to draw this aspect to the Senate's attention.

BREAK.PARA: I have a few brief comments—and I am sure we will have opportunity to debate on this matter later on—with respect to savings choice and incentive. I think there are two fundamental problems with the approach announced by the Treasurer last night. Firstly, he has not delivered on his promise, the Liberal and National parties' promise—and indeed, it was not just a commitment they made; it was actually put in the forward estimates—on funding for the so‐called co‐government three per cent contribution. It was in the forward estimates. And what did we get last night? We got less than half that money devoted to a savings vehicle in the form of a rebate.

One of the critical problems is that that three per cent and the matching co‐contribution delivered into all working Australian savings accounts would have led to a significant increase in their retirement saving and their retirement income. But by delivering it in the way it has been done, only half the money is committed to this package. Goodness knows where the rest of the money has been allocated to; perhaps this federal initiative holds part of the answer. It is very regrettable because that will mean less retirement income. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eggleston, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to take note of the answer Senator Hill gave in terms of the general thrust of the budget. I am particularly impressed by the way the budget provides help and assistance to regional Australia. In particular, I am very excited about the impact of the federal fund and what that could mean for infrastructure in regional Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: In the north‐west of Western Australia, for example, it could mean that the Tanami Desert Road, which connects Alice Springs to the Kimberley, could be sealed as a result of the funding provided under the federal plan. The Tanami Desert Road, which has been there for many years, is becoming a major highway, even though it is not sealed, and is used by a high number of trucks carrying produce from the horticultural areas of the Kimberley and cattle from the Kimberley to the south‐eastern Australian markets.

BREAK.PARA: It is this kind of project which will be funded by the $1 billion federal fund announced in this budget. I am sure that people in the three northern regional development commissions in Western Australia and local government in the north of Western Australia will be beginning even today to prepare lists of infrastructure projects which this federal fund will provide finance for.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only for marginal seats.

—As it happens, they are all Labor seats in the Kimberley and Pilbara, and it shows what a generous approach we have to regional development in Australia that, unlike Kelly and the whiteboard, we will provide funds in areas where they are really needed.

BREAK.PARA: One of the other great initiatives in the budget is the $17.4 million boost to rural health services, which will improve health services and specialist medical training in rural areas and increase specialist services in rural areas. That will be a great boost to the health standards in country Australia.

In addition, there is $5 million for a pilot study to develop obstetric services in country areas of Australia, so that women who are having babies do not need to go to regional centres and to capital cities but can have their babies in the country as they used to and where most of them would still prefer to to this day.

Furthermore, the states and territories are going to be provided with $14 million over four years to buy the hepatitis B vaccine as part of a program to ensure that greater numbers of people in country Australia are vaccinated against hepatitis B. I think that is a very important initiative.

The other initiative that I would like to refer to is that there will be a $5.2 million boost to regional tourist development. Tourism is very important in many areas of regional Australia, and it is particularly important because it creates jobs and more particularly important to Aboriginal communities in providing jobs. Of course, if we can have Aborigines working in enterprises, it means that they will be generating their own income and will be less dependent on welfare. Once that happens, many of the problems which the Aboriginal community faces in Australia will end as a matter of natural course.

There are, of course, many other initiatives in the budget which are boosting regional Australia. The allocation of $1.6 billion to roads will create some 19,000 jobs around the country, and I am told that of these funds 90 per cent of the money spent on national highway programs will be spent in regional Australia. One of the other great centrepieces of the budget is the natural heritage trust fund which is the largest investment the Australian government has ever made in conservation and natural resource management. This will, of course, as these programs are developed, boost employment in regional Australia also. The regional telecommunications infrastructure fund will provide $250 million to raise regional communications standards, and that will provide a real boost to business and, more importantly, employment in regional Australia.

Finally, the introduction of the dedicated $20 million assistance program to depressed regions will mean that regions that are experiencing adjustment pressures, high levels of unemployment and/or are disadvantaged by their remoteness will benefit under that program. So, Madam Deputy President, one can see that this budget is very good for regional Australia. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the same matter. Senator Hill indicated that he thought this budget was good news. For all those persons who are actually unemployed at the moment, the last thing you would say is that this is a good news budget. You are not even predicting growth rates sufficient to bring down the level of unemployment. For young people, there is no good news in this budget as far as unemployment is concerned. For middle‐aged people who are actually trying to get a job, there is no good news in this budget in terms of trying to improve the employment situation.

SPEECH.PARA: What we have here today is the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Hill) reciting similar words to those uttered by the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) who, on 2 May, said that this budget would be good news for the education sector and that there would be no bad news. The proposition that I put is that there is, in fact, lots of bad news in this budget—lots of bad news for the universities, lots of bad news for the TAFE sector and lots of bad news for public education in our country.

As a result of this budget we have seen measures being taken by this government to reduce Commonwealth funding towards the higher education Commonwealth‐industry places scheme. Some 4,700 university places that have traditionally been funded will have funding taken away. What you will see is a very savage impact on regional universities in particular. I ask senators opposite who cry and bleat about their concern for regions in the country: what are you doing about the regional universities? What are you doing to defend public education in the regions and towns of this country? What are you doing to ensure that people in this society actually get a fair go when they in fact live in the country? What are you doing to protect young people in the regions of this country?

There is a similar pattern in vocational education with a further $72 million cut to the TAFE sector in particular. This is, of course, on top of the $183 million cutback announced last year for the TAFE sector. There are further cuts to the universities. A further one per cent cut has been announced in this budget for the year 2000. There is more bad news for education. There are further cuts to language training in this country with the phasing out of moneys to Language Australia—more bad news for people who are trying to learn a multitude of languages to further Australia's place within the region. There are further cuts right across the board in this budget. It is bad news for education.

Today the minister expressed concerns about how complicated the youth allowance is. There are no announcements in this budget with regard to the youth allowance, and this is despite the fact we were told in the last budget that there would be a major announcement and that, operating from 1 January 1998, there would be a new reform package in regard to the youth allowance—changes to income support payments which will affect some 630,000 young Australians. But we have seen nothing from this government. We were told by the minister on 20 August 1996 that there would be an announcement early in 1997 in terms of the fine detail of the youth allowance. But there is not a word of that in this budget.

Why is that so important? It is important because there is a great deal of concern in our community about the proposals by this government to introduce a new package of measures which may in fact see substantial cuts to assistance for young people. Substantial cuts will put at risk measures undertaken by this government to help young people who are currently on the youth training allowance or the jobsearch allowance and who currently enjoy support from Austudy or from Abstudy. In this budget we see an eight per cent cut in Abstudy. So there is a great deal of uncertainty.

This is a measure the government said—and hailed with great glory—that it was going to introduce to reflect the changing labour market, to provide flexibility and to provide simplification. Of course, we understand what this government means by simplification, flexibility and by taking into account changes in the labour market: it means more unemployment and less support for people who need it the most. This is a budget that actually gives to the wealthy and reinforces the tendency of this government to take away from the people who are most in need of support from the public sector.

This is a budget that is full of bad news, particularly in education; it is full of bad news for the young people of this country and it is full of bad news for the economy. It is full of bad news because it takes away opportunities for people to go to university, for people to go into the TAFE sector and for people to enjoy the benefits of a full education. It takes away real choice for people in this country. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously I have very little time, but I have to refute Senator Carr's comment that there is absolutely no good news in the budget. SPEECH.PARA: The budget is a clear indication that carers are a priority for this government. The Howard government has listened to carers. The Howard government is to be congratulated for initiatives that will bring some light to the lives of some of the nation's poorest people.

I have a letter here—and I will not say their name—from a constituent. They say that they have a 12‐year‐old daughter who has Rets syndrome who needs 24‐hour one‐on‐one care. She goes to a special school. But her general state of health is such that she has a lot of time home sick, and her mother has to look after her over a long period of time.

One of the things that we have introduced with this budget is an absolutely good news story. Up until now after 13 years of Labor, somebody with a child of under 16 years of age with a profound disability got no help whatsoever. The good news for those people is that they are now eligible for assistance at an increased level, which will enable them to care at home for a child who is disabled.

Senator Carr said that there was no good news in this budget. TALK.START.PARA: —They got $92 million worth.

PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The Petition of the undersigned shows that only one group have been excluded from eligibility for repatriation benefits in the Veterans Entitlements Act 1986 (the Act) where such group has performed honourable overseas `active service'. That group being members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 which were excluded under `Operational Service' at Section 6. (1)(e)(ii) of the Act.

The various claims made in Statements to the House and the Senate and the contents of correspondence from various Ministers to maintain the exclusion are answered as follows, the answers are from documents obtained under FIO and from public record:

(i) `They were never allotted for operational service', (contained in a letter from the Hon. Con Sciacca Minister for Defence Science and Personnel 1995). A letter from the Secretary Department of the Navy to Treasury dated 11 November 1955 stated `the date that the Navy were allotted for operational service was 1 July 1955'.

(ii) `Members of the RAN were only doing the duty for which they had enlisted', (October 1956 The Hon. Dr Cameron representing the Minister for Repatriation in the Senate). This applies to all Service personnel everywhere.

(iii) `They were in no danger', (November 1956 The Hon. Dr Cameron representing the Minister for Repatriation in the Senate). They shared the same danger as all other Australian Service personnel serving in Malaya at the time.

(iv) `They were not on Special Overseas Service', (in a letter from the office of The Hon. Bronwyn Bishop Minister for Defence Industry Science and Personnel to Mrs Williams of Adelaide dated October 1996). Requirement for Special Overseas Service was introduced in 1962 without retrospective conditions, therefore has no relevance to events of 1960.

(v) `They were not on Active Service', (in a letter from the office of The Hon. Bronwyn Bishop Minister for Defence Industry Science and Personnel dated October 1996). It is now, as it was then, that Service Personnel had to comply with one of three requirements for Active Service, this group complied with two, or twice as many as is needed. The one that they did not comply with was, `is in military occupation of a foreign country'.

Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate should remove the discriminatory exclusion in the Act, thereby giving the Australian sailors involved comparative recognition with the Army and RAAF personnel that served at the same time, and all other Australians who have served their Country on active service overseas.

PETITION.TITLE: Higher Education Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: that the Victoria University Library is closed for the first five weekends of semester and thereafter will only be open for four hours of a weekend;

PARA.TAB: increase funding for Higher Education so that vital services such as the Victoria University Library may remain open on the weekends'
bring back free education so that students aren't forced to pay for services they wont receive'
and acknowledge that access to a library on the weekends is essentially for students, especially part time and mature age students, in order that they may successfully complete their studies.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate an answer relating to the motion by Senator O'Brien which has just been agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

(1) The Commonwealth of Australian Gazette of 5 June 1952 included a declaration concerning `persons subject to military law'. The Gazette notice referred only to Army personnel and the purpose of the declaration was that Army's disciplinary code at the time, the Australian Military Regulations and Orders did not have extraterritorial application.

When outside Australia, Army personnel were subject to the Imperial Army Act. This Act had certain provisions that only applied when persons subject to the Act were on active service. Section 4 of the Defence Act 1903 defined `active service' for the purposes of the Army Act. Service with the Far East Strategic Reserve fell within the scope of `active service' for the purposes of discipline only in relation to those persons subject to `military law'. Naval personnel were not subject to `military law' in the sense used, but were subject to the Naval Discipline Act.

This Act, unlike the Australian Military Regulations and Orders, had extraterritorial jurisdiction, and was not reliant on any declaration such as those required for enforcing discipline in the Army. As no declarations were necessary, none were made for the Royal Australian Navy. The Commonwealth of Australia Gazette notice of 8 December 1960 declared that those persons subject to military law serving in Malaya would no longer be on active service.

Further confirmation that only Army personnel were declared to be on `active service' is included in a letter from the Chairman, Repatriation Commission to the Secretary of the Prime Minister's Department in response to a request dated 20 March 1953 to define properly the description of Australian operations in Malaya, which states inter alia:‐

`The Secretary, Attorney-General's Department, has brought his description into conformity with the Proclamation made under Section 4 of the Defence Act, declaring Australian Military Forces in Malay to be on active service. This declaration, which relates only to Army Forces, was made primarily for the purpose of the application of certain provisions of military law to Army personnel serving in Malaya.'
