TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Crowley proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

BREAK.PARA: This Government's savage cuts to child care, and the detrimental effects on women, whether working at home or in the paid workforce.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—
Before calling Senator Crowley, I understand that an agreement has been reached as to the speaking times of those participating in the debate and I would ask the clerks to set the clocks accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley, Sen Rosemary

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, how long do I have to speak?
—Nine minutes.

—In looking at this budget it is imperative that I do take the opportunity to be the first speaker on this matter of public importance. What is this matter of public importance? It is that the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, and his Treasurer, Mr Costello, who claim to be working for Australia and working for Australian families, have added in this budget $321 million more cuts to the $500 million cuts they made to child care last year—over $800 million out of child care in just two budgets. Yet they keep saying that they are a government and this is a budget that will help Australian families. It will not. The way the cuts in child care are affecting Australian families is already very savage.

SPEECH.PARA: These cuts come on top of the impact of the $500 million from last year's child‐care cuts that are already seeing the closure of at least 10 community based child‐care centres in Western Australia. Senator Newman acknowledged two closures in her own state today, one of which she says was before her government's time in office—not that I remember, Minister, that it was closed when I was minister. I will certainly chase that one up because I was never told of a child‐care centre closing in Tasmania.

Community based child‐care centres are closing thick and fast across the country because of your specific and deliberate deci sion to see them do so. You are seeing the closure of community based child‐care centres because you have removed the operational subsidies, in the face of a promise that you would not do so; you have seen the fees go up $20 to $40 a week per place, in the face of promises that you would not attack child care; and you have also seen the assessment for child‐care assistance fixed so that not only are the fees going up but assistance to families in most cases is going down.

So there are dramatic cuts in the number of child‐care places. In this budget you have added to that by restricting the forward estimates of child‐care places from about 21,000 to 7,000 in the next 12 months and similar figures in the out year beyond that. Why are you doing that? So as to shore up the private child‐care centres already in existence. That is what you are doing—the most counter to free market, which you people advocate, proposals ever.

In particular, what you are doing is restricting the access to child care for families of Australia. The costs have gone through the roof. The child‐care community based centres are closing and you say that you are trying to help families. In March, over 50,000 women withdrew from the work force in this country. That is directly correlated to the costs of child care for so many of those families. You are anti-family. You are anti-working mothers. You are anti-working families. It is now obvious what you are, if there was any doubt before—and I never thought there was.

This is the second tory budget following on a first tory budget that aids the rich and does not give a damn for the poor—savings that are going to benefit the top end of town. What working class family, I ask you, is going to be able to salt away $60,000 to enjoy the savings benefit? They cannot even pay for their child care. The savings benefit in this budget is not going to help the struggling families in Australia.

This is no longer even a thinly veiled attempt to encourage women to move back into the home. This is a completely blatant exercise in encouraging women back into the home. While I do commend some of the increased payments for carers, modest and all as they are, that is also just another recognition of the role you have for women—at home, looking after and doing all the caring for very, very few dollars.

This budget is the exercise in two‐facedness to take the cake. You are introducing a restriction of 20 hours child care for non‐work related child care. Let me quote Sally Loane in the Sydney Morning Herald. She said:

In taking child-care services back to its primary purpose, a labour market tool designed to enable women to re-enter the workforce, the Government has done what it prevented the previous Labor Government doing just three years ago. Then, when Labor tried to put a cap on the exploding outlays on recreational child care, the Liberal and the National Parties, aided by powerful private sector lobby groups, stopped the cuts. Then, the Coalition argued that the battler parents should get all the access to publicly-funded child care they wanted.

That is what Sally Loane said in the Sydney Morning Herald today—and very succinctly said, too. I will now turn to a few quotes which were made at the time of that debate. I thought Senator Minchin deserved a recollection; I note that he is in here to defend himself—keen anticipation.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, just on duty, Rosemary.

—You're not, Senator Minchin? Oh well, let me see whether I can provoke you. Certainly, Senator Troeth will be up, so I thought I would quote her, too. Senator Minchin said that the 12‐hour restriction was a matter of bureaucrats deciding what was work related. He does not understand the legislation. He didn't then; he doesn't now. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is a Dickensian view of what is work and what is not. It is a nonsensical approach to the lives of modern Australian women. It does not fit in with the way they live, how they work and how they operate in the community. That is why . . . this legislation is so wrong.
Well, Senator Minchin, I sincerely wonder what happened to you—struck in the back of the neck on the road to Damascus with this budget. You said:
I draw the Senate's attention to the correspondence . . . from the Australian Federation of Child Care Associations . . .

You went on to argue how the federation—and only they—wrote to you at the time, protesting desperately about what would happen to child‐care centres if you restricted non‐work related child care. It seemed to be entirely persuasive then, Senator Minchin; you went on and on, and then opposed us. No doubt Senator Troeth will get up and say, `Ah, but you said 12 hours; we're saying 20.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Exactly!

—Of course you are going to say that. It is as patent as the nose on your face. Because you don't want to know what I am going to quote you as having said at the time, of course you would say that. Gosh, talk about the Mandy Rice‐Davies defence! I seem to have lost your quote, Senator Troeth. I will find it in a minute.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I regard that remark as offensive and I would ask you to ask Senator Crowley to withdraw it.
—On a point of clarification: what is it that I have said that has offended the senator?
—Her particular reference to Mandy Rice‐Davies.

—On the point of order: the Mandy Rice‐Davies defence is, `Well, she would say that, wouldn't she?' or, `He would say that, wouldn't he?' I really cannot see what is offensive about that. It is absurd.

—Senator Mackay, I am not about to sit in judgment on what is offensive or not. Senator Troeth has taken offence at a comment of the nature she outlined. Senator Crowley, I would ask, on the basis of Senator Troeth's request, if you would not mind withdrawing that particular reference.

—I mind very much indeed. I will withdraw but only because Senator Troeth is so touchy that she cannot bear my anticipating exactly what she would say when she came in here, which is all it is. I was not in any way referring to you as a prostitute, Senator. The Mandy Rice‐Davies line is a very good metaphor for the sort of defence you have just put up. But, if you are so offended, let me then quote to you what you said and see if this is less offensive. On 20 September 1995 Senator Troeth said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . suddenly we have women who deserve child care and . . . women who do not deserve child care . . .
You talked about being fair and equitable to parents.
How can you say that when you are slamming the door of child care in the faces of people who need it, and people who are seeking it, on a basis that has so far been commercially available?

What about the position of centres which have taken a commercial decision to cater for the non‐working portion of the child‐care market? What happens to them? . . . What about centres in rural and remote areas?

Well, I sincerely hope, Senator, that you find the eight hours is going to mean all the difference in the world; that somehow choosing between 12 and 20 hours is going to make no distinction between women who deserve child care and women who do not deserve child care. The trouble is that you got it wrong then and you will not admit it. Now you are fixing that up—to put some restriction on the unfettered use of child care which was primarily work related but never solely. We always had a commitment to occasional care. Your budget is a disgrace. It is two‐faced; you do not care about the families. You have cut $800 million out of child care.

You have completely turned around your view on how to help families. You are, by and large, encouraging them to return home. You are closing community based child‐care centres. You are putting up the price of child care. You are making it hard for working women and working families, already struggling to meet their costs, to meet them any more. You are penalising single parents, women on unemployment benefits, people who are studying and training for the prospects of jobs—all of them are penalised by your cuts, your increased costs in child care and by your restriction on places. The community knows and they will judge you. (Time expired)

Senator NEWMAN (Tasmania—Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women) (4.20 p.m.)—Senator Crowley is talking about the government's so‐called savage cuts to child care and the detrimental effects on women, whether they are working at home or in the paid work force. The trouble is, Mr Acting Deputy President, you simply cannot rely on what Labor women tell you—whether they are the facts or not. I have a few quotes, which I will save the time of the Senate—

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: I take particular exception to the very unveiled implication of Senator Newman's words about Labor women being unreliable in what they are saying—that we are liars—and I ask her to withdraw that.

—Order! It might be helpful if we did not have the discussion going on across the chamber. I would hope that the speakers—and the interjectors from time to time—on both sides of the chamber would reserve their comments and be careful of them because, ultimately, it is the time of the debate that you are wasting. I did not hear Senator Newman make reference to the word `liar'. I understood Senator Newman to say `had trouble with the facts'.
—`Can't rely on any Labor women' is what she said.
—Yes, Senator Crowley, but I am not sure that that is unparliamentary. I might seek advice on whether or not it is unparliamentary.
—On the point of order—

—Senator Crowley, resume your seat. I do not believe that what Senator Newman said was unparliamentary, but I would remind Senator Newman to be careful of implications that she makes and to make them in such a way that they do not imply that people are indeed handling the truth with some degree of liberality.
—On the point of order—
—I am making a ruling, Senator Reynolds, with regard to the point of order that Senator Crowley raised.
—Yes, I respect your ruling, but I would like to make a further point.
—So you are rising on a further point of order?
—A further point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. You have ruled appropriately. I would like to ensure that we are talking about facts—and the facts are that $800 million is cut from child care.
—There is no point of order.

—The facts are that Senator Mackay only within the last hour said that I did not live in Tasmania and that I did not understand or care about Tasmania. The facts are that I have not only produced the Tasmania package, which has now been implemented in two budgets, but I have also been congratulated in the editorial recently of the Launceston Examiner for what this government has done for Tasmania through my efforts.

SPEECH.PARA: The facts are that Ms Macklin, the shadow spokesman, said that 12 centres in Tasmania have been targeted by this government to close. There are none targeted to close, so she is wrong again. The shadow minister also said that this government was sending women home and they were not to be in the work force. That was also repeated by Senator Reynolds the other night during the adjournment debate.

The trouble is that Labor women have trouble with figures as well as facts. The March figure which she was quoting includes all females, not just females with dependent children under the age of 15. In the single month of March, which was being quoted by Ms Macklin, with the exception of sole parents, employment of women with children actually rose. The major falls were for students and non-family groups. Let us make it clear that you cannot take the facts you are given by Labor women as gospel.

Let us get the facts straight on child care. Far from making savage cuts to child care, this government has increased and will continue to increase both the number of child-care places and expenditure on child care. Did you get that? We will continue to increase and have increased both the number of child-care places and expenditure on child care.

In the last year of the Keating government, $1.003 billion was outlaid on child care. Last year, the first year of the Howard government, we spent $1.102 billion—that is an increase of around $100 million or a 10 per cent increase on the Keating government's last year. This year spending on child care will be $1.146 billion. Over the next four years, this government will spend $4.8 billion. Child care will continue to grow at three per cent real growth in each of the next four years.

Since coming to office we have created over 31,222 new child-care places at a full year cost of around $86 million. Over the next four years, 83,000 additional places will be provided. Senator Crowley was keen to make allegations about numbers, but she is not prepared to listen to that. Forty-four thousand of those additional places will be in the private sector and 39,000 will be in community long day care, family day care and after school hours care.

In addition, we have also made available a further $31 million over four years to ensure that children with high levels of additional needs get appropriate access to child-care options. These are hardly the actions of a government which has made `savage cuts to child care', and they are the facts.

This government has demonstrated its commitment to child care with tangible policy initiatives aimed at fixing the aftermath of Labor's lack of coordinated planning of the child-care system. I draw the Senate's attention to a press release I have just received from the Australian Federation of Child Care Associations, which states:

We see this budget as a reasonable and carefully considered plan which reflects the listening that Government has done through the consultations that have taken place since the previous government budget in August 1996.

The control on supply of Private Childcare services capped at 7,000 new places for 1998 and 1999 is a welcome initiative that will slow growth and encourage more thoughtful and rational decisions regarding Private childcare provision. For existing services in areas of oversupply this measure has shown that the Government is concerned about the long-term viability of Private services.

Child care under Labor was characterised by oversupply in some areas and undersupply in others. As I said in question time, under Labor there was a proliferation of child‐care centres in many urban areas. The consequent underutilisation of places has created viability problems for a number of child-care centres. In other areas there are insufficient places. So Labor's unplanned and unchecked child-care system was unsustainable and threatened the entire child-care system.

In addition there have been excessive charging practices in place by a number of services. It is not the government's role to subsidise child-care centres whose charging practices are in some cases excessive or inefficient. It is not the government's role to expend endless amounts of money on a child-care system that is expanding out of control and which has lacked any coordinated planning or control and, in many cases, does not meet the needs of families, especially in rural and remote Australia. I understand that Senator Mackay was talking about that earlier. If I have time, I will go through some details about what we are doing for rural and regional Australia. It is very substantial.

We are determined to establish a high quality child-care system that remains flexible, affordable and accessible to families to enable parents to participate in the work force if that is their choice and at the same time provide a reasonable amount of subsidised child care for those not in the paid work force.

Let me make it clear that, unlike our predecessors, we have consulted widely with parents, child-care providers—as you heard from the quote that I gave just before—and other interested parties. We have developed a national planning framework for child care which is based on these consultations and research. We have listened and we have put in place what needs to be done. It is a plan which is going to provide a sound foundation for the development of an affordable and sustainable child-care system. We will work with local and state governments in planning for the future development of a sustainable child-care system and an appropriate balance of facilities. This child-care package will give Australian families fair and equitable access to subsidised child care and it will provide more even distribution of child-care places, especially in rural and remote areas.

It is important to stress that in the budget announced yesterday there have been no changes to eligibility for child-care assistance or the child-care cash rebate. We have preserved every benefit for working families. It is also important to stress that 85 per cent of the savings come from managing future growth. That seems to be the big problem that those on the other side have to come to grips with. It is savings coming from managing the future growth—not stopping it, but managing it.

Eligibility for child‐care assistance for new private long day care services will be limited to 7,000 places in 1998 and 1999 consistent with the number of places required to meet the expected growth in labour force participation of parents with young children. In addition, the government will provide 2½ thousand new family day care places in recognition of the fact that families are seeking greater access to family day care which provides flexible hours, care for family groupings, and quality care in a home setting. As I mentioned earlier, in total, around 83,000 new child‐care places are expected to be established over the next four years, allowing access for an additional 136,000 children. Did you hear that, Senator?

Over the next four years the Commonwealth government will increase the number of outside school hour care places by 28,500 to meet the unmet demand for school‐age care which was ignored by the previous government. Over four years an additional $11 million will be injected into outside school hours care. This will improve the equity and the affordability of care for school age children by making many low and middle income families eligible for a higher rate of child‐care assistance from January next year. This new child‐care assistance for school‐age children will benefit an estimated 70,000 families. Again, that does not sound like savage cuts to child care to me and, in your heart of hearts, you must understand that, Senator.

Let me just look at the 20‐hour per week limit on access to child‐care assistance to families using care for non‐work related reasons. I well recognise the need, as I said in question time, and the value of non‐work related child care to enable children to experience a range of social and developmental opportunities and to enable parents to participate in community or voluntary activities and have a break for themselves. Child‐care centres play an important role in early childhood development and preschool education, but the 20‐hour limit recognises that on average families using care for non‐work related reasons use around 14 hours of care a week. There will be exemptions to the limit available to assist families in crisis and children at risk of abuse or neglect.

Let me conclude by making some of the points about rural and regional Australia. Funding totalling $9.5 million over four years has been provided to support community centres—still to be established under the child‐care strategy—to target family needs which are not being met by private operators, particularly in rural and regional Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to begin by putting on the record the fact that the Democrats have been critical of the way that this government slashed funding for child care in last year's budget. The government should be condemned for the cuts made in the 1996 budget. Many of these changes were just awful. Some have not even started yet. For example, the effects of abolishing operational subsidies for community child‐care centres does not even begin to be felt until after this measure comes into effect on 1 July this year.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats fought very hard to prevent many of the changes which were announced in last year's budget from coming into effect. We voted against—after a hiccup, I agree—the abolition of operational subsidies for community based long day care centres; the capping of child‐care assistance at 50 hours per week per child; the payment of child‐care assistance directly to parents; the abolition of the additional income allowed dependent children when assessing a family's eligibility for child‐care assistance; and the freezing of child‐care assistance and child‐care cash rebate from indexation for two years. But we should not let last year's cuts be confused with this year's budget which, while it makes savings, is not nearly so savage as the 1996 attack on families.

I am surprised that former minister Senator Crowley is complaining about the proposed 20‐hour limit, because she championed for months and months—although I believe that personally she did not support it—a 12‐hour limit. Not only that, it was a 12‐hour limit in isolation from other needed actions like national planning. The Democrats give the new minister credit for listening to our concerns, and the concerns of child‐care organisations, and coming up with what seems to be an acknowledgment of the need for planning. We certainly want to see the details of that before we sign off. But let us give the minister a tick for that. We did say right through the 12‐hour debate that there was a place for limits on non‐work related care, but not 12 hours and not in isolation from a national plan. So we will not sign off on the 20‐hour figure just yet—we have more consultation to do—but it is much more the ballpark figure than Labor's proposal.

The Democrats are concerned, however, about other effects, particularly the effect of withdrawing operational subsidies from school‐age care services. It is difficult to read the budget papers in regard to this, but I must say that that would be a disaster, so let us see what the proposal really means. Also, we will monitor the capping of places to 7,000 in 1998 and 1999. It is a move that I believe will be supported by some of the providers of child‐care services. It is a move towards planning for this industry and that is certainly needed, even though some people think that that word `planning' is a terrible word. The previous government turned their back on it and this government always harps on the need for the market to decide.

But at last there is an acknowledgment that we cannot allow wholesale unplanned expan sion of child‐care places in any suburb that a developer picks. All of us know stories about how in some parts of the country there is almost a child‐care centre on every corner. Market forces do come into play, sometimes tragically so, especially if there are too many places. Some or perhaps every child‐care centre is affected. Some, of course, go broke.

We will monitor how the 7,000 places are distributed and watch carefully to ensure that no rural or regional area suffers from this decision, because the imbalance affects rural and regional areas in the other direction where there are not enough places available. We will also be seeking further clarification on what the effects will be of paying child-care assistance to families in arrears from 1 January 1999. I would be particularly concerned about the problem for child-care providers and the effect on their ability to provide for adequate staff. I suspect that this will not be a progressive move. However, we are prepared to look at it further.

The Democrats want it to be perfectly clear today that a lot of damage was done to child care as a result of cuts which were made in last year's budget. There have been closures of child-care centres around Australia. Surely that is sufficient evidence. Finally, given that the government has predicted a massive budget surplus, I call on the government to give the money taken from Australian families back to those families in order to undo some of the damage which was caused by child-care cuts contained in last year's budget.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion moved by Senator Crowley alleges savage cuts to child care by this government. I think Senator Newman has adequately put to the Senate the increases which have been introduced by this government. We had a figure of 10 per cent increased expenditure mentioned; that is, $1 billion under the prior government in its last year as opposed to $1.146 billion proposed under this expenditure. As well, under these proposals we also have a provision for ex penditure of $1 million per annum on increasing services to play groups.

SPEECH.PARA: The government stated in the budget released last night that it is committed to assisting low and middle income Australia to obtain affordable child care. That in turn will enable parents to participate in the work force should they choose to do so. This commitment recognises the need for some women to participate in the work force. However, I would suggest that the part of the proposal put by Senator Crowley which refers to the detrimental effects on women is somewhat narrow-minded, because what Senator Crowley fails to recognise is that there are some 33,400 men who are single parents with children under the age of 12. It is estimated that 48 per cent of those men are using child care. So when we talk about it being detrimental to women, let us talk about those single parents who are men as well.

I might just add that this opposition has a hide when it talks about the government's lack of commitment to women. We thrashed the opposition in relation to representation of females in the House of Representatives, in this chamber and also on various Commonwealth bodies.

The legacy that Labor left us in relation to child care was abysmal. In fact, we have heard mentioned today the proliferation of child-care services in urban Australia. In fact, there were some 20,000 places added each year under the ad hoc growth approach by the previous government. Senator Crowley mentioned the 10 services that had closed in Western Australia. Of course you are going to get closures where you have an oversupply of a service in a particular area.

The previous government did not plan any strategic growth in child-care services, so what you had was the proliferation of child-care services in areas where there was an oversupply. Of course they are going to end up being under‐utilised and in turn you will have closures. Senator Crowley failed to address that when she raised this point of the closures in Western Australia. The reality is that under the previous government the growth in child care was unplanned and unchecked. Under Labor, child care was careering out of control, and the taxpayer was footing the bill.

Before I go on to highlight the benefits of the government's child-care plan for both men and women, I would like to remind the opposition of its poor record in this area. Senator Crowley would remember that under the former Labor government there was this increase of child-care services in urban areas. Of course, the prior government's poor management of this led to an under-utilisation of places.

In contrast, the current government is committed to ensuring that child care can be available for all and that it will be available for all Australians in various geographic areas. The Treasurer (Mr Costello) said last night that child care is an area of unsustainable growth in government spending. In fact, it is one of the fastest growing areas of government expenditure. We see this when we look at an article in the Canberra Times of today's date which was written by Verona Burgess. She states:
But the Howard Government has put the brakes on the mushrooming of subsidised places in private long day-care centres.
Even the Canberra Times was recognising that this area was growing out of control.

Mr Costello explained last night in the government's budget that these measures would guarantee growth based on targeting areas with greatest needs. These measures represent an equity issue. More parents in lower economic areas will receive assistance, and more places will be located in areas where access is extremely difficult.

From 1 January next year, a 20-hour per week limit on access to child-care assistance will be introduced for each child in care for non-work related purposes. The limit will apply to all day‐long care and school aged services. This will free around 6,000 places for work related care. Without these measures, the child-care assistance scheme would not remain viable in the long term.

In the West Australian of today's date, Mark Mallabone did a survey of some aver age Australian battlers. He referred to Mr and Mrs Nortje in Ballajura, which is a marginal seat and represents middle Australia. Mrs Nortje said:
. . . the move to place restrictions on non-working mothers using child-care was a positive one.
"Day-care should be a priority for working mums and I can't see anything wrong with putting a 20-hour limit on other people who use it . . .

If that does not come from the area where it is most intended to help people, I do not know what is. The opposition fails to realise what middle Australia needs. It failed to realise that last year when it went to the election, and that is why it lost so horribly.

This government has announced reforms to child care, which will see strategic and well‐planned growth in that sector. This budget has also mentioned improvements in outside school home care services which, as Senator Newman mentioned, would benefit some 70,000 families. In addition, the government believes that families should have available to them a service, no matter where they live. I note that the government has also mentioned that there will be an exemption for families in crisis in relation to the 20‐hour cap.

From 1 October this year the government will work with states and local governments as well as the private sector, as Senator Newman mentioned. The government will work to establish new services in areas of greatest need and the private sector growth will be contained to 7,000 new places for each of the years 1998 and 1999. The government will increase the supply of family day care by 2,500 places at a cost of $11 million over the next four years. These additional places will alleviate pressures in rural and remote areas where there is a great need for child care. In particular, I refer to my home state of Western Australia. An estimated 3,200 additional families will benefit from this measure.

These measures build on reforms which were outlaid in last year's budget. They provide a sound foundation for the development of an affordable and sustainable child‐care system, unlike that offered by the prior government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise also to speak on this matter of public importance. Before I start my contribution I would like to refute a number of the claims made by Senator Newman in her address on this matter, particularly her claim that her government is actually increasing funding for child care.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Newman can quite clearly state that, on the books, every year there is an increase in the columns. But what Senator Newman does not inform this chamber and the Australian public is that those increases do not reflect the anticipated growth in child care. So what we are seeing in real terms is a decline in funding for child-care services in Australia. The $841 million cut over the last two budgets represents the absolute magnitude of the gap between the growth in child-care services the need for support of Australian families, and what this government is prepared to offer them.

Another point I would like to make is that Senator Newman brags that there are no changes to eligibility in this year's budget. Well of course there are not because they were all made last year. All of the changes to eligibility were put in last year, whether it was with respect to child‐care assistance and having two or more children in care or whether it was with respect to the rebate. So, yes, Senator, you can stand up and say, `Isn't this wonderful. No changes to eligibility this year,' but it is because you put those things in place last year.

I am also very interested and quite relieved in some way to hear the senator bragging about savings coming from managing future growth. I think that is an acknowledgment of exactly what this government is doing. They say `managing future growth'. That is a euphemism for restricting future growth, and I will return to that point later.

As a general comment, it is very interesting to look at a snapshot of what Labor did with child care up to the election last year. Child‐care places grew from 46,000 to 300,000 places nationally during the time Labor was in government. That was not just because Labor thought child care was a great idea—I think it is a great idea as a working parent— but it was in response to a need of families in Australia. It was not something that Labor just drove because we thought it was a good idea; it was something in response to the needs of working families.

But this government does not operate like that. It does not look at Australian society and see what the needs of Australians are. It has a social model in its head. Its social model for the working family is that it likes to see one of those parents—be it the man or the woman, Senator Ellison—in the home looking after young children. What we have now is a government that is prepared to impose its social ideal on Australian society instead of responding to the needs, the demographics and the changes in the working patterns of Australian families who, for one reason or another, choose to both work or, in the case of single parent families, have to work to survive.

The standard that we set as a party did recognise those changes in employment. Unlike the coalition, we know that the average Australian is already doing it really hard as a result of the child-care cuts last year. Growth in child care over the last six years has been 18 per cent. This growth has not been recognised by this government in its effort to impose its social ideal on Australian working families with children in care.

The social outcomes of Labor's efforts in responding to community needs were not only the higher participation in the work force but also a service that provided what parents were looking for—that was, guaranteed quality and an affordable and accessible service. I find it so amusing, Senator Newman, that, when we were talking last year about the $500 million budget cuts to child care when you were cutting operational subsidies for community based child care, you stood up and argued and said, `Let the market decide,' or words to that effect.

Your line last year, Senator Newman, and the line of this government was: the market must decide where the centres are needed. And this year we see a complete turnaround on that position. Suddenly it is no longer: let the market decide on where the private centres can be built and the services that they provide. Suddenly, this year, the government has changed its tune completely and has said that unsustainable growth in child subsidisation is something that must be controlled. So instead of letting the market decide, this government has switched tracks completely and said, `We will impose restrictions on the growth of private centres. We will control where they are built. We will control the numbers of places they provide to the community with subsidisation.'

Here we have a free market government turning the tables when it suits them to impose a social model that they choose and which they seek to put on Australian working families. That is a model that we all know dates back to the 1950s. There is nothing this government could say or do to move away from that position because the hypocrisy of their policy approach on child care has now been exposed.

I would also like to take the opportunity to say that in a mere 14 months the landscape for child care has changed completely and dramatically. To refresh the memories of my senatorial colleagues, let us have a look at what happened last year. Community long day care operational subsidies were cut, forcing parents in only a matter of weeks to be paying $20 or so a week more for each child in care.

The rebate and child‐care assistance maximum limit froze for two years, so again it is not recognising any growth and squeezing a few extra dollars out of the child care budget. Child‐care assistance was restricted to 50 hours per week and the child‐care cash rebate is now means tested—that came in earlier this year. There was also that little bit on the side that offered tax rebates to families with a child under five staying at home with a parent.

So the social outcomes that we have seen over the last 14 months or so as a result of last year's budget are that women—or one of the working parents—have been forced out of work and care has become a commodity. No longer is care an essential service that needs to be provided in response to a community demand. Care is now a commodity under this government—a commodity to be controlled, a commodity to be manipulated and to be used to allow this government to make Australian families conform to their retrograde social ideals. I do not believe that is acceptable in any way, shape or form.

As to the sweeteners attached in this year's budget, we have heard about the out of school hours care—although the operational subsidy has been cut to that—play group funding and so forth. Sure, they are all good, but it is all about restricting choice in some areas and then making it look good, putting a bit of sugar on top, in the other areas.
The other thing about this year's budget—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth, Sen Judith

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to take part in this debate which, in the wording of Senator Crowley, simply reinforces the stereotypes that the Labor Party would like to present as to their view of who should be handling the child‐care debate. It is significant that Senator Crowley talked about the detrimental effects only with regard to women. I am very glad that Senator Ellison saw fit to raise the point that the child‐care debate also has some effect on men.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor view of the world was only perpetuated in the adjournment speech of Senator Reynolds the other night when she asked time after time what the coalition women who came into the last parliament were doing about child care. There was not one mention of the extended role which many men look to play and choose to play in child care for their children. I would suggest that they remove the blinkers somewhat when they are talking on this debate.

Senator Woodley, I can actually answer one of the queries you raised in regard to last year's budget. One of the changes in last year's budget which removed operational subsidies from community care centres simply righted the balance and put the outlook of private centres and community centres on an even playing field. Operational subsidies have never been available to private child‐care centres, and the removal of the operational subsidies simply placed them on a an equal footing with the private day care centres.

I would be very interested to know of the evidence for child‐care centres closing, because it has been passed on to me that since July of last year in Western Australia only four centres have closed, mainly due to underutilisation. As a contrast to that, in Balcatta, which, I understand, is a Labor area of Perth, seven private sector centres have opened within walking distance of the community centre. And if, Senator Lundy, we are talking about child care as `an essential service'—and I am quoting your words here—`to be provided according to community demand'—
Senator Lundy interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, those were the words you used. What better example do you have of that than one centre closing because of underutilisation and seven private sector centres opening because of the demand that parents have. That is the way the market operates in a real business sense.

SPEECH.PARA: If these changes that have been brought about as a result of last night's budget are so unfair and detrimental to parents, not just women, how then do we account for the words today from the Age in Melbourne—which is not a paper that is noted for its conservative views—where they interviewed a woman in Melbourne who is a mother at home in East Bentleigh with a two‐year‐old and a one‐year‐old? Her husband, Ross, works full time in a factory, and she was interviewed before and after the budget. After the budget, Mrs Walkear thought that changes to child care were fair.

To illustrate that, statistics show that the average amount of child care used in non‐working care is 14 hours per week. Certainly, we moved against the mean and inadequate 12‐hour limit proposed by Labor when they were in government, because we believed it was inadequate. By contrast, the 20 hours which we are proposing under our budget measures give a non‐working mother or father the equivalent of five days for four hours a day. That is a generous allowance, and Labor are being extremely hypocritical on this in view of the fact that they tried to cut it down to much less. On that basis, we would expect that they would be supporting our government's position on child‐care hours.

Those senators who were in government for the Labor Party during the previous time of government would know that I asked many questions in estimates on the amount of planning that was being done by the Labor government to try to mould child‐care centres into some form of acceptable pattern. They know as well as I do that there was untrammelled expansion in some areas and relative underdevelopment in others. No amount of questioning by me and other coalition senators could elicit the fact that there was any planning going into this at all. By contrast to this, we would like to really use some measures to expand areas where child care has not been very prevalent, particularly in rural and regional Australia, which is an area dear to my heart.

Certainly, we are looking to expand outside school hours care and we will have pilot and research projects going into rural and regional areas. We are providing ongoing funding of $15.7 million over four years to make services available in disadvantaged areas where there are no alternative funded services. Not only that; if Labor senators had taken the trouble to read the fine print of our budget documents, they would know that in areas where there are no other services the 20‐hour limit will not apply and parents will be able to access that for non‐work related care to use as they would any other sort of care.

Every benefit—as both Senator Newman and Senator Ellison remarked—that existed up until last night has been preserved for working parents and for working families. Senator Crowley cannot have it both ways. We cannot be detrimental to working families and at the same time be forcing parents back into their ideal of a very conservative home. What we are trying to do is establish a system of choice: if you work, you should have accessible, equitable and funded child care which is available for you to use as a working parent. That was the primary objective of child‐care services as they were set up by the Labor government.

BREAK.PARA: If you do not work, you should also have access to care if you cannot find it within your extended family or in flexible working hours, which we hope will be the norm rather than the exception under our new industrial relations laws.

The changes which we have made to child care will provide a better‐organised service which is more accessible to more parents and will certainly not have detrimental effects on parents and families, other than those prescribed by the Labor Party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to rise on this matter of importance, the issue of child care. It is an extraordinarily complex issue and I must confess that I do not think that every proposition that is put forward is a negative. But I think that, on balance, the changes that have been imposed by this budget on child care are negative for parents who do rely on child care.

SPEECH.PARA: When I first had my child and was seeking child care, I found that to guarantee a place for your child in a private child‐care centre you had to put your child on the waiting list 12 months before it was going to be born. I found this proposition extraordinarily difficult, but maybe that was possible for those who have perfect timing in terms of conception. Certainly it was extraordinarily difficult to get into a child‐care centre. Not only that; when I first re‐entered the work force after the birth of my child, I found that I had only $40 left in my pocket after payment of child care.

I am very proud to say that over the period of time that Labor was in power, we introduced 400,000 child‐care places, child‐care assistance and the child‐care rebate, which really gave working parents direct access to child care at a realistic cost. I think that was something that was applauded by the community at large.

Last year, it was a slash and burn budget. There were major cuts in child‐care assistance, in operational subsidies and in the rebate. I do not wish to waste my time and go over them again, but I think most people are well aware of the detrimental effect those cuts have had on the services provided in child care. More importantly, a lot of the ill effects are still to come into place because they have not actually started operating yet.

What I want to look at very clearly are some of the propositions that have been put in this budget and to see what the negatives are for parents who are trying to find child care. I think it is a rather simplistic proposition to say that the Labor Party is opposed to the restriction of hours to non‐working parents as a matter of principle, because certainly that is not the case. There is some sympathy for the view, in principle, that non‐working parents should have their hours restricted. But the difficulties that arise from this proposition being put in place were made very obvious to us in the Senate community affairs committee last year when we took evidence in relation to a restriction in hours down to 12.

The very clear practical difficulty with this restriction is that non‐working parents, if they are entitled to only a limited number of hours, will normally seek care during the hours of 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. or thereabouts. The difficulty with that is that a child‐care centre that has a child in care between the hours of 10 and three is unable, generally, to find a child who is prepared to come in for the hours before 10 and after three. I think this is a serious problem that you will have to deal with, Minister, and one which you will need to take a rational approach to because it is certainly a problem that you will need to tackle when you impose these changes.

The second area that I have to applaud is the introduction of greater planning in the child care area. I do see that as a positive step and we will be supporting it. But, in saying those two positive things, as I like to do, I have to say that overall I think this is a very negative thing for parents who rely on child care.

In the next two years, there will be 27,000 fewer places available than there would be except for this budget. In fact, the additional cuts are $321 million, as has been stated over and over again, and that is on top of the $500 million last year.

BREAK.PARA: Included in the budget is the abolition of the operational subsidy for before and after school care. It has already been estimated that the removal of that subsidy will mean additional charges of up to $20 per child for those who utilise that care. The trouble with this particular sector is that it is probably the most poorly funded sector of child care in our community. The care is often in either unused school rooms or buildings donated by council that are no longer used—not the ideal. And certainly the staffing levels are not the same as those that many of the other child care centres and private long day care centres enjoy. It is very sad to see that this government is beating around the head a sector of child care which is very poorly off at the moment.

There has been an extension in the means test for those in before and after school care. The number of people who can receive child-care assistance for this type of child care has been extended, but the budget very clearly states that the level of assistance that is going to be provided to those utilising before and after school care will go down. If you are a low income earner earning less than $27,000, already utilising before and after school care, you will be not only $20 a week worse off but also worse off in the level of assistance that you will receive.

There has been an abolition of a number of things. The block grants to states for school care have been cut. This may well increase the cost of parents for vocation care. Alternatively, parents who cannot afford it may well leave their children unsupervised during vacations, which is not an option that I consider reasonable.

The cruellest cut or the most sneaky cut is a small line item in the budget which will save the government the princely sum of $39 million: that is, the requirement that in future child-care assistance—which is presently paid in advance—be paid on a fortnightly basis in arrears. It seems to me that a large number of families that enjoy child-care assistance will not be assisted. In fact, they will have to pay the money up front and then get it back two weeks later.

It certainly will not meet the objectives that I think are important for child-care assistance, and that is to ensure that parents can afford child care and that child care is of a high quality. All in all, this is a damaging budget for child care. There are some minor positive elements contained in it. I initially gave the government credit for that. But, overall, those people in child care are worse off. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for this debate has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert, Sen Paul
