DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee on the Brew report and on the continuing role of the Commonwealth in the Australian rail industry, together with submissions received by the committee and the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

This report is very important. It should have been brought down and the inquiry held before the government took the decisions that it took. This whole process has left a rather nasty taste in my mouth, given the importance of Senate inquiries and given the importance to the people of Australia of their Commonwealth railways.

BREAK.PARA: The committee felt that it was acting under a cloud and certainly under some pressure because the government had already announced that it was going to sell the Commonwealth railways without any opportunity to debate the decision in public. However, we took evidence, and I was very grateful for the quality of the evidence which was given. I thank the people in Adelaide, Port Augusta, Broken Hill, Launceston and those whom we heard from in Canberra who gave a lot of quality evidence to this inquiry and who enabled this report to proceed.

I also give thanks to the committee members. Despite the fact that politics was caught up in this—and I was as much involved in that as anyone else; we could not avoid that because of the decisions taken by the government before we even had a chance to meet—the committee members put their best foot forward and made a very good contribution. I think we all tried very hard to hear the evidence which was given and to allow that evidence to influence the way in which the report was written.

Nevertheless, there are two reports. I acknowledge that the government members were under a certain restriction in terms of their ability to endorse the majority report, given the decisions made by the government prior to the inquiry being held. Nevertheless, they cooperated very well with the inquiry. I certainly thank them for that. They made a very useful contribution.

I thank the members of the secretariat. I want to place their names on the record because of the work they did in a very quick time in making sure that this inquiry could proceed. I thank Andrew Snedden, the committee secretary, Pippa Carron, John O'Keefe, Maurice Chalmers and Judith Wuest, all of whom played a greater or lesser part in the hearings and in the presentation of this report. I think I said that we were very grateful to those who gave evidence at the various places where evidence was taken.

Let me, in setting a context for this report, speak about a concern that I have, which is a development that is very evident among governments in the Western democracies. It is illustrated very much by the process that I have just described. That is the development of the corporate state. The corporate state is a state where decisions are not made by elected representatives so much as by government, and particularly executive government, dealing with powerful elites and individuals rather than using its elected representatives to inform it about decisions. It was a development under Labor, but it has certainly escalated under this government.

This whole process of the sale of our Commonwealth railways is a perfect example of how the corporate state operates. The government, without any reference to parliament, made the decision to sell the people's asset. Before any legislation was passed, the sale of the asset was advertised. Then we discover, particularly through the budget last night, that this whole process is now being delayed by the necessity of the Commonwealth government to consult with the states that are most affected. I am concerned that governments are using this process of the corporate state rather than using the processes of the parliament itself.

I would remind the Senate that the corporate state was a concept developed by the Italian fascists in order to increase efficiency so that Mussolini could boast that he made the trains run on time. I am not implying that this government is fascist at all. I am not making that reference. The fascists believed that there was a role for government. I think this government believes that government should almost have no role in anything, so I am certainly not suggesting that it is fascist. But I am concerned about this development of the corporate state because I believe it is a development which takes away from the parliament its proper role.

The committee's report is very clear, and it does cast doubt on the sale of the railways. It examined the evidence and the report by Mr John Brew, and recognised that he operated within a very narrow framework and probably could not have come to any other conclusions than the ones that he came to. But the committee would say that there were other options and, if the terms of reference for Brew had not been so narrow, he could have considered other, I believe, more creative options. I am concerned about the continuing loss of jobs in Commonwealth railways, and the loss of transport to regional areas—or at least the possibility of that. I am also concerned that we have a need—and the government does not seem to take account of this—for a nationally integrated land transport strategy.

The committee did criticise the Brew report. It found that it failed to focus on the effect of the loss of AN business on South Australia. It failed to consult with users of the interstate passenger network. The Brew report failed to focus on users of AN services and the AN work force, or consult them to any degree. The committee raised concerns about the accuracy of the calculations in the Brew report. It is concerned that Brew did not consider AN in the broader context of land transport policy, ecologically sustainable development and employment in regional areas, but it does recognise that Brew laboured under some difficulties given the narrow terms of reference.

I commend the report to the Senate. I recognise that certainly the government has a different opinion and that it is quite appropriate for the government to make decisions, but I would certainly warn that governments that make decisions outside the parliamentary process surely are treading on dangerous ground. I hope that the government will take account of the recommendations of this report. I recognise that the government members themselves have their own dissenting report. I am sure that the government will take note of what they say, but I hope it will take note also of the majority report. Now that the government has run into some trouble, it may find itself able to look at some other options.

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose to address my remarks today only to the South Australian aspects of the report as my colleague Senator Crane will address the report's more general recommendations and comment on Senator Woodley's remarks. However, I draw to Senator Woodley's attention that in fact the government members have not made a minority report; they have simply made alternative recommendations in chapter 7.

BREAK.PARA: In Adelaide, the committee heard of the tragic and continuing demise of the South Australian rail network. Since 1982, 1,375 kilometres of railway line were closed or abandoned or, worse still, torn up and sold for scrap. So in 15 years 50 per cent of the South Australian rail network has been closed, most of it in regional areas. The most recent closure was at Eudunda in October 1995 when a South Australian minister, Diana Laidlaw, commendably, but sadly unsuccessfully, appealed to the then minister for transport, the Hon. Laurie Brereton, and asked that the line be left intact pending a discussion on its future. Not an unreasonable request, I would have thought, but interestingly enough it was completely ignored by the previous minister and so the line was dismantled and the rail stockpiled for sale.

But by far the greatest tragedy in South Australia's sorry saga with the railways is in Port Augusta, where thousands of people have lost their jobs. Forty of them lost their jobs on Christmas Eve. Can you imagine receiving a worse Christmas present than on Christmas Eve to be given notice that you have lost your job? What a legacy of the mismanagement of this network.

Just to give a perspective on the South Australia rail network: in 1974 there were 2,157 men and women working in the South Australian Railways at Port Augusta; in June this year the figure was 618—and, sadly, the work force has since been further reduced. This was a devastating blow to the city of Port Augusta and was colourfully outlined to the committee in evidence by the mayor, Joy Baluch. She described to us the `pious platitudes' and `empty promises' of the previous government ministers on the railways' future. She said that she welcomed the Brew inquiry because the `rail industry in Port Augusta was being strangled and employment opportunities were being continually lost'.
Mayor Baluch—and she is a colourful woman—also told the committee:
You would have to be deaf, dumb and blind and with a labrador dog to suggest that AN should continue to be operated by Government.

During the lunch break that day, some of the senators on the committee visited the railway workshops where an overwhelming sense of desolation and foreboding prevailed in those large empty buildings. The young men explained to us the great sense of helplessness and loss that they felt in their work environment. Moreover, they told me of the older family members who were taking redundancy to protect the jobs of their children. What a tragic decision to have to make.

Fortunately, at last, these Australians now have a sense of optimism. The Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) has indicated that there have been more than 50 bidders and expressions of interest for parts of NR and AN—clear evidence that once again the remarks of the handwringers in the Labor Party about the future of the railways have been unfounded and misguided—and notably, very notably, and importantly, a number of short‐listed companies have expressed an interest in buying the whole of AN, lock, stock and barrel.

These rail workers and their families at Port Augusta and at Islington in Adelaide can be heartened by the news that there is such strong interest in the sale of these very important federal government assets. Their optimism comes at the time when the level of interest is the best indicator of long-term employment in the rail sector. In fact, the strong interest by the private sector has totally vindicated the government's decision to sell the AN businesses and the Commonwealth's share of the National Rail Corporation. It also convincingly refutes the doom and gloom scenarios that Labor and the Democrats have tried to present in their report.

I note that last night's budget contained the second half of a very generous $20 million rail reform transition program. It may turn out to be even more generous, looking at the number of people who are interested in buying the rail network. But this figure will be crucial, and this package will help enormously the rail employees' adjustment process at Islington and at Port Augusta. It is yet another sign that this government is commit ted to helping rail communities get back on their feet and take control of their lives.

The government senators who took part in this inquiry found clear evidence that there is good reason for optimism for the future of rail in Australia. The private sector, by its bids for the network, has confirmed it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman, Sen Dominic

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee report on the Brew report and on the continuing role of the Commonwealth in the Australian rail industry is an important document. Its significance is not based upon any profound answer that it has for the future of the rail industry, although it may be a good starting point. Its importance is based on the fact that it opens up the debate about the future of our nation's transport infrastructure and the role for rail within it.

SPEECH.PARA: It is the hope of those of us in the Labor Party that the government will reconsider its position in light of the flaws that have been found in the Brew report, and ensure that a plan for rail is developed which allows for significant consultation with all interested parties. We are not oblivious to the problems that confront AN and, indeed, National Rail. In fact, the Brew report does pull together many of the economic issues that must be considered.

The problems with the report by John Brew, commissioned by Minister Sharp, relate to the solutions that he sees for rail, and the way that the government has dealt with this report. The Brew report was not released in a way that allowed for scrutiny and public debate. A small amount of information was released, but much of the Brew report was kept secret. The delay in full scrutiny of the report allowed a great deal of anxiety to develop within the AN work force.

It can be said that, given the contents of the Brew report, this anxiety was justified. But I think there is certainly a principle of openness and honesty that has been betrayed by this government. It is essential that the Australian people have an opportunity to examine the issues that were explored by the Brew report. It is important that people can see the shortcomings of the findings, and the limitations of the terms of reference.

BREAK.PARA: In the hearings I discovered that the commissioning of the Brew report was welcomed by the mayor of Port Augusta, Joy Baluch. But the subsequent investigation by John Brew did not include any discussions with the city council or any consideration of the interests of the affected communities. What point was there in having an inquiry which does not canvass the views of the work force and the affected communities?

Rail and associated industries, and the people who work in these industries, face great uncertainty. Australian National has undergone much change—it had to. The rail unions were amongst the first to recognise that the future of rail depended on more efficiency and a well trained and forward thinking work force.

The workers that I have spoken to over a number of years have always been willing to accept the need for change. They have always been enthusiastic about explaining the developments in their operations to those who have visited the shop floor, and those of us with a strong interest in the maintenance of industry have long been impressed with the commitment of these workers. My association with rail workers in South Australia began long before I entered this place. As secretary of the Vehicle Builders Union, I worked for union members who built and maintained carriages in the Commonwealth railways, the South Australian railways and later AN.

Workers in Port Augusta feel particularly vulnerable. Despite the views of the mayor, privatisation will be a real gamble for the people who work in this rail town. Many of the families have spent their entire lives working in this industry. The railways have been part of this region since last century and have provided stable employment for generations of Port Augusta, Stirling North, Quorn and Wilmington residents. So the implications of Mr Brew's recommendations are immense for workers in South Australia and Tasmania. The recommendations relating to the South Australian workshops, the closing of unprofitable lines and the privatisation of rail are the areas of most concern.

The government has approached the issue of AN privatisation with a great deal of ideological zeal. They have not proved that there is a case for the sale of Australian National; they have merely set AN up for a predetermined fate. For a start the terms of reference were designed to make this matter a purely financial one. The aim was to isolate the debate about the viability of AN from the effect that its departure would have on the lives of the people and the economy of South Australia. The single‐minded pursuit of a bottom line outcome for the AN business denies the long-term plans that the previous government put in place and was committed to.

Management received criticism in the hearings for exacerbating the problems within AN. It seems unfortunate that AN management accepted the Brew report and its implications without trying to explain its own actions that have led to this situation. The concerns about the way that Port Augusta operations were managed from Adelaide and the lack of communication between AN and the Port Augusta community should be noted with concern. I am aware of other concerns over AN management which have been raised by concerned constituents in my electorate office. I trust that AN is taking note of the issues that have been raised during this inquiry.

Unemployment is the major economic problem that this nation faces. This is at its most severe in regional Australia and amongst the work force that has been trained to work in a particular industry such as the rail industry. This government is showing no commitment to unemployed people. The lack of initiatives to tackle unemployment in the 1997-98 budget shows that this will not change in the foreseeable future. Unemployment in the northern and western regions of South Australia is at 9.3 per cent. Youth unemployment is over 30 per cent. A positive response to unemployment by the Howard government is needed and this response must include a commitment in real and long-term jobs for regional Australia.

There is a great deal of concern out there in the community about the apparent desire of this government to privatise industries like AN for the sake of it. There is no demonstrated need for privatisation in the case of Australian National. It is true that some feel that maybe things will be better or different if AN is sold off, but I believe that this is hardly a sound and rational reason for changing the ownership of an important industry in South Australia and Tasmania.

In essence it is the view of the majority on the committee that the government must carefully plan its response to the questions that arise from the debate on our rail system. There must be a land transport strategy that defines the role of this form of transport. It is not in the best interests of our community to allow for a hotchpotch approach which is based on some rigid concept of competition. It is not appropriate to just accept the experiences of other nations when our circumstances are so unique, our distances great and our historical experiences so different. I hope that this inquiry sparks a real assessment of where we are going in terms of the development of a future for rail.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane, Sen Winston

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to comment on the report of the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee and refer to some of the contributions that have been made. I found it offensive when Senator Woodley said that there were restrictions on the position adopted by government members. The evidence speaks for itself as far as that is concerned as examples of our independence. I refer also to the reports on PADS and chicken meat. In terms of inquiries, government senators of this committee have dealt with things on their merits and I think our record stands firm in that regard.

SPEECH.PARA: The solution that has been put forward by the Democrats and the Labor opposition would result in more jobs being lost and more taxpayers' money being lost. I will deal with a couple of points that I think are very important. The report states:

In fact, Mr Brew disclosed that in recent years there had been 7,000 jobs lost, mainly in South Australia, that taxpayers were subsidising every remaining employee $30,000 per year and that this subsidy would increase to $220,000 in just four years . . .

That is the situation. Nobody questioned the validity of the figures put before us by Mr Brew. There were criticisms with regard to the width and breadth of the terms of reference, but nobody could shoot holes in those figures. That was what we were faced with. That was the legacy of the previous Labor government—that lot over there—the 13 years of mismanagement. We had no option but to look at a new way; there is no question about that. I also bring to the attention of the chamber that the coalition has proposed a $2 billion reform package to rejuvenate rail operations and services in Australia. From the actions that we have already taken, it has been revealed that over 50 operations have shown an interest in taking up the option of providing rail services in this country.

At long last those people in the rail industry can look forward to an opportunity to get back to do what they do best. Let me quote from Mr Carter, Executive Officer of Rail 2000, a rail lobby group—certainly not a friend of our side of politics. He says:

We have lobbied extensively against rail closures in this state and for the preservation of rail infrastructure when lines have been closed. Unfortunately, our efforts have been only moderately successful and in the main, the Federal Government, through the auspices of the Australian National, has ripped up these taxpayer funded assets and sold them for scrap metal.
He is talking about that lot over that side. He continued:
Rail 2000 believes many of these lines that have been closed could have remained open had the opportunity been given to alternative operators . . .

. . . the rural rail network in South Australia has been decimated over the last decade or so and over 1,300 kilometres of track has been lifted. If we delay this process any further—for whatever reasons—even with the best will in the world, what you are going to see is that there will be no rural rail services left in South Australia.
That is what was said there.

Let me deal with some of the comments made in regard to Mr Brew. There was criticism of the terms of reference, and I accept that. But when Brew went outside the terms of reference and made recommenda tions, he was also criticised. So regardless of what he did he was damned. He could not win. It would not satisfy any of you lot over that side whatever way he went because he did not come up with the recommendations you wanted. He, in fact, gave a correct financial analysis of the serious state that our rail system was in.

It needs to be noted that in the 13 years of Labor in office AN ran up a debt of almost $1 billion, and over 7,000 rail jobs in urban and regional South Australia and Tasmania were lost. That is the legacy that was left to National Rail. With the formation of the National Rail Corporation and the assets stripping that was done of Australian National, what hope did they have? The assets were taken away—fundamentally given to National Rail—and they were left with the debt. That was the situation they were confronted with.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even Bob Collins agreed.

—Senator Collins spelt out, as we have spelt out in our report, exactly what happened and the difficulty involved. Nonetheless, it is the Labor government that must accept responsibility for what has occurred to Australian National and the National Rail Corporation. I can say to this Senate that in view of the activities of this government since it came to power—and thank God we did move and take some action on this—we find that over 50 operations wish to get involved in giving proper service in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: During the committee hearings, Senator Ferris asked:
If the debt was to be set aside—as some of our submissions have suggested, I think—or in some way relieved, that is, accepted by the government, do you think AN has a future?
Mr Smorgon, the chairman of AN, answered:
No, I think we have reached a stage where we are past that point.
It is here for you all to see.

Some alternatives have been put forward. One in particular that I want to deal with is AN interstate passenger services—something that we on this side of the chamber believe is very important. We believe in developing this in a flexible and proper manner. What do we see from the other side? They say, `Keep all that we have there; don't advance it; don't improve it; don't give it a chance; just let it go broke; let it cost taxpayers more money'—

TALK.START.PARA: —Let more jobs be lost.

BREAK.PARA: Senator CRANE —Yes, let more jobs be lost, as Senator Ferris says. The committee made the following recommendation: Therefore the Government Senators recommend the Government should ensure that if AN's passenger services are sold to operate as luxury tourist trains—
as was recommended by a number of people—
the needs of existing rail commuters to regional centres are considered by alternative services.

That was done in Western Australia when some of the railway lines closed down some years ago. There are now alternative bus services which take alternative routes and, in fact, now service a lot more people. So there are other ways of doing things. There are successful and constructive ways of doing things.

I am delighted that we had this inquiry and brought down this report, although at the time the inquiry was proposed I was not quite so keen on it. I know the processes that were going on. But having gone through the inquiry and seen the decimation that has occurred, and having had an opportunity to have a look and make some constructive recommendations to the government from our perspective, I believe that a lot of the recommendations that we have put forward will be incorporated into the new rail systems and Australia will maintain successful Commonwealth‐state railway operation in business, and it will be to the benefit of all Australians.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee on value‐adding in agricultural production, together with submissions received by the committee and the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

This report has been a long time in coming. The original reference was made in December 1993. In some ways it had a gestation equal to that of an elephant, and although it was a fairly painful birth I do hope the child will be healthy and have a long life. This is a very important report and I want to pay tribute to the midwife, Mr John O'Keefe, the senior research officer of the committee secretariat who did an excellent job. The deputy chair and I had a few issues that we needed to resolve but we were able to come to a unanimous report.

Value adding is a very important issue in Australian agriculture. I regret that it has taken so long for the report to be finalised. The problem was that we had a change of government, we had a change of committee, and we had a change of committee membership.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a big problem, I reckon.

—No, I am not going to comment on that. I did not attend many of the hearings for value adding, which I regret. I was a member of the committee at the time. For that reason, I do not want to make too many comments about the report because I believe others were far more involved than I was in its production.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not accept some of the conclusions but I agree that they reflect the evidence which was taken, and it is important that the issues that are raised in this report are debated. I think it would be helpful if, in conclusion, I read one of the conclusions, which states:

The Committee observes that, although agriculture's proportionate contribution to Australia's GNP and labour force has declined over the years, it still makes a very significant contribution to the national economy, particularly in regional areas, and will continue to do so.

Then the report goes on to show how that contribution needs to be supported by value adding to those industries. Many recommendations are made. I trust the government will, and I am sure they will, in their response take note of those and, I hope, respond positively to many of them.

I would draw attention to a conclusion about the need for ethanol production. I think the Senate would know this is a bit of a wheelbarrow of mine. I trust that the government may look again at the ethanol bounty scheme in light of that conclusion and recommendation made by the committee. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane, Sen Winston

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse the comments of our chairman, Senator Woodley, and in doing so acknowledge the work that Senator Burns and Senator Brownhill did in putting this report together.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the President, I present to the Senate a request from solicitors acting for Senator O'Chee that counsel be briefed to appear as amicus curiae in a defamation action by Mr M.H. Rowley against Senator O'Chee in relation to a point of law concerning parliamentary privilege. On behalf of the President, I also present correspondence associated with this request.

INTERJECT.PARA: The matter in issue concerns whether correspondence addressed to Senator O'Chee and information provided to him is subject to parliamentary privilege in that it was furnished for the purpose of, and incidental to, Senator O'Chee's participation in proceedings of the Senate.

It may be appropriate in some circumstances for the President to instruct counsel to appear in a case without a direction of the Senate. The President has, however, indicated to the solicitors in the correspondence that in this case the President would not undertake to instruct counsel except at the explicit direction of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor‐General:

BREAK.PARA: Report No. 31 of 1996‐97—Performance Audit—Medifraud and inappropriate practice—Health Insurance Commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I welcome the report on what is a most important issue for the parliament. It is an important issue also for the people of Australia, particularly for the health sector. The report, which is entitled Medifraud and inappropriate practice —a report by the Australian National Audit Office on efforts by the Health Insurance Commission to reduce, stamp out, health Medicare fraud and inappropriate practice—is one which finds that the efforts being undertaken by the Health Insurance Commission to do this are working.

The report notes, as I think is well known to all senators and the public at large, that the expenditure by government on payments under the Medicare system and in terms of pharmaceutical benefits run to the order of $8.3 billion per year. That is a heck of a lot of taxpayers' funds in anyone's language. Of course expenditure on the health budget, ensuring that Australians have access to universal health care, that we have an equitable system and a high quality system—indeed, a world's best health system—takes up a significant proportion of the overall level of government expenditure.

I think it has been recognised on all sides of politics that it is important that that expenditure be properly accounted for and that the system is one which taxpayers can have faith in and that will deliver what it is intended to do. So when you have around $8.3 billion of public funds being paid out as benefits in one form or another under the health system, as I said, particularly through Medicare benefits, we need to ensure that the level of fraud, the level of overservicing, the level of inappropriate practice, is kept to a minimum, if not ideally removed all together.

This study by the audit office arises out of an earlier report conducted in 1992‐93 which found problems within the system. It found there was an unacceptable level of fraud. The audit office consequently made a number of major recommendations as to how to deal with that situation. This report looks back at what has occurred since its earlier report in 1992‐93. It examines how successful the measures have been which were put in place by the Health Insurance Commission and the then Labor government to deal with this problem. I would like to quote from the summary of the report because I believe it should be recorded how successful the efforts have been. This report was embargoed until earlier this afternoon and I have not yet had time to go through the report entirely. I will refer to the comments in the summary. It states on page xi of the report:
The ANAO's purpose was to report to Parliament on:
HIC's management of approaches to minimise medifraud and inappropriate practice;
HIC's reporting of its performance on these matters to stakeholders;
the methodology used by the HIC to estimate the extent of fraud and inappropriate practice, including comment on the reliability of the estimates; and
the HIC's implementation of the major recommendations from Medifraud and Excessive Servicing —Audit Report No. 17 1992‐93.
On page xii the ANAO concludes that—and I quote:

the HIC has adopted a sound risk management approach to managing leakage through fraud and inappropriate practice from the Medicare and Pharmaceutical Benefits Schemes. Its approach, which emphasises the importance of preventative action, is being amended to bring it into accord with the Commonwealth Law Enforcement Board . . . guidelines for the management of fraud against the Commonwealth;

the measures the Commission uses to report to external stakeholders on management of fraud and inappropriate practice could be improved. These improvements include additional performance indicators, release of more useful information on results of Purpose Based Audits, and publication of estimates of fraud and inappropriate practice;

while the Commission has followed advice from the Australian Bureau of Statistics in developing and using data from Source Based Audits, it is unable to produce a reliable estimate—at an acceptable cost—of leakage through fraud. The Commission intends to re‐ examine the possibility of producing an estimate once three years of data from Source Based Audits are available. The Commission has not produced national estimates of inappropriate practice from Medicare and the Pharmaceutical Benefits Schemes; and
the Commission has implemented all major recommendations from Audit Report No. 17 1992‐93.

The report by the audit office finds that whilst there is still room for improvement and that there is still work that needs to be done, particularly over a longer period of time, to assess how successful the actions have been, nevertheless, the commission has implemented all the recommendations that came out of that earlier report.

I particularly want to point to the fact that the audit office finds that, on indicative estimates, leakage through fraud is currently running at around 1.3 per cent to 2.3 per cent of payments from the Medicare and pharmaceutical benefits schemes. To put it another way, it finds that 98 per cent, or thereabouts, of payments that are made through the Medicare and the PBS schemes are proper and that there is no evidence other than, as it says, for about two per cent of payments where any fraud has occurred. That, the office finds, is a very commendable level of ensuring that the system is not abused.

It is unfortunate, of course, that in a scheme as large and significant as Medicare, there will always be instances where the system is abused, either by practitioners in the system or, indeed, by those who may be patients or claimants. Of course, within the Health Insurance Commission, there is the professional services review scheme which has as its specific task, firstly, to monitor the schemes to ensure that fraud is eliminated wherever it is suspected and proved and, secondly, that practitioners, particularly, are counselled where, whilst there may not be evidence of direct fraud, there is the existence of inappropriate practice such as overuse of referrals and other health services.

I welcome the report of the audit office. It demonstrates that the actions and systems put in place by the previous government have worked within the Health Insurance Commission. I hope that this current government, whilst it seems to be able to find ways to increasingly cut back on government regulation and government servicing, ensures that we continue to maintain Medicare as the top quality health system that it is. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

BREAK.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the first report of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties and I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE FIRST REPORT OF THE JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON TREATIES

SPEECH.PARA: The Government welcomes the Committee's endorsement of the main features of the reform of the Australian treaty‐making process that Mr Downer presented to Parliament on 2 May 1996. We remain hopeful that most of the community disquiet about treaties and the external affairs power will be allayed through the effective implementation of the reform. We intend to take stock during 1998, with the benefit of about two years' experience, and consider then the need for any further steps.

The Committee's scrutiny of Australian treaty action, and in particular the consideration of tabled treaties, is a fundamental component of the new approach to treaty‐making—an approach characterised by consultation and transparency to the greatest extent possible, consistent with the national interest.

PARA.EMPHASIS: National Interest Analyses should also include a discussion of the legal effects and potential areas of conflict with State and Territory laws;

SPEECH.PARA: National Interest Analyses (NIAs) already have a section (`Implementation') that describes the measures Australia intends to take or has taken to implement the treaty action in question, including any legislation. This section notes whether Commonwealth and/or State and Territory action is involved, and any changes to the existing roles of the Commonwealth and the States and Territor ies as a consequence of implementing the treaty action in this way. There are well known general principles concerning the effect of treaties in Australian law. These include:
. treaties do not form part of Australian law unless and until they are incorporated into that law by statute; and
. their use in the interpretation of statutes and as a source for the development of the common law.

In addition, there is no doubt that they give rise to Commonwealth legislative power under the external affairs power in the Constitution. Although the Teoh Case stated that treaties also might give rise to a legitimate expectation that administrative decisions would be made consistently with obligations under those treaties, that expectation (and the procedural right that follows) has been set aside by the Joint Executive Statement issued by the previous Government on 10 May 1995 and the Executive Statement issued by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Attorney‐General on 25 February 1997.

There is no need to reiterate the general legal effects in the case of each treaty. The Government remains of the view that its commitment to ensure that the necessary implementing legislation and practice is in place, together with a description of that legislation and practice in the NIA, is appropriate.

As for potential areas of conflict with State and Territory laws, the Committee will appreciate that a complete search of all the statutes and other sources of law for all the Australian jurisdictions in relation to every contemplated treaty action would not be practicable, given Commonwealth Government resource constraints. In addition, the States and Territories themselves are the most appropriate authorities on State and Territory law and are best placed to form a view on any potential conflict. On this basis, the Commonwealth circulates to the States and Territories (through the Standing Committee on Treaties), approximately four times a year, complete schedules of current treaty negotiations and impending treaty action. With this information and the other formal and informal CommonwealthState consultation that occurs in a range of forums (including the Standing Committee of Attorneys‐General), States and Territories are given the opportunity to examine this issue and to put views on areas of potential conflict to the Commonwealth. Many such matters are resolved in the course of consultation. Where there are major outstanding issues, these will be reflected in the existing sections of the NIAs dealing with consultation and the role of the States and Territories in implementing the treaty obligations.

PARA.EMPHASIS: National Interest Analyses identify the Commonwealth department or agency with primary carriage for a particular treaty along with relevant contact details; and

SPEECH.PARA: The Government accepts this suggestion and has included contact position details in NIAs tabled from the beginning of 1997. Since NIAs are intended to be of long‐term use, the inclusion of individual officials' names would not be very helpful. Even Departmental titles and sub‐divisions will of course change, but knowing which area was responsible at the time of tabling will give people interested in the treaty in future a starting point for tracing its continuing relevance.

PARA.EMPHASIS: National Interest Analyses include specific details of organisations and individuals consulted and how such consultation occurred, particularly with the Treaties Council.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has no difficulty with the proposition that the `Consultation' section of NIAs provide as much detail as is feasible. If a treaty has been considered by the Treaties Council, that can certainly be mentioned, quoting the conclusions of the Council as recorded in the communiqu. Of course, it will not always be appropriate to name individuals, and there may even be instances in which national security, for example, would make too much detail invidious. The other ground for occasional derogation is that certain major treaties, negotiated and considered over several years, might generate unusably long NIAs if every contact were itemised.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 2.12—International Institute for Democracy and Electoral Assistance

An assessment of the performance and effectiveness of the International Institute for Democracy and Electoral Assistance be provided to the Committee, including the extent to which its activities are focused in countries of significance to Australia and the level of Australian involvement in its activities, before any further financial contributions are made.

SPEECH.PARA: The International Institute for Democracy and Electoral Assistance (International IDEA) was established on 27 February 1995 as an international organisation, with Australia as one of its founding States. Its Headquarters Agreement with the Government of Sweden came into force in December 1995, and the recruitment of international staff commenced in January 1996.
The objectives of the Institute, as set out in the Agreement by which it was established, are:
. to promote and advance sustainable democracy worldwide;
. to improve and consolidate democratic electoral processes worldwide;
. to broaden the understanding and promote the implementation and dissemination of the norms, rules, and guidelines that apply to multi‐party pluralism and democratic processes;
. to strengthen and support national capacity to develop the full range of democratic instruments;
. to provide a meeting‐place for exchanges between all those involved in electoral processes in the context of democratic institution‐building;
. to increase knowledge and enhance learning about democratic electoral processes; and
. to promote transparency and accountability, professionalism and efficiency in the electoral process in the context of democratic development.

The Government believes that these objectives are valid, and consistent with its own commitment to seek to uphold and promote the principles of liberal democracy where possible, and to encourage, and aid in an active way societies in the process of developing democratic institutions, while recognising that many countries that are important partners of Australia place different interpretations on the nature and meaning of liberal democracy, which will be respected.

Australia has committed, through AusAID, A$250,000 per annum for three years to the Institute's core budget from May 1995. This contribution is made in recognition of the synergies between stable democratic government, peace, and equitable economic and social development. International IDEA's work in developing countries will build the local capacity to sustain electoral reform and bolster democracy, providing the stable environment crucial for effective government and sustained growth.

According to its Statutes the Institute consists of a Council, a Nominating Committee, a Board of Directors, a Secretary‐General, and a Secretariat. The Secretary‐General is Mr Bengt Sve‐Sderbergh, a national of Sweden. Australians have since the Institute's establishment participated directly in all of its main structures. Australia as a member is directly represented on the Council, and the Electoral Commissioner, Mr Bill Gray AM, has led the Australian delegation to the Council on two occasions. Senator Margaret Reynolds is a member of the Nominating Committee, as a representative of Parliamentarians for Global Action, an organisation which is an Associate Member of the Institute. Emeritus Professor Colin Hughes, former Electoral Commissioner, serves in his individual capacity as a member of the Board of Directors. An Australian national is also employed as a Programme Officer in one of the fifteen international staff positions in the Secretariat.

The Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) has been substantially involved in the development of the Institute's overall work program. As part of the consultation process underpinning that development, the Electoral Commissioner participated in two meetings of the election management bodies of the member States, funded by the Institute, at which priority projects were discussed and identified. An AEC officer, seconded to the Institute at its expense, drafted the working papers that were dealt with at the first of those meetings. An AEC officer also participated as an expert panellist in a roundtable meeting on capacity building, sponsored by the Institute in AugustSeptember 1995, that provided input to the development of the Institute's work program in that field.
The AEC has also taken part in a number of major projects within the Institute's work program.

. The Institute is currently undertaking a substantial cross‐national study of the administration and cost of elections, the aim of which is to identify optimal and efficient practices in a broad range of areas of electoral administration. It is intended that this will widen the range of alternatives and choices available to electoral administrators, provide complete and systematic information to those who are faced with designing electoral procedures, and support those who provide advisory assistance to election management bodies. An AEC officer is a member of the expert working group that is guiding the project.

. The Institute is developing a draft Code of Conduct for election observation. The need for such a Code was identified at a roundtable meeting on the subject, organised by the Institute in late 1995, that brought together a wide range of international bodies active in the election observation field. The first draft was prepared by an AEC officer seconded to the Institute specifically to work on the project. Even in its draft form, the Code was held up by those in charge of the observation of the recent elections in Bosnia‐Herzegovina as a model Code for use in that election. In addition, it was used at the recent elections in Nicaragua, at the instigation of the Electoral Commission in that country.

. As associated projects, the Institute is developing draft Codes of Conduct for election administration, and for the conduct of political parties during election campaigns. Again, the first drafts have been prepared by an AEC officer seconded to the Institute for that purpose.

Apart from those listed above, the Institute is pursuing a diverse but practically oriented set of projects, covering at the moment such areas as electoral dispute resolution systems, the support of networks of election administrators, and field co‐operation for international election observer missions. The Institute anticipates that in 1997 it will be launching projects on electoral technology, the political participation of women, the future of electoral observation, guidelines pertaining to election observation involvement, and guidelines for the evaluation of free and fair elections. It will also be continuing to develop a joint Institute/United Nations Development Programme Information Network. In the field of capacity building, the Institute undertook in 1996 introductory missions to Kenya, Nicaragua, Romania, and, in the Asia‐Pacific region, Nepal. Work has also been done on challenges facing democratic development and electoral processes in Bosnia‐Herzegovina, Nigeria, and Bangladesh.
More general projects have also been initiated on the nature of democracy, on electoral systems and their design, and on the funding and functioning of political parties.

Finally, the Institute is providing a range of information services for its clients, including an Internet home page, a Newsletter, databases, and a range of professional publications and reports. The Institute has on a number of occasions been able to provide Australian clients with information on international best practice in specific areas of election administration.

In the Asia‐Pacific region, the Institute's activities are expanding. Apart from its activities in Nepal and Bangladesh, it has offered services in the field of electoral assistance to the electoral authorities in Papua New Guinea and Fiji, and has taken a particular interest in the situation in Myanmar as a consequence of the presence of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi on its Board of Directors. It has also agreed to provide funding of $50,000 for a meeting of the election management bodies of South Pacific countries, which the AEC has proposed be held in 1997. It has further indicated its interest in making a substantive continuing commitment to electoral assistance in the region.

In summary, the Government notes that the overall level of Australian involvement in the Institute's activities has been substantial, and has given Australia the opportunity to exercise a beneficial influence in the specialised area that is the focus of the Institute's activities. The extent to which its field projects are being conducted in areas of significance to Australia is increasing, and is likely to reach a substantial level in the near future. In the light of these facts, the Government believes that the Institute's activities are deserving of continued support from Australia. The government also notes that there are no provisions in the Agreement by which the Institute was constituted that impinge in any way on Australian sovereignty.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade provide the Committee with details of contracts tendered for and awarded to Australian companies, the number of qualified Australians occupying staff positions with the Korean Peninsula Energy Development Organization, together with the schedule of payments of Australian contributions.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia has consistently underlined its interest in securing Korean Peninsula Energy Development Organization (KEDO) commercial contracts at a level broadly commensurate with our financial contribution to the consortium. High‐level representations have been made to the KEDO Executive Board and senior government officials from the consortium's three principal countries (the Republic of Korea (ROK), Japan, and the United States) on potential commercial opportunities for Australian companies. They have all acknowledged the reasonableness of our expectation that Australian companies be given a fair chance to compete for KEDO contracts within the framework of an open and transparent contracting system.

With AUSTRADE's assistance, my Department has also alerted companies to the available commercial opportunities, identified relevant Australian capabilities and interest in providing a range of auxiliary goods and services, and communicated this information to both KEDO and KEPCO, the prime contractor for the light water reactor project. For commercial reasons, we are unable to identify the twelve companies that have expressed interest in tendering, but the areas of identified Australian expertise include communications, electricity distribution, tower cranes, site roads, steel formwork, drainage pumps, remote monitoring, and construction catering.

Since KEPCO's tendering guidelines and procedures have still to be worked out, no major international tenders have been let and none are expected for the proposed eight‐month site preparation stage. Work on the light water reactor was effectively put on hold following the incursion into ROK territory in September 1996 of a submarine and armed Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK) military personnel. Fortunately, the statement of `deep regret' over the incident issued by the DPRK on 29 January 1997 cleared the way for a resumption of the project. We are maintaining pressure on KEPCO, and indeed the ROK government, to finalise the tendering procedures as soon as possible.

The possibility of placing Australians in the KEDO Secretariat has not been taken up with KEDO as this would detract from our effort on contracts and having the consortium adopt open tendering processes. Moreover, KEDO is trying to limit staff numbers and has indicated that countries wishing to occupy positions will have to fund their own staff. We are keeping the matter under review, but do not believe that a position is necessary at present, especially given our excellent relations and high‐level contact with KEDO.

There is no schedule of Australian payments to KEDO. Our three contributions to date reflect our strategic and non‐proliferation interests in seeing KEDO succeed, the consortium's financial needs, and high‐level approaches from the KEDO principals. Possible further Australian contributions are a matter for Government decision, taking into account KEDO's overall performance and future needs.
