TITLE.XREF: NATURAL HERITAGE TRUST OF AUSTRALIA BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering the bill as a whole and amendments 9, 10 and 11, moved by Senator Lees on behalf of the Australian Democrats.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Just very briefly to remind the minister that I did leave him with a question or two at the end of the last session, when we were discussing this bill. They related to what surveillance mechanisms he and his department will have in place to keep an eye on the states and also on local government in relation to the potential for cost shifting and for them to find ways to pull money out of local government areas particularly and catchment management groups where there is money going from the Natural Heritage Trust.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —We recognise the problem and we would not want to overstate its occurrence, but we do appreciate there must be a temptation from time to time to cost shift. That is not to our advantage because we are trying to maximise the environmental benefit and if we are simply substituting for state money then that does not achieve the goal. But our people, while they do not have surveillance procedures as such, are well informed as to the structure of the state government programs, which vary, of course, greatly in state of development. Nevertheless, they are well informed as to what is occurring on the ground at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: A lot of it has come out of the history of landcare, because you have had the regional assessment committees and the state assessment committees through that body. As the new projects are developed up through the RAPs and the state bodies they will be carefully monitored by our people to ensure that there is not this substitution. The states will be committing themselves in the partnership agreements to not be substituting. The procedure cannot be absolutely foolproof, but it is certainly in our interests to ensure that it works as well as possible, and we think it will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again the minister wants the committee to accept his glib assurances that his people will be watching this matter, but turn down the specific amendment coming from Senator Lees which will ensure that moneys are not given to the states simply to be used for environmental projects which otherwise the states would be funding, while the states move that same amount of money across to other projects, which, of course, can be inimical to the environment.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us be clear here: the minister, presumably supported by Senator Harradine, is going to vote against an amendment which would ensure that the states do not double shuffle this money coming from the Natural Heritage Trust Fund, out of the partial sale of Telstra, and simply use it to fund projects that they were funding anyway so that they have got money to put into other pursuits of their own designation. What is more, there is an amendment here to ensure that there is an agreement, including an undertaking that the states receiving grants do not do anything contrary to the principle of the act. That is pretty clear. If the state is going to get money under the Natural Heritage Trust Fund it does not, at the same time, act in a way that cuts right across the principles of the trust fund in repairing and enhancing Australia's environment.

But here we have the minister for the environment saying, `I do not want to abide by that; I do not want to tie myself to that. If the states are going to be wrecking the environment and taking money out of this fund to put into repair projects, that is going to be okay. I am certainly not going to be tied down to ensuring that does not happen.' So we have got this absurd situation where under the lax rules in this Natural Heritage Trust Fund, for example, mining corporations can leave environmental degradation behind them and the states can take money out of this fund to fix it up, while at the same time authorising the same mining companies to be going in elsewhere and creating more havoc to the environment.

That is clearly potentially available. That is what happens in Australia at the moment. We have seen massive funding, in terms of what community groups get, go to cleaning up after mining companies in several states, including Tasmania. That was in the budget last night. Millions of dollars of taxpayers' money repairing the damage that the mining corporations should have been repairing themselves. Instead of that, they put it across into their profit lines and pocket the money.

But when Senator Lees puts forward an amendment which says, `Let's ensure that does not happen. Let's ensure, at least, that this public money does not go in a way which is throwing good money after bad, does not go to clean up after projects which cause environmental damage and are authorised by state governments,' this Minister for the Environment says, `No, I am not going to allow that stricture to come in.'

That is reprehensible. That is plain and simple accountability which the minister is thumbing his nose at. That is tantamount to saying to the people of Australia, `If you expect that the Prime Minister meant last year, when he was announcing this fund, that he was actually going to guarantee that it went to top value environmental repair projects, silly you. I am now Minister for the Environment, and I am not going to bind myself by stipulations in this legislation which are going to ensure that the environment gets the best deal.'

After all, this is the same minister who is authorising the broad scale logging of forests in this country for woodchipping and whole log exports, including forests of national estate and world heritage value; who is authorising the government policy which thumbs its nose at a global effort to bring into control the global warming phenomenon; who is authorising an increase in uranium mining; and who is authorising generally a suite of government policies which are the most inimical to the environment in living memory—certainly since the beginning of the 1970s. It is just not good enough for him to sit with his head in his hand and talk about other things while this challenge from the Democrats in the form of this amendment goes wholly inadequately answered by this minister who is so derelict in his duty.

Maybe Senator Harradine will get up and speak for him again. Maybe it will be left to Senator Harradine to try to defend the indefensible. Maybe Senator Harradine—who is a stickler for transparency, for due public process and for ensuring that the government spends public dollars in the best directed way possible—will get up and defend these amendments of Senator Lees which try to do just that, which try to ensure that the states do not double‐shuffle moneys, so that in effect the Natural Heritage Trust Fund moneys are wasted on projects which ought to be funded by the states.

Maybe Senator Harradine will get up and say, `Well, it's logical. You are right, Senator Lees.' There should be a stipulation here which ensures that the states, if they are going to get this money, do not engage in other activities which cut right across the principles which this legislation sets out in its ostensible pursuit of helping improve Australia's environmental future.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments will be put separately. Therefore, the first question is that Senator Lees's amendment No. 9 be agreed to.
—Thank you, Mr Temporary Chairman, I would—
—Again! You have put your argument 20 times. How much public money are you going to waste?

—The minister throws his hands in the air and says `again' and looks annoyed and frustrated, but I told him that he was going to get tackled on this, and he is. It is not good enough for him to sit there and go silent when he is being challenged. This is a matter of major importance. It is a matter of proper, responsible government. He is simply waving it away. I have no doubt that he is going to vote against it—as I said, assisted by Senator Harradine. Again, a very proper amendment, which is meant to bring some rigour into the spending of this money on behalf of the environment, is simply being denied by the cavalier attitude and anti-environmental attitude of this so-called Minister for the Environment.
—The amendments will be put separately. Therefore, the first question is that Senator Lees's amendment No. 9 be agreed to.
—The second question is that Senator Lees's amendment No. 10 be agreed to.
—The last question is that Senator Lees's amendment No. 11 be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (7) Clause 21, page 11 (lines 26 and 27), omit paragraph (2)(b).

Let me outline the strong case that the opposition has in support of this amendment. This amendment in effect removes the reference in the bill which allows the minister to allocate funds to any project which he believes is relevant. I must say that I thought this was a clause that the minister had slipped in—no doubt to ensure that the reserve could be used for whatever political purposes this minister sees fit. As far as the opposition is concerned, we would argue very strongly that this clause should be removed to ensure that the reserve is allocated to projects which meet strict selection criteria. The case for this amendment is strong. I commend it to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment is in fact the same as our amendment No. 16. What it does to clause 21 is remove part (b). The clause says:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) In making that decision, the Minister concerned must have regard to:

TAB.TAB: (b) such other matters as the Minister concerned considers relevant.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps I could ask the minister: what other matters do you envisage would be relevant?

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very difficult to answer that in advance. This provision seeks to retain a certain flexibility and to demonstrate that it is not solely the principles of ecological sustainable develop ment upon which the decisions will be based. They must be based on that, but it may include other matters. That is all we are seeking to do through this provision. The examples that have been suggested to me by those wiser than I that we may wish to take into account are future intergovernmental agreements which may be developed or existing national strategies—it might be the national biodiversity strategy which Senator Faulkner referred to this morning. I would have thought the biodiversity strategy, in view of the earlier debate we have heard, Senator Lees—
—That fits under (3)(a)(i), the principles of ecologically sustainable development.

—There could be a whole range of matters that could be very relevant at the time in making a decision as to whether a particular project will achieve the best environmental outcome. That is why it has been put in—to retain that flexibility. Senator Faulkner appreciates that all programs have to be pursuant to the objects and goals of the bill. But to ensure the best chance of achieving that, there obviously needs to be some flexibility in the factors that should be taken into account.
—That was pathetic, even for you.
—Senator Faulkner laughs, and I guess that is fair enough.
—No, I just said that, even for him, that was pathetic.

—Absolutely. A certain supercilious note comes into his voice when he says there are other things to be taken into consideration. Like what? Like who has put the biggest funds into the Liberal Party's election campaign monies? Like which electorates they consider are marginal and therefore need to prop up with projects? Like which woodchip company has the best contacts with the minister's office? Like which mining corporation wants to get out of having to do its proper duty and clean up the mess it has left, wherever it might be? What the minister is saying is, `Trust me.' Well I don't, and the further he dismisses any attempt in here at accountability, the less I am inclined to do so.

BREAK.PARA: Both the opposition and the Democrats are right: the principles of ecologically sustainable development should be taken into consideration and should be paramount and definitive. We should not have them counterbalanced by a clause which says `such other matters as the minister considers relevant', because he has already made it clear in here that, if there is an economic interest at stake against an environmental interest, he will let the environment go down the gurgler. His own actions outside the ambit of this particular legislation demonstrably show that he will put the environment second every time. In fact, in his representations in cabinet, he does not have the environment at the top of his priorities. It will come in a bad second if he is given a chance.

So I totally support this amendment from the opposition. It cannot do more than restrict the minister, if it were successful, to adopting the principles of ecologically sustainable development. Well, we might say, `Does he understand what that means?' Yes, he does. He absolutely understands what that means. But we might then say, `Well, is he going to faithfully implement the principles of ecologically sustainable development in the disbursement of this fund?' The answer to that is, no, he will not, because he does not have it in his make‐up to stand up and properly defend the environment and ecologically sustainable development either in disbursement of this fund or in carrying out the rest of his very important environmental responsibilities.

Of course he is going to oppose this move, to allow himself free rein to do what he likes as far as allocating this money and of course Senator Harradine is going to support that free rein given to the minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask the minister a question, but, before I do so, the clause we are talking about says:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) In making that decision—
namely, to approve proposals to spend money in the reserve for a purpose of the reserve—
the Minister concerned must have regard to:

TAB.TAB: (a) the principles of ecologically sustainable development; and
(b) such other matters as the Minister concerned considers relevant.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not an `or'; it is an `and'. The disbursement must be made to programs which are able to meet the criteria of establishing ecologically sustainable development. Those definitions are contained in clause (3).

Am I to assume, Minister, that `other matters' would include, for example, the fact that the government has assured me that 10 per cent of the monies to be spent will be spent in Tasmania? Is that not another matter that the minister would consider relevant? If it is, then surely this particular provision should be supported by all concerned in this chamber. Should that be a matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is quite a tricky question, actually. The government has made a commitment to ensure that 10 per cent of the fund is expended in Tasmania. We did that on the basis of accepting a number of arguments: firstly, the pre‐eminent position of Tasmania in relation to Australia's natural heritage; and, secondly, a recognition of the extra burden that Tasmanians have accepted in conserving that natural heritage—a much greater proportion of the state of Tasmania, for example, is included within the reserve system; and also a recognition that Tasmania does have some extra economic difficulties above and beyond those of certain other states.

SPEECH.PARA: They were the reasons we believed a case a was made out for it, but what we had to do, Senator Harradine, was then ensure that projects consistent with the principles of the act could nevertheless be developed, because that was the constraint in which we had to operate. We were satisfied, after receiving several submissions from the Tasmanian government, that projects of the appropriate quality and within the programs as set out in the act could be developed in Tasmania that would take up 10 per cent of the fund.

Whether it is technically a matter that needs to be taken into account in terms of this legislation, as opposed to a background matter—I am not sure. What I can tell you, Senator Harradine, is that the principles of ecologically sustainable development were never intended to be the exclusive principles upon which money is to be disbursed. What we have committed ourselves to in this bill—and I think for the first time—is to ensure that the principles of ecologically sustainable development are taken into account in determinations. We think that that is very important.

As we were saying earlier today, there is not much point in setting up national strategies in relation to these areas if they simply then become another book in the bookshelf; they need to be implemented. In this bill, in appropriating this very large sum to our natural heritage, we are taking those principles into account.

But there may be other factors from time to time that we want to take into account as well. I mentioned the Biodiversity Convention and the national strategy in that area, and the interjections were that it was believed that that would be sufficiently encompassed within the principles of ecologically sustainable development. It may or it may not be.

I am reminded that we are in the process of developing a national wetlands strategy. We have developed a Commonwealth wetlands policy and each of the states is developing a policy, and we want to integrate all of these into what will be almost a world leader in terms of preserving the wetlands of this nation. That strategy we may wish to take into account in the future as well. It is not specifically referred to, of course, in the national strategy for ecologically sustainable development, because the latter was developed before the wetlands strategy. So we do need that bit of flexibility.

Given that it is our objective and it is sensible policy to have that bit of extra flexibility, the question then becomes, Senator Harradine: if this amendment is successful and subclause (b) is removed, what is the consequence of that? We took advice on that from the Office of Parliamentary Counsel, and I just read the last paragraph:

The only way that I can guarantee that the courts will not construe subclause 21(2) as an exhaustive enumeration of the matters for consideration is to include a provision along the lines of paragraph 21(2)(b).

That is why the draftsman has included it: to make it clear that the ESD principle was never intended to be an exclusive factor in the determinations to be made under this clause. So it is a safeguard and, I put it to the committee, a sensible safeguard.

Some want to review it cynically—unfortunately that is in the nature of politics—but that will be watched. There will be the annual reports, the questions in this place and the estimates committees. No doubt, programs that are developed under this fund will be analysed in very great detail and judgments will be made upon that. I do urge the committee to recognise that maintaining that bit of flexibility within this clause is the implementation of sensible policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens would submit that all government expenditure should come within the ambit of ecologically sustainable development. Since the international conference on the future of the planet, in Rio de Janeiro in 1992, environmental and indeed wider wisdom—the complete wisdom of humanity—is that we have to move to ecologically sustainable development. We have to stop the catastrophic deterioration in the environment which is coming out of the rapid so‐called development of the planet in the interests of materialism in the late 1990s.

BREAK.PARA: Consequent on that conference, some 1,500 of the world's top scientists, including more than 100 Nobel laureates, appealed to the governments of the world to adopt those principles in everything they did, saying that the living fabric of the planet could not withstand the rapid degradation that is occurring at the moment under current government guidelines; not least in the developed nations of the world, including Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hang your head in shame.
—The government senator opposite says tritely, `Hang your head in shame' and there is a laugh about it going on on the government benches. But I, for one, take this seriously.

BREAK.PARA: I think when 1,500 of the world's top scientists, including all those Nobel laureates, say to the world, `Let's do something about this,' we should take it seriously. As I said earlier in this place, if there was an injunction from an equal number of economists warning governments that if they did not change course there would be a collapse on the stock exchange, there would be a frantic rush to change government direction and to head off such an economic outcome. And we would have it on the front pages of the newspapers around the country. But, because the scientist was speaking about the environment and the sustainability of life—including human life on the planet in the next few decades—it is a matter of some humour on the coalition benches and they dismiss it as if it is a bit of fun. It must be taken seriously.

Here we have the situation where not only will Senator Hill, the Minister for the Environment, on behalf of this government, not confine himself to ecologically sustainable principles in the spending of a very tiny amount of money, compared to government budgets, in the pursuit of environmental enhancement in this country; he will not apply it to this Natural Heritage Trust Fund. He does not want to be confined by that wisdom. He wants the ability to take into account such other matters as he wishes, as might seem proper to him.

Some of those matters, of course, will involve pressure from those in the corporate sector doing the wrong thing. Not all the corporate sector is doing the wrong thing; some of it is making excellent changes in direction as the increasing alarm about the way the world's environment is going gets through to people with a greater wisdom. Nevertheless, in 1997 in Australia—and I cannot repeat this often enough—under the aegis of this government, and particularly authorised by this Minister for the Environment, we have got the greatest rate of destruction of our forests in history and, with that, a tragic impact on the safety of the species richness that this country has. Moreover, we have got rapid, vast, wholesale destruction of native vegetation cover—up to half a million hectares per annum in Queensland alone— which parallels that going on in the Amazon Basin and the Taiga forests of Siberia.

But the minister says he is not going to confine himself to ecologically sustainable principles in spending money on the environment. This is not spending money on the nation as a whole; this is just the environment. He says he is not going to be confined by what the world think tank of scientists says should be our guiding lines in the 1990s. He is not going to be confined by what comes out of the alarm of those people who have the wisdom to look at the world. He says, `I am going to keep doing what we have done in the past and I will not even be confined to environmental principles in spending money on the environment.'

What a farce. What an abject farce. What a disgrace it is that, instead of the minister espousing environmentally sustainable development—ecologically sustainable development—he is saying, `I want an out from that. I want to be able to do what I want. I will pay lip‐service to it but I am not going to be bound by it.' It is reprehensible and the minister knows it. He is, of course, getting ample sustenance and support in this from the Independent senator from Tasmania, Senator Harradine, who has the pivotal vote in enabling him to get away with this—without, of course, being able to do more than say, `It may be that you will need to abide by a commitment to give 10 per cent of this money to Tasmania.' Well and good for Tasmania.

The whole of this money spent in Tasmania would not undo the damage that is being occasioned by Senator Hill and his government's licensing of the chainsaws and bulldozers moving in on our natural domain, including world heritage forests, at the moment. It would have been far better if Senator Harradine had stood up for the forests when he was needed rather than standing here in defence of this minister's welshing on his responsibilities to spend this money in top‐rate environmental care.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about maniacs like Alec Marr who started all this? Seriously.

—I have said before to the former minister that many Australians, including environmentalists, took the government at face value when Prime Minister Howard got up in the Sherbrooke forest and said, `I am going to commit this money to the environment.'
—I know that, but no‐one has come out and said, `We were conned.'
—I have, for one—
—All right. You have, but some of these other turkeys should do.
—and it was very clear last year that that was the case. But let's not blame those people who put good faith in Mr Howard.
—I do.

—Well, I put the blame on Prime Minister Howard, Senator Faulkner. And I put the blame on Senator Hill, who is doing the Prime Minister's bad work in the Senate; and I put the blame on Senator Harradine, who is ensuring that the laxity of these measures prevails against the sensible sort of innovation that Senator Lees, for the Democrats, is trying to get through on this occasion.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —We cannot let these requests slip through. I would like some clarification. These mean that, instead of the fund being spent over five years, it will now be spent over six years. Is this correct, Minister?

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —The minimum balance of $300 million must be achieved at the end of the year 2002, from memory.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, will you be topping up the fund? If you divide $1.1 billion by five, you get about $220 million a year. But if you divide it by six, you are spending only about $183 million a year. Therefore, we are falling short something like $38 million a year, unless the government will top up the fund and put in an extra $37 million or $38 million each year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think these amendments require some comment and debate in the committee. I will, nevertheless, keep my remarks brief. The government amendments 4 to 6 will be opposed by the opposition. This amendment removes the requirement for the base amount for the financial year that begins on 1 July 2001 to equal 30 per cent of the total amount transferred to the reserve and sets a fixed amount of $300,000 to remain in perpetuity after 1 July 2001.

SPEECH.PARA: The government has increased the amount to be transferred to the trust by $100 million to meet the terms of the arrangements it came to with Senator Harradine. The opposition believes that 30 per cent of this $100 million should be kept in perpetuity, as was originally required. Amending this bill to make it easier for the government to meet what I have described in the past as the Telstra vote deal with Senator Harradine is another example of the trust being manipulated, in my view, for political rather than environmental imperatives.

On the issue of perpetuity, I am somewhat interested in the government's approach, considering the trust expenditure commitments announced last night. How much will remain in the trust at the end of the financial year 2001? I would appreciate a response to that issue from the minister. Is the government on track to have at least $300 million left in the trust?

In relation to government requests 2 and 3, this goes to a crucial issue of the extension of the trust from five to six years. This extends the trust fund from a five-year program to a six-year program but with no extra funding for the sixth year. Last night's budget included no extra money for the trust. In fact, as far as I can see, it robbed $103 million from the trust. The government is about stretching the Telstra money out to 2002. By extending the trust fund over six years, the actual value of funding for the environment and sustainable agriculture to be spent by the trust has been reduced by nearly $50 million a year. I say to the committee that this is a massive dilution of the Natural Heritage Trust. It is an extra year but no extra money—that is the nub of it.

Last night's budget did not deliver on John Howard's environment funding promises. It did not deliver on the funding promises that Mr Howard made when he went for that walk in the forest during the last election campaign. That is the walk in the forest that I was referring to earlier with Senator Brown where, unfortunately, one or two of Senator Brown's close confidantes got sucked in and conned. They swallowed the John Howard line hook, line and sinker. The best example is Mr Alec Marr. It was the greatest environmental sell‐out in Australia's history. Senator Brown, I know that you have commented on this and I appreciate the points that you have made about what you have said in this debate on this issue, but let us not forget the way this operation worked. It was very disappointing to see people sucked in, conned and manipulated in that way, but I am not a bitter person.

I move on to this point, which I hope everyone can embrace, that last night's environment budget was a massive con. This proves it. It has effectively torn asunder the government's electoral mandate. You had at the centre of the coalition's campaign commitment an unqualified promise from the Liberals to provide $1.15 billion over five years to the environment on top of Labor's forward estimates. That is the promise that was made: $1.15 billion for five years, not six years, on top of Labor's proposed environment spending. I see Senator Harradine nodding. I assume that means that he accepts this. This is not an interpretation; this is a reality. This is a fact of life. This is what they said. This is the big con that I am talking about. But of course what the government has done is re‐badge its existing environment programs and put them under the natural heritage banner. And last night's budget robbed the Natural Heritage Trust of $103 million.
