TITLE.XREF: NATURAL HERITAGE TRUST OF AUSTRALIA BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will continue my contribution, Mr Temporary Chairman, which I thought was a rather good one. Let me in fact conclude because the point I am making is that this is an open and shut case of a breach of an election commitment. Let me not dwell on the fact that some in the environment movement swallowed this election commitment. Let me not dwell on that anymore. Let me just say it was a black and white election commitment. It was a pledge from the government, and the government tonight reneges on the commitment as well as reneging on the commitment in terms of the existing programs last night—the commitment to provide $1.15 billion on top of Labor's forward estimates.

SPEECH.PARA: So the government reneges on its commitment to the Natural Heritage Trust, and now it is further attempting to erode the trust. We in the opposition will not accept this cynical, sleazy fiddling of the books. We are not going to cop that. I have taken it pretty easy through this debate, but I want to place absolutely on the record what a scam from Senator Hill and the government this is. They ought to be exposed for this cynicism, this gross misleading of the Australian people in the election campaign.

BREAK.PARA: I think this government will basically do anything it can to weasel out of the commitment that it made to spend $1 billion on the environment over five years. As far as the opposition is concerned—and I hope other senators will join us—we are not going to stand by, Senator Hill, and let you abrogate your responsibilities, your commitment to the Australian people during the last election campaign. We will not let you slide away from commitments that you made. That is what are you trying to do—and you stand exposed and condemned for it.

I commend to the committee the knocking over of this proposal, the government requests and amendments, before us—knock them over, hold the government to its word, hold the government to its commitment. It has shown scant regard for these electoral commitments but often argues the case of electoral mandate—and it certainly has argued the case of electoral mandate in regard to the Telstra‐environment link. We heard it ad nauseam, the argument of mandate, when the Telstra partial privatisation was debated in this place.

From your own point of view, if you are going to be consistent, you will continue to argue the electoral mandate of the coalition—and that is, a properly constituted Natural Heritage Trust Fund, with funding over five years and expenditure over and above that which is contained in Labor's forward estimates. That is what you promised, and I hope the Senate ensures that, on that part—or on some part—of the commitments you made, you are held to them. You ought to be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just clarify the matter, I hope, for the benefit of the committee. It is true that in the last election we promised an expenditure of $1.149 billion over a period of five years. And, although it was difficult to be exact as to how that should be broken down, we nevertheless published indicative figures for each of the five years.

SPEECH.PARA: We started off, for example, with an indicative figure of $84 million in the first year—and that is the year that is just completing. The $1.149 billion was made up of a capital contribution, from our desired intention to sell one-third of Telstra, of $1 billion, then there was an interest component and there was also a component from recurrent expenditure.

What has happened subsequent to that is that we have decided to add a further $100 million, so that now the capital contribution to the fund will be $1.1 billion. Together with interest and a contribution from recurrent expenditure, the total expenditure will now be $1.249 billion, plus $300 million which will be left at the completion of this term of the trust. So we have increased the sum very substantially by $100 million. But we have also decided and announced last night that we would prefer to expend the larger sum over six years, one year having just about passed. This means that the balance of the fund would be spent over the next five years.

We were not able to spend in the first year what we had desired. We put in the indicative figure of $84 million—and I have to say that I am going from memory here. But when in the early stages of our government we re ceived such strong opposition to our intended sale, the government decided that it was irresponsible to advance $84 million up-front without there being any real assurance that we would ever get the capital infusion to repay that sum of $84 million.

So, in order to do some preliminary work on the trust, I think we got funding of about $20‐odd million. Then, when we got the sale of Telstra bill through the Senate, we went back and, through the additional appropriations, we could then speak more comfortably to the government about our wanting to accelerate the planning for the trust, the preliminary work. We got then a total of $41.9 million, which we will have expended. So about half of what we had intended to spend in the first year we spent.

We are now looking at a larger overall sum but with a much smaller contribution having been spent in the first year. The question then becomes: how do you responsibly spend the balance? The other thing we have become aware of through this preliminary work is that in a lot of areas around the country of Aus tralia—although in other areas a lot of the planning work has been done which will enable us to implement programs at an early date—there is still a great need for planning work before money actually being expended on the ground. It seemed to us as a result that to squeeze the balance of this larger sum of money into just the next four years would not result in the best possible environmental outcome; that it would be a more responsible approach to spend it over five years to allow better planning, where necessary, and the expenditure of the expanded trust fund to achieve, as I said, the optimum environmental outcome. So that is what we are doing.

We published last night new indicative figures of what we have in mind. They are published at page 3 of the document `Investing in our natural heritage'. Basically, it would mean, under the trust fund, the expenditure in this upcoming financial year of $186.9 million—and I do not believe that we can responsibly spend more than that consistent with this objective of getting the best environmental outcome—in the following year of $290 million, and in the years after that of $297 million, $279 million and $152 million respectively, which will leave us with the balance of $300 million. That is what has happened since the time that that original promise was made. What I would suggest to the committee is that what we are now putting before the committee and seeking to put into this legislation is a responsible approach to public expenditure but also an approach that will ultimately achieve the best environmental outcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very disappointed with your explanation for this, Minister. Basically, what you are now asking us to accept, after what you have told us as we have been through this bill and after what you have said about sticking to the eight per cent interest to try to maximise funds for Tasmania—and I agree that they have, compared to their population, larger responsibilities due to the very large reserves that we fortunately have in that part of Australia—is that you are now saying, `Sorry, it is all going to be absorbed because we are going to stretch this out for another year.' That is simply not acceptable.

SPEECH.PARA: Your only choice, as far as I can see, is to put another year's value into the fund. Surely, after the Telstra money is spent, we will not have a situation where there is nothing to spend on the environment. As you go through the figures in last night's budget you find that we are looking at $152 million for the last year. If that was something like $352 million we might be able to sit around and talk. There would still be some short changing. If you look at the average, we were expecting $230 to $250 million a year to be spent.

I agree with you that the first year may not have gone as you forecast, but there is no reason why that cannot be put out into years three or four. We do not have to stretch it over into year six and therefore spend less money on the environment. I believe it is a real sleight of hand to suggest that we have to accept a cut of somewhere between $200 and $250 million in terms of spending on the environment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —When this plan was announced to the elector ate Mr Costello made a commitment that there would be $223 million spend out of this fund in the coming financial year. What Senator Hill is saying now—and this includes the Harradine $25 million—is that in fact there will be $187 million spent this year. The promise to the electorate is being broken to the tune of $36 million if you put the best spin on it. If you were to discount the extra money that Senator Harradine got from the government, you could argue that it is over $60 million. It is at least $36 million that is not going to go into the environment because Senator Hill and the government have broken their election commitment.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me for a moment go back to what Senator Faulkner had to say when you traduced the name of Alec Marr. I have said it before in this place that Alec Marr is amongst one of those citizens who has gone to extraordinary lengths in their lifetime to stand up for the environment. I was at Farmhouse Creek when Mr Marr sat for not just days but weeks in a huge eucalypt tree which was the target of the chainsaws and bulldozers of the then Liberal government of Tasmania led by Robin Gray.

Although that tree was not saved and although the logging industry, with the full backing of the Liberals of the day, bust in vigilantes to assault environmentalists—and many were hurt on that particular occasion and the tree was ultimately destroyed—Alec Marr amongst many others kept on fighting and campaigning peacefully for those forests until years later they were protected as world heritage. He is one of those stirling people committed to the environment like those people currently sitting in the Giblett block in Western Australia because the Minister for the Environment sitting in here tonight has failed in his duty to protect part of the National Estate.

Along comes a Liberal promise to do better by the environment in the name of Prime Minister Howard March 12 months ago and in the wake of a pretty poor performance by the then Keating government which in turn in the wake of the loggers illegally circling Parliament House had gone to water and ordered vast tracts of the National Estate and, remarkably, important forests to be given across to the woodchip companies. That is just what happened.

As I said as an aside to Senator Faulkner, if you cannot believe the last opposition and if it was a reprehensible thing to believe the last opposition when you had a government that was failing in terms of its environmental responsibilities, is he not simply saying that next time around the opposition should not be believed either? Citizens have a right to expect that those who make promises at election time, in this case on the environment, will keep those promises. Not only is the promise that is inherent in this Natural Heritage Trust Fund being defrauded here today as this minister repeatedly sells out his obligations to ensure that the money is, under the terms of this legislation, for priority spending for the environment but it is very clearly and specifically being breached by this attenuation of the spending period from five to six years.

BREAK.PARA: What a clever little trick by Senator Hill. What a nasty little way to defraud the environment: instead of spending what you said you would spend, you take $36 million out of that obligation and put it over to some hypothetical future use. We must expect that further down the line there will be changes again to the way in which this Natural Heritage Trust Fund is established and the way its funds will be disbursed. One can only conjecture as to why they want to make it six years instead of five. We have not heard an explanation for that from Senator Hill.

He did try to say that he could not get his act in order and that he was not prepared to risk spending the necessary money because last year he could not get the guarantee that was later forthcoming from Senator Harradine that the legislation for the part sale of Telstra would get passage through this Senate. But he knew early on that it would; the deal was struck with Senator Harradine and the legislation went through. All he is saying is that he could not get his act together. He did not have the commitment and the wherewithal, and he did not give the environment the priority that was required of him to meet the Prime Minister's commitment to the people of this country that the money would be spent in the coming year on the environment according to the formula promised by Treasurer Costello.

We are led to believe that $36 million is being filched out of that fund to be spent in future years. No doubt the government thinks that it is going to get away with that in the Senate. I predict that it will not. l predict that even Senator Harradine is not going to accept this manipulation of this fund in a way which, because Senator Harradine got a better deal for Tasmania, will specifically impact on the expectations of Tasmanians, who, as the minister himself said, have a particular claim to government regard because of the enormous importance of the natural heritage in the island state.
I would hope that this committee is not going to allow this minister to get away with this sleight of hand.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not coping very well with these particular amendments. I feel that the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) did make a case which was fairly irrefutable. As Senator Lees has indicated, these amendments are, in effect, going to adversely impinge on what we all thought was the case at the time the government announced what it intended to do. I have listened carefully to what Senator Hill said in response to the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and I personally feel that 4, 5 and 6 do not meet the actual policy decision as expressed by the government, and I am inclined to vote against those amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make one last attempt to try to explain why this can actually lead to a better environmental outcome. I will respond very briefly to Senator Brown, who made the point and was very critical of the fact that, under this amended program that we think more accurately reflects the expenditure necessary to maximise the environment outcome, we would be spending less in this next year than what we had originally intended. I draw to his attention that in the following year, after the programs have had that extra year of development, we are actually spending considerably more than what we promised. If he adds up the funding expenditure intentions for the next two years and compares them with what was promised way back in the election he will find that they are not, in fact, very different.

SPEECH.PARA: It is the government's view that we can get a better environmental outcome. We are not just spending money for the sake of spending money; we are spending money to achieve the best environmental outcome within the terms of the objects and purposes of this bill, which reflects the objects and purposes of the trust. It is our view, now that we have had a year to spend on the planning to working up each of the major capital projects—the revegetation project, the coast and clean seas project, further work on the national reserve, further work on the land and water audit—that a lot more work needs to be done in terms of planning in the earlier stages to achieve the maximum output on the ground in the later stages.

To squeeze all of that into the next four years we do not believe will produce as good an environmental outcome as spending it over the next five years. It is true that it will take a little longer but in our view we get a better outcome. We do not really see the term of the trust in quite the same way as some others see it here because we intend it to be a trust in perpetuity. We do not claim that we are going to fix this problem in four or five years. What we have done to reflect our recognition that there is a need for a major ongoing program is to ensure that there is $300 million left available at the end of this term.

That will be a base, hopefully, that will be built upon by the government of the then day to continue the task of restoring the health of Australian's natural environment. I would respectfully suggest to the committee that what we are putting, although it is a little different to that which we put at the time of the last election, is nevertheless sensible, rational and very much environmentally sound.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of the $300 million that the minister indicates would be left in the trust, what is the minister's anticipation as to how that will be topped up to make it a reasonable trust fund for the purposes of expenditure on natural heritage after then and where will the money come from? How much does the government consider that they might get from the one‐third sale of Telstra? The original figure of $8 billion was certainly not an optimistic estimate as to what moneys would come from the one‐third sale. Does the minister have any idea at all or any up to date assessment of how much the one‐third sale would realise?

SPEECH.PARA: It has been suggested by many economists that it will realise a substantially greater amount than $8 billion. I am just wondering whether there is not more of that money which perhaps should be directed, rather than towards the redemption of debt, to this particular fund? That is probably a forlorn hope. I cannot see why we cannot go ahead as we thought, despite the fact that there was only about half of the amount spent in the first year than was foreseen? Why can't we stick to our five‐year program? I know you are saying that we might get a better outcome, but I frankly cannot quite see that at this stage.
Consideration interrupted; progress reported.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.20 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to discuss the future of Newcastle and the Hunter following recent announcements by BHP. The federal government is very concerned at BHP's decision to scale down steel making operations in Newcastle. The Howard government is committed to assisting those affected by the decision and really stands ready to help support the people in the Hunter region.

SPEECH.PARA: While I believe that BHP has made a commercial decision to cease integrated steel making in Newcastle, I deplore the timing of the announcement. It was actually an insult to the parliament of Australia because we did have an unfinished bipartisan steel inquiry still in process at the time of the announcement. The inquiry had finished its work in terms of visiting all the steel plants where we were accompanied by BHP officials but we were yet to report to the minister the result of those inquiries.

Senior BHP officials gave no indication at all to the government that they were about to make that decision. It was really a snub to the government and a snub to the parliamentary committee. The steel committee did meet earlier today with Ron McNeilly, the chair of BHP Steel, and we put this point very strongly to him at the time. We also called on the need for BHP to be a bit more forthcoming in the way they proposed to deal with the site from this time on.

BHP Steel started on this site in 1915. The plan before BHP came along was actually to make it a botanical gardens. It would take some effort in terms of site restoration to bring it back to being suitable for a botanical gardens. But it is certainly prime industrial land right on the harbour—the sort of thing which the world has a great shortage of—and it could be a very attractive site for future industry. We believe BHP has a moral obligation to lay down a plan, the timing, the costing and what they intend to do about cleaning up that site.

This decision by BHP will have a major impact on the Hunter; 2,500 direct jobs will go and another 1,000 contract jobs will go. The one small bright light in the BHP announcement was that they were going to relocate and upgrade the wire plant making facility, therefore locating all the long product and wire division in Newcastle. But this would represent only about 150 jobs as against a drop of 2,500.

I must clarify for the Senate something that is widely misunderstood by the public. People keep talking about the closure of steel in Newcastle. What is closing down, of course, is the smelting of steel in Newcastle, where most of the jobs are. But what is very important for the downstream industries is that steel will continue to be rolled in Newcastle. Of course, the engineering divisions which rely on this product downstream are very dependent on that. So even though the impact is great, it could have been a lot worse if BHP had decided to shut the plant totally.
I turn to the deplorable hypocrisy of the Labor Party on this matter. They come to this debate with no credibility at all, particularly after the failed Button steel plan.

TALK.START.PARA: —Failed? Ha, Ha!

—I see Senator Forshaw laughing over there. You think that was a successful plan. Well, wasn't it a brilliant success! You had 11,000 jobs in Newcastle and now you have got 3,000. What a great success! I would hate to think what you would call a failure. It was a major down‐scale. Indeed, what BHP announced in 1995 was a further down‐scale.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Schacht interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, under your government they were going to downsize further, from 3,500 to 1,000. Where was the Button steel plan mark 2 then? You are a bit quiet now, aren't you? You had no alternative; you had no plan whatsoever.
—Where was your steel plan?

—You can bleat over there but the hard reality is that you had no plan to do anything at that time. Where were the member for Newcastle, Mr Allan Morris, the member for Shortland, Mr Peter Morris and the member for Charlton, Mr Robert Brown—those Labor members for the Hunter—at the time that this was going on? They were incredibly quiet. They did flag at that time that the numbers would be reduced by this amount.

BREAK.PARA: The reason why it has all scaled down so drastically over this time, particularly since the Labor government came to power in 1993, was the very poor investment climate created by Labor in the 1980s. There was no upgrade of steel making in Newcastle. There were some patch‐up and fix‐up jobs. They shed 10,000 jobs, they lost $144 million and, under Labor, there was a massive decline. Their export performance fell away and, even though they did spend money at Port Kembla on building a new blast furnace, they just relined the old Newcastle plant. The incentive was not there under Labor's last scheme to save the steel industry in Newcastle.

The rank hypocrisy that I mentioned continued right until yesterday. The member for Hotham, Mr Crean, claimed yesterday that he was going to set up a new steel plan. Well, is he? Where was he in 1995 when you were in government? All of a sudden, now that you are in opposition, you are going to come up with a new steel plan.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where was yours? You had none.
—Let me read the quote, Senator Schacht. Mr Crean said:

BREAK.PARA: Had Labor still been in government, what was announced two weeks ago would not have happened.
What dishonest nonsense. Even Premier Carr was a little more honest on 29 April 1997 when he said:
It has to be said this is being done predominantly because of BHP's assessment of global factors.
Well, that is the truth. He could have added, `and the investment climate that Labor created.' Crean called this meeting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Would you like to refer to the gentleman from the other place by his correct title?

—Mr Crean called a crisis meeting in the Newcastle town hall to inflame this particular set‐up. Well, what a flop! The Newcastle Herald reported it with this headline, `Meeting high on passion, low on turnout'. There were 150 in the audience, and that included 15 ALP officials who were sitting on the stage, in a hall that seats 1,000. That is how interested they were in what Mr Crean had to say. On Labor's record of the last 13 years people knew he had no answer so why bother turning up to listen to him.

BREAK.PARA: Yesterday, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) announced a re‐positioning and assistance for the Hunter, and this is the start of considerable assistance that will flow over the next few years. He was called on, in a first response, by the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Carr, to come up with $10 million to match his $10 million, and for BHP to put in $5 million. By the way, BHP is still interested in this proposition. But the $10 million put up by Mr Carr in the Hunter advantage scheme is a promotional effort, `We have got a lot of things up here, come and set up industry.' It is good to promote the Hunter, but how many jobs are going to be there at the end of the day with such a scheme?

We will be setting up a number of projects that will deliver real jobs in the Hunter at this time. The Prime Minister will be coming up to the Hunter; a number of ministers will also be coming up to the Hunter; and they will put this in place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Name one!

—Let me point out a vital point about this downsizing, Senator Schacht. When most industries suddenly downsize, people are thrown out of work and within about a month you have got to find jobs for 500 people. We have a two‐year lead time on this. We are not going to have a knee‐jerk populist reaction like Mr Carr. We are going to come up with a sensible plan; there will be real jobs and there will be real projects as a result of it. Some of the new projects, by the way, were announced in the budget last night. There will be 1,000 new jobs created by the commitment of $140 million for roads for the Hunter Valley.

BREAK.PARA: Bob Baldwin, the member for Paterson, and I met with the Prime Minister the night before last and put forward a number of other projects that might be put into this plan. The Prime Minister is very supportive. It is not a Carr type knee‐jerk reaction. It will be a well‐targeted approach to help replace jobs that have been lost by the downsizing of BHP.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I think this is my first opportunity to speak since you have been elected as Deputy President. I congratulate you on your election and say `Long overdue' as circumstances have delayed your rightful accession to that position for some nine months.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to speak tonight about the issue of car tariffs and South Australia, the car industry in Australia and industry policy. I do not want to get diverted by the remarks of Senator Tierney talking about Newcastle. What his remarks showed is that this government has no industry policy at all. We had the disgusting spectacle of the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) preferring to be at the opening of the Melbourne casino than in Newcastle addressing and talking to people about the BHP closure and the loss of 2,500 jobs.

We do not want the same thing to happen to the car industry in South Australia as John Howard and John Moore let happen to the steel industry in Newcastle. As a result, last Friday, and on Monday of this week, I was in Japan, representing the federal parliamentary Labor Party and the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley, with Mr Mike Rann, the Leader of the Opposition in South Australia, explain ing to the Japanese companies that are involved in the car industry in South Australia what our tariff policy is and why we want them to continue to invest in the car industry in South Australia in particular, and in Australia, and why our tariff policy gives them the certainty that they can invest well into the next century.

We made it clear that at the state level the Liberal Party and the Labor Party have a bipartisan view about the tariff issue for the car industry. Unfortunately, we had to explain that the Liberal government here in Canberra has no policy; it keeps dithering and deferring any decision—which we think it should have made some time ago—to reject the idiocy in the Productivity Commission's recommendation that tariffs be reduced to five per cent for the car industry by the year 2005.

We outlined our policy: when tariffs get to 15 per cent by the year 2000 they would not go lower than that and would certainly be guaranteed to remain at 15 per cent until the year 2005; there would be a review in 2003 and 2004; and a look at any further reduction would only occur if our competitors in other APEC economies were also reducing their tariffs to the same level as we have in Australia, so that there was a fair and even, level playing field. We made that very clear.

We also made it very clear that we support the retention of the export facilitation scheme to encourage our car industry to continue its very successful program of exporting cars and car components from Australia, and particularly from South Australia.

On Friday of last week we met a major delegation from the Mitsubishi Motor Corporation led by Mr Kuromizu, the executive vice‐president of that company for their worldwide operations. He made their views very clear to us, in a presentation he gave us, by saying in conclusion that tariffs on passenger motor vehicles and components at 15 per cent ought to be maintained until at least 2005, and that either the export facilitation scheme ought to be maintained to post‐2000 or comparable levels of support to automotive exporters introduced. They made it clear that both those things are needed and, if they do not get that decision, they will review and not proceed with a $440 million investment for the next generation Verada and Magna in South Australia—a decision they have to make no later than January 1999.

If that decision is not made, that will be the end of manufacturing by Mitsubishi in South Australia and Australia by early next century. They also said that, if there was a decision not to maintain tariffs and the export facilitation scheme at the present level, they would then look at another country within APEC to manufacture their cars and, of course, export them into Australia. Mr Kuromizu made it very clear and said, in English—he did not use a translator—`And we are not bluffing.' I have to say to those who have had dealings over time with Japanese officials and senior business people, who are usually very polite and formal in these meetings, that for him to use English and to use a phrase that we all understand in Australia was very significant.

We also met with the Bridgestone company, which has a major tyre and car component manufacturing operation in Adelaide. We met with a Mr Uchiyama, who is the vice‐president of their international tyre operation and his phrase was very simple: if the tariffs go below 15 per cent in the year 2000 it would be fatal for their investment and fatal for their car component manufacturing in Adelaide, and it would be a very serious blow to their tyre manufacturing. Both these companies spoke politely, bluntly and firmly about the importance of getting the correct decision.

We indicated what the Labor Party policy is. We outlined it very clearly. They welcomed our decision. I have to say that I suspect they are at the moment quite perplexed that this federal government will not make a decision and has let it drag on. They also noted that Mr Hashimoto, the Japanese Prime Minister, when visiting Australia only two weeks ago, publicly raised the issue of the tariff policy and the importance of the investment of the Japanese car industry in Australia. So even at that level, during a state visit, it has been raised.

I also had the opportunity to meet with Vice‐Minister Ueno of the Ministry of Inter national Trade and Industry and explain our policy on tariffs, which he noted and welcomed. He understood our position and the importance of Japanese investment in car manufacturing in Australia.

I also took the opportunity on behalf of the Labor Party to completely reject the mad ideas of Pauline Hanson, who is calling for an end to foreign investment, calling for high tariffs and making unbelievably outrageous remarks about the possible `Asianisation' of Australia. I noticed that when I made those remarks at the MITI meeting in Japan their officials took it all down very seriously. They knew about the debate. What particularly alarmed me over the weekend in Tokyo was that in the Japanese Times English version they had reprinted the Bangkok Post editorial about the Hanson issue. I understand they had also on a day before, though I did not see it, reproduced a Sydney Morning Herald editorial on Pauline Hanson.

For anyone to say that she is not creating damage to Australia's long-term interests—particularly when we are trying to convince the Japanese Mitsubishi and Bridgestone companies to maintain their investment in the long term for jobs and economic wealth in Australia—when she says, `We don't want foreign investment,' is the height of economic lunacy. I think it is incumbent upon all of us at all times in the Labor Party and the Liberal Party and the National Party to reject completely the madness from Pauline Hanson. It is doing us significant damage overseas.

In conclusion, I appeal to this government to rapidly make a sensible decision on car tariffs within the next few weeks. They need to get on with the job so that we can guarantee the long-term future of thousands of jobs in Adelaide, Melbourne and Geelong in our car industry. If we lose the manufacturing of Mitsubishi and Bridgestone in South Australia and then General Motors, it will be a major blow to the economy of South Australia and put tens of thousands of people out of work. This is an issue that is a matter for South Australia. It is a life and death economic issue. This federal government must accept its responsibility and support South Australia but, above all else, we need a viable car industry for the future of all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I, too, extend my congratulations on your election and wish you well. I begin tonight with the notion of terra nullius. This nation is built on the back of the legal fallacy that is terra nullius—that is, that no-one was here when the white settlers arrived.

SPEECH.PARA: Aboriginal people did occupy this land in 1788 and had for tens of thousands of years. They respected this land. They cared for it. Their spiritual beliefs are centred upon it. They obtained all they needed from the land and their dreamings arose from and embraced this land. So it is almost inconceivable that the new arrivals could have so ignored their presence, could have legally overridden the presence of the indigenous inhabitants without any acknowledgment of their rights or even the fact that they were actually occupying the land.

As inconceivable as this may be, this is the history of our nation. It is this history that has created the chasm that exists between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians. Reconciliation was to be the process of acknowledging this history and seeking through active measures to restore to indigenous Australians some of that which has been stolen from them.

The fight to stop the bridge to Kumarangk on Hindmarsh Island has been taken up and led by indigenous women—not just the Ngarrindjeri women but also their sisters from other indigenous nations. It has become a symbol of the division between non-indigenous greedy development on the one hand and the beliefs of indigenous women on the other. Ngarrindjeri women have told us of the spiritual significance of Kumarangk and what it means to them. Did we listen? No. Non-indigenous Australians knew better. Non-indigenous Australians sought a factual, plausible, specific and unanimous base for these spiritual beliefs before they would listen.

How well would Christianity hold up to such scrutiny? How many loaves of bread did Jesus create out of nothing? Should we hold a royal commission to examine that? How many days after he died was he resurrected? Should we hold an inquiry to examine that? Is there no variation amongst the Anglican and Catholic Australians as far as their support or understanding of the Bible is concerned? Is it accepted that within a religion or a spiritual group there will be unanimous, unequivocal, unquestioning acceptance of all their stories and beliefs? Only for some, it seems.

The women of the SOPHIA Justice Circle—a group of Catholic women who are fighting for the rights of Aboriginal women in Adelaide—have provided a strong dissenting voice in the midst of this ongoing debate over Kumarangk. The Sisters of Mercy in Adelaide have worked hard to support the Ngarrindjeri women. The Kumarangk Coalition has brought together a cross-section of people—mostly South Australians, many of them from the Goolwa area—to fight for the Aboriginal women and to fight for the protection of the island and the Coorong that lies beyond. These three groups have taken part in the long march and are now preparing for the long sit-in.

It has not always been easy to stand up to the backlash against indigenous spirituality and indigenous culture in general. Nonetheless, these people have done so, and I congratulate them for their courage and commit ment in the face of adversity. Their determination to continue to support the women and to protect Kumarangk is an inspiration for all of us.

Tonight I am pleased to publicly associate myself with their efforts and to say that the Australian Democrats vehemently oppose the building of this bridge. It is an attack directly on the spiritual beliefs of indigenous people. It is an attack on the process of reconciliation. It is an attack on the very land that we are fortunate to occupy now. This attack must be resisted, and I and the Democrats will con tinue to do so. Such an attack on other religious groups in this country would, I suspect, not be tolerated at all.

So how is it that this nation has adopted the findings of a royal commission which has carried out this attack without the involvement of those women who specifically hold these beliefs? The royal commission was a sham. Its findings were a sham, and I now suspect that the Hindmarsh Island Bridge may be constructed as a result of this sham.

There is much work to be done if Aboriginal people are to feel at home in their own land. The constitution needs to be amended to reflect their presence here. The national anthem needs to be rewritten so that indigenous people have a place in it or that we at least remove the word `young', for people have been here a long time. It is time to correct our history, to base our written history on facts.

The High Court's decision on native title has begun that rewrite, but it is a very small step in the correction of the history of this nation. Terra nullius has been legally laid to rest. However, the battle is far from over. The battle against the Hindmarsh Island Bridge is but another small step in the process of reconciliation—another step in the fight to protect the limited native title rights of indigenous people and to ignore the greed and self-interest of a few developers.

The High Court's decision on native title was a very limited recognition of native title, although you would never believe that from listening to some of those recently commenting in the media. It was, on its own, a very narrow window of recognition of land rights for indigenous people. Yet this government seeks to obliterate even these slender rights.

The Wik decision was actually in favour of the pastoralists, ensuring that their rights, if there was any conflict, took precedence over native title rights. I state here tonight—and I am saying this personally—that I strongly oppose this government's attempts to water down and, in fact, extinguish the already weak native title rights as recognised by the High Court.

BREAK.PARA: The women of SOPHIA are absolutely correct in their view that Australia will be shamed in the eyes of the world if the government legislates to extinguish native title on pastoral leases. I believe the government is being held to ransom by a number of interested parties, including its coalition partner, the National Party, and those farmers who have a vested interest in getting their land converted to freehold.

What about the broader picture? What about the agenda of reconciliation that was a commitment of the Hawke government in the 1980s and that this government has committed itself to? What about the views of those Australians who believe that it is time for this country to recognise its indigenous inhabitants?

Once again, I thank SOPHIA, those women of the Catholic Church in Adelaide who have organised this group. I thank the Kumarangk Coalition who have done a lot of the work bringing together the various parties who are interested in these issues. I thank the Sisters of Mercy, particularly Sister Janet Mead, and indeed all those who are working so hard for reconciliation and working to stop the Hindmarsh Island Bridge. Your fight for the recognition of indigenous land rights, indigenous cultures and indigenous spiritualities is an important one, and the Australian Democrats will continue to stand by your side.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coonan, Sen Helen

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak briefly about Australia's foreign aid program. There are always perennial questions about whether Australia's program does enough to alleviate the plight of the poor living in our region in abject poverty, where hunger is indeed a grim reality. Equally compelling is the often asked question of how Australia can most effectively deliver the assistance it provides to recipient countries.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition has always acknowledged the importance of an effective aid program and, upon coming to office in 1996, commissioned an independent review of Australia's overseas aid program through the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Hon. Alexander Downer. The resulting report, One clear objective, chaired by Mr Paul Simons, more commonly referred to as the Simons report, attempts to address some of the funding inconsistencies which have plagued the foreign aid program during the last decade.

Fundamentally, Simons suggests that Australia's aid program is in need of renewal as opposed to fundamental change or dramatic overhaul. It raises the question: if the 1980s was the lost decade for development, has Australia the capacity to deliver more effective solutions to better respond to world poverty in the 1990s and beyond? I suggest that the obvious and fundamental issues to be addressed in the wake of the Simons review are why, where, how, and how much aid Australia should provide.

In the first comprehensive review of foreign aid in 13 years, Simons identifies the primary goal of the aid program as humanitarian—to reduce poverty through sustainable development. This goal of primary humanitarian focus is in line with community support, with 81 per cent of 2,011 surveyed responses in the most recent Roy Morgan research poll in May 1994 believing that aid should go to the very poor countries to respond to the priority areas of natural disasters, health promotion, basic needs and human rights.

The Simons report states that the primary motivation for providing aid is to help those less well off than ourselves. This is a laudable aim. But with this principle comes the need to address the extent to which the aid program can meet multiple objectives and whether it is possible and/or desirable to pursue compatible objectives through the aid program without distorting its primary focus.

The employment of a singular objective of poverty reduction to direct the provision of Australian aid raises four main questions. Firstly, whilst a primary goal of the aid program might be to reduce poverty reduction through sustainable development, this needs to be defined with measured and identifiable parameters within a specific time frame. Secondly, is it possible to isolate poverty reduction as a singular objective of the aid program when, in practice, questions such as human rights, geographical distribution, sectoral concentration and good governance influence the decision making process? Thirdly, is this singular objective of poverty reduction through sustainable development appropriate, given that the aid program can deliver a range of different outcomes such as those relating to Australia's engagement in the region and other policy interests, as well as assistance to Australian industry? Fourthly, to what degree are trade‐offs between different interests inevitable anyway?

One fundamental issue examined by the Simons review was how best to ensure the maximum effectiveness of the Australian aid program. Although the committee was alarmed by the proportion of Australian aid tied to the procurement of Australian goods and services, the report conceded that there is no mechanism to verify reported levels of tied aid and concludes therefore that the proportion of Australian tied aid may be overstated in relation to other donor countries.

The implication of breaking down the number of contracts per company or firm is that tied aid—similar to allegations about the former development import finance facility or DIFF scheme—has resulted in a concentration of benefits to a few select firms rather than net gains to the economy.

But given that there has been no comprehensive and authoritative study relating to the costs of tying Australian aid, the determination of the fate of tied aid is akin to stabbing in the dark. If you cannot measure the economic impact of tied aid, how can it be either supported or abandoned one way or the other?

Whilst supporting the principle of micro‐credit financing, it is disappointing indeed that the Simons report does not acknowledge in any way the role of women in maximising development benefits in this form of aid delivery. Micro‐credit has been firmly placed on the world's aid agenda following the International Micro‐Credit Summit held in Washington in February 1997. The preliminary analysis suggests overwhelmingly that targeting women in micro‐finance activities in developing countries results in significant multiplier effects as well as immeasurable benefits to the woman's immediate family— help the woman and you help the whole family.

Leaving issues of the relationship between aid and development unexplored, most commentary since the Simons report was brought out seems to concentrate in relation to foreign aid on the overstated question of `How much?' rather than `What for?' I suggest that those questions are ordered wrongly. In logical terms, the answer to `What for?' should determine the ballpark figure `How much?'

In the wake of the Year of the Eradication of Poverty, it is appropriate and timely for the Simons review to reflect on the progress made to eradicate world poverty and Australia's contribution to meeting this goal both now and in the future. I welcome the period of public consultation invited as a result of the report, welcome the fact that comment has been called for, and look forward to the valuable input of NGOs, industry groups and indeed other stakeholders in Australia. It is an important question and, as I said, it is a timely matter for us all to consider.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight on a matter with which Senator Alston says I am obsessed. No doubt, Senator Alston and those in the telecommunications industry who have his ear would like to silence me and others who speak out on the issue of the potential for electromagnetic radiation to detrimentally affect the health of Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: But I do not have an obsession; what I do have is a deep disquiet about the reluctance of the government to do anything but persistently try to discredit research findings on this issue. I must say that this increasingly futile endeavour has quite the opposite effect on the Democrats and many others who are starting to ask why it is that a government which is supposed to act to protect public health should act in such a defensive manner and ignore its responsibilities.

Far from being silenced, I want to talk at greater length another time about the research study conducted in Sydney and published last week. Of course, this study found an increased incidence of cancer in mice after their regular exposure to digital mobile phone emissions. This was a study which the industry and the government have been at pains to discredit as irrelevant to humans, even thought it was commissioned by Telstra, who presumably are not in the business of selling phones to mice. But I do not want to trivialise this issue by making silly jokes about mice using mobile phones. The government might find that amusing but we do not. I will speak later about the details of that study.

Tonight I want to again appeal to the government and to the industry to adopt the `precautionary principle' when it comes to wireless communications equipment and infrastructure. In its web site, Senator Alston's department says that it is not prepared to adopt the precautionary principle because:
There is no substantiated evidence that exposure to EMR from mobile phone towers will have an adverse health effect.
Earlier in that document it says:
The precautionary principle is based on the knowledge that some thing or action will have an actual or potential effect.

As I understand it, the research data showing biological effects—and therefore potential health effects—is quite substantial. I have already listed such data in this place. Even the Australian Radiation Laboratories information officer has recently been quoted in a Melbourne newspaper as saying:
. . . there plainly are non‐thermal effects, but it is difficult to interpret them to the extent of including them in the standard setting procedures.
The same officer, while touring Australia with the telecommunications roadshow in February this year, said:
. . . there are clearly some sort of athermal effects around.

If I am not much mistaken, there is a contradiction here. On the one hand, Senator Alston's department is stipulating that adoption of the precautionary principle is based upon knowledge of a potential effect—

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 27 February 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to unanswered questions put to the then Minister, Mr Lee, on 25 September 1995 (following a letter from Mr E and Mrs A Arends, dated 3 April 1995):
(1) Will the Telstra base station at Mount Kuring‐Gai telephone exchange be removed.
(2) Does the Minister understand that Mrs Arends has developed breast cancer since the installation of the tower.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Telstra has advised that it has no plans to remove the base station at Mt Kuring‐Gai. I am advised that whilst Telstra has investigated alternative sites for the base station, none of the sites is considered suitable for either environmental and/or technical reasons.
(2) I was advised of this in a letter dated 21 March 1996 from Mrs Arends which she sent to her local member who forwarded it to me.
(3) I was advised of this in a letter dated 16 January 1997 from the local member, the Hon. Philip Ruddock MP.

(4) Mrs Arends' letter to me was sent to her local member, Mr Ruddock, who took up the issues with me on behalf of Mrs Arends. As Mr Ruddock raised the issues associated with the base station located near the Arends' property on behalf of a number of residents, I responded to him in the context of those general representations.
(5) It does not follow that the presence of a telephone base station represents an effective subsidy of telecommunications carriers by private property owners.

(6) The Government has considered the issue of concerns about the potential for reduced property values in residential areas near telecommunications infrastructure generally. We have decided that it is not possible to introduce an appropriate regime—principally because the difficulty of appraising any loss of value which individual property owners might have suffered. In particular, since telecommunications facilities are installed throughout the community it is difficult to conclude that property owners near such facilities have been singled out for discriminatory treatment of a kind which would found a case for compensation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 27 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the answers to questions on notice nos 2066 and 2091 (Senate Hansard, 19 June 1995, pp 1380 and 1395, respectively) and question on notice no 200 (Senate Hansard, 26 November 1996, p.6069):

(1) Was drilling of production seepage recovery bores carried out on Hampton Location 32 Trans Australian Railway near Fimiston 11 tailings dam near cell B, paddock west, in the period between 20 January 1997 to 23 January 1997.
(2) (a) How many bores were drilled; and (b) how long did each bore take to drill and construct.
(3) To what depth were these bores drilled and constructed.
(4) Who carried out this work.
(5) What is the purpose of these bores.
(6) Are these bores for monitoring ground water levels.
(7) Are these bores for taking water samples.
(8) Did excavations with mechanical equipment take place near the site of the drill holes.

(9) Can a plan showing the location of these new bores, along with all the monitoring bores, production seepage recovery bores and interceptor trenching located near Croesus/Fimiston 1 and Fimiston 11 and Oraya tailings dam be provided.
(10) Will further seepage recovery or monitoring bores be constructed in future on Hampton Location 32 Trans Australian Railway.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice from the Australian National Railways Commission (AN):

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Drilling was carried out on the eastern side of the railway line at the site mentioned between or about the dates given.
(2) (a) Three bores were drilled on AN land; and (b) the average time for each bore was approximately one day.
(3) AN has not been able to provide precise information on the depth of the bores, but estimates that the depth was between 15 and 20 metres.
(4) The hydrologist was Peter Clifton and Associates and the drilling contractor was NuDrill.
(5) The purpose of these bores is to control ground water levels. It is assumed seepage from the Fimiston tailings dam is being recovered.
(6) No. See the answer to (5).
(7) No. See the answer to (5). However, it is understood that KCGM takes water samples from the bores.
(8) Yes. Standard practice is to construct temporary sumps to contain any water which is extracted from the bore during the drilling process.
(9) AN does not hold a plan of the area with these items marked.

(10) AN has advised that further bores are envisaged at this stage. The advice of the hydrologist and the Western Australian Environment Protection Authority would be used to determine the need and extent of additional bores.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 27 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the Senate debate on the Bankruptcy Amendment Bill 1996, the Bankruptcy (Estate Charges) Bill 1996 and the Bankruptcy (Regulation Charges) Bill 1996:
(1) What are the names of the top 20 bankrupts in Australia, by value, for the period 1985 to 1997.
(2) How many and which of these have been jailed, and for what offences.

(3) With regard to those bankrupts can the Government provide the names of any banking, legal audit accounting, valuers and other organisations largely instrumental in professionally advising and servicing the above persons and businesses of these persons prior to bankruptcy.

PARA.TAB: (4) Can the Government indicate whether it has contracted the services of any of the organisations identified in paragraph (3) to undertake any significant work for, or on behalf of the Government during the period 1985 to 1997.

QUESTION.PARA: (5) What is the selection process undertaken by the Government in the investigation of banking, legal, audit accounting, valuers, or other organisations prior to contracting the services of such organisations.
(6) Does that selection process identify whether such organisations have been principal advisers to convicted corporate crooks, or major bankrupts; if so, what action is then taken.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Information about values of indebtedness of those bankruptcies administered by the Official Trustee (ITSA) could be recovered. This would require extensive resources being devoted to writing a special computer program to extract and collate the information. However, in respect of those bankruptcies administered by private sector Registered Trustees who, in almost all cases, administer those bankruptcies with high levels of debt (ie the "top" bankruptcies to use the honourable Senator's term), the information would have to be extracted manually from Statements of Affairs. This also would be resource intensive.

Also, the data that would be the source of this information is limited to the understanding of the bankrupt at the time of completing the Statement of Affairs and therefore could not be considered entirely accurate given that, in the course of the administration of estates, the Trustee often ascertains better information about the extent of indebtedness.

Accordingly, the information which could be collected could well be misleading in terms of identifying the persons sought. I therefore do not consider it appropriate to divert and expend resources to this end.
(2), (3), (4) Not applicable

(5) Where consultants are engaged by the Commonwealth to undertake the tasks referred to in the question, each Department should, in accordance with DAS Procurement Guideline Number 13 "Contracting for Consultancy Services", investigate or at least consider security and probity issues before selecting a consultant.

PARA.TAB: (6) The selection process should identify any problems in these areas so that an informed decision can be made as to whether the consultant should be engaged to undertake the work.

ANSWER.PARA: The DAS guidelines form the basis for the Attorney-General's Department procedures applying to the engagement of consultants.
